Quiz Attempt #119605

Total Questions: 82
Question 1
What are the different strategies from reset pricing to capture.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)A. Challenge the cost route by ideology the inflection price pointB. Offering lower/ agodesle price pointC. Penetration PricingD. What the traffic can bear’ pricingE. Absorption cost pricingChoose the most appropriate from the option given below:
  • A.A and C only
  • B.D and E only
  • C.A and B only
  • D.B and only
Correct Answer: A and B only

The correct answer is (C) A and B only

 

Option A refers to challenging the cost route by identifying the inflection price point, which is a strategy to capture value.

Option B involves offering lower or aggressive price points to capture market share.

Question 2
_______takes into accounta host of inputs, such as buyer's image of the product performance, the channel deliverables, the warranty quality, customer support and softer attributes such as thesuppliersreputation, trust worthiness and esteem.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)
  • A.Target rate-of-return pricing
  • B.Auction-type pricing
  • C.Economic-value-to-customer pricing
  • D.Competitive pricing
Correct Answer: Economic-value-to-customer pricing

The option that takes into account a host of inputs, such as buyer's image of the product performance, channel deliverables, warranty quality, customer support, and softer attributes such as the supplier's reputation, trustworthiness, and esteem, is option (C), i.e., Economic-value-to-customer pricing.

 

Let us explain the options one by one.

  • Target rate-of-return pricing: This pricing strategy involves setting prices to achieve a target rate of return on investment or profit margin. It typically focuses on the company's internal financial objectives rather than customer perceptions or value.
  • Auction-type pricing: This involves setting prices through an auction process, where buyers bid for products or services, and prices are determined based on the highest bid. It is not specifically tailored to consider the various attributes mentioned in the question.
  • Economic-value-to-customer pricing: Economic-value-to-customer (EVC) pricing is a pricing strategy that seeks to set prices based on the value that a product or service delivers to the customer. It takes into account a range of factors, including product performance, channel deliverables, warranty quality, customer support, and softer attributes such as reputation and trustworthiness. EVC pricing aims to capture the value that customers perceive in a product or service and align pricing accordingly.
  • Competitive pricing: This strategy involves setting prices based on competitors' prices or market norms. While competitive pricing may consider some customer perceptions, it may not comprehensively account for all the inputs mentioned in the question.

Therefore, the option that aligns with the description provided is (C), i.e., Economic-value-to-customer pricing.

Question 3
Match the List-I with List-II(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)LIST I (Pricing Strategies)A. Skimming Price PolicyB. Penetration Price PolicyC. Peak Load Pricing PolicyD. Dumping Pricing PolicyLIST II (Their Explanation)I. Where the nature of the productsarenon-storableII. Where close substitutes of a new product are not availableIII. Exporting goods at a price lower than the domestic priceIV. Substitutes of new products are availableChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- III, B-II, C- I, D-IV
  • B.A- IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • C.A- I, B- III, C-II, D-IV
  • D.A- II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
Correct Answer: A- II, B-IV, C-I, D-III

Here’s the matching explanation:

A. Skimming Price Policy – II. Where close substitutes of a new product are not available:
Skimming involves setting a high initial price to maximize profit from customers who are willing to pay a premium, especially when there are no close substitutes.

B. Penetration Price Policy – IV. Substitutes of new products are available:
Penetration pricing sets a low initial price to attract customers and gain market share quickly when substitutes are available.

C. Peak Load Pricing Policy – I. Where the nature of the products are non-storable:
This strategy charges higher prices during peak demand periods, commonly used for services or non-storable goods.

D. Dumping Pricing Policy – III. Exporting goods at a price lower than the domestic price:
Dumping involves selling products in a foreign market at a price lower than in the domestic market to increase market share or eliminate competition.

Thus, the correct matching is A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III.

Question 4
Match the List I with List II(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)List I (Pricing situation)A. Product line PricingB. Optional product pricingC. Captive product pricingD. By-product pricingList II (Description)I. Pricing optional or accessory products sold with the main productII. Setting prices across an entire product lineIII. Pricing low value by product to get rid of or make money on themIV. Pricing products that must be used with the main product.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • B.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • D.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
Correct Answer: A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III

The correct matching between List I (Pricing situation) and List II (Description) is:

A. Product line Pricing - II. Setting prices across an entire product line
B. Optional product pricing - I. Pricing optional or accessory products sold with the main product
C. Captive product pricing - IV. Pricing products that must be used with the main product
D. By-product pricing - III. Pricing low value by-product to get rid of or make money on them

So, the correct answer is (C) A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III.

Question 5
Which one of the following conditions is not true in case of marketing skimming as the pricing objective?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)
  • A.The market is highly price-sensitive
  • B.A sufficient number ofbuyerssignala high demand
  • C.The high initial price does not attract more competitors to the market
  • D.The high price communicates the image of a superior product
Correct Answer: The market is highly price-sensitive

The correct answer is (A) The market is highly price-sensitive. Marketing skimming is a pricing strategy where a company sets a high initial price for a new product to "skim" the maximum revenue from the segments willing to pay the high price before lowering it to attract more price-sensitive customers.

 

(A) The market is highly price-sensitive:

This is not true in the case of a skimming pricing strategy. Skimming works when the market is not highly price-sensitive because the strategy targets customers who are willing to pay a premium for the product initially. If the market were highly price-sensitive, skimming would not be effective, as fewer customers would be willing to pay the high price.

 

(B) A sufficient number of buyers signal a high demand:

This is true. Skimming pricing relies on the assumption that there is enough demand from early adopters who are willing to pay a higher price, signaling that the market can support such pricing initially.

 

(C) The high initial price does not attract more competitors to the market:

This is true. The high price can act as a barrier to entry for potential competitors who might find it difficult to match the high price with their own products without offering something superior. This helps the company maintain its competitive advantage for a longer time.

 

(D) The high price communicates the image of a superior product:

This is true. A high price can signal to consumers that the product is of high quality or has a premium image, which is consistent with the goals of a skimming strategy.

Question 6
Multi-stage approach to product pricing in a firm involves considerations for setting the price as follows: (UGC NET Management Dec 2013)i. Selection of firm’s objectiveii. Composition of marketing-mixiii. Selection of target marketiv. Selection of pricing policy and strategyIndicate correct sequence:
  • A.iv → ii →i→ iii
  • B.iii →i→ ii → iv
  • C.ii → iv → iii →i
  • D.i→ iii → ii → iv
Correct Answer: iii →i→ ii → iv

The multi-stage approach to product pricing in a firm involves a systematic process of considering different factors before setting the price. The correct sequence is indicated by option (B), which is "iii → i → ii → iv." Let us break down each step:

 

iii. Selection of Target Market:

  • The first step involves identifying and selecting the target market for the product. This means determining the specific group of consumers who are most likely to be interested in and purchase the product.
  • Understanding the target market's preferences, needs, and buying behaviors is essential to setting an appropriate price that resonates with this segment.

 

i. Selection of Firm's Objective:

  • Once the target market is defined, the firm needs to establish its pricing objectives. These objectives could vary, such as maximizing profits, gaining market share, achieving a specific return on investment (ROI), or creating brand image.
  • The pricing objectives guide the pricing strategy and decisions throughout the product's lifecycle.

 

ii. Composition of Marketing-Mix:

  • With pricing objectives in mind, the firm then considers the entire marketing mix, which includes the product, promotion, distribution, and pricing strategies.
  • The price should align with the overall marketing strategy, product positioning, and perceived value among the target market.

 

iv. Selection of Pricing Policy and Strategy:

  • Finally, after analyzing the marketing mix and understanding the firm's objectives, the pricing policy and strategy are determined.
  • This step involves deciding whether to adopt a premium pricing strategy, value-based pricing, cost-plus pricing, skimming, penetration, or any other approach that aligns with the firm's goals and market conditions.
Question 7
What kind of pricing strategy a firm should normally follow for marketing electronic goods? (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.Penetration pricing strategy
  • B.Skimming pricing strategy
  • C.Cost plus pricing strategy
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The correct answer is (D) All of the above.

 

A firm marketing electronic goods may employ various pricing strategies depending on its specific objectives and the market conditions. These strategies can include:

 

(A) Penetration pricing strategy: This involves setting a lower initial price for electronic goods to quickly gain market share and attract price-sensitive customers.

 

(B) Skimming pricing strategy: This strategy involves setting a high initial price for new electronic products to maximize profit from early adopters and then gradually lowering the price over time as demand from price-sensitive customers increases.

 

(C) Cost-plus pricing strategy: This strategy involves adding a markup to the cost of producing electronic goods to determine the selling price.

 

So, a firm may choose any of these pricing strategies based on its market positioning and goals for its electronic goods.

Question 8
Match the items/persons included in List – I with the items in List – II and indicate the correct pairing through codes given below: (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)List – Ia. CCIb. Cognitive dissonancec. Everett M. Rogersd. Theodore LevittList – IIi. Consumer buying decision processii. ‘Marketing Myopia’iii. Diffusion of Innovationiv. Predatory pricingCodes:
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
  • C.a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
  • D.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii

The correct pairing of items/persons in List - I with the items in List - II is as follows:

 

a. CCI (Competition Commission of India)- Predatory pricing

b. Cognitive dissonance - Consumer buying decision process

c. Everett M. Rogers - Diffusion of Innovation

d. Theodore Levitt - 'Marketing Myopia'

 

So, the correct answer is (D) a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii.

Question 9
Match the items of the List – I with those of the List – II and suggest the correct code from the following: (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)List – Ii. Loss Leaderii. Unchanged Pricingiii. Basing Point Pricingiv. Skimming PricingList – IIa. Locational price differentialsb. Products with high initial demandsc. Product line pricingd. Oligopoly pricingCodes:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.c-i, d-ii, a-iii, b-iv
  • C.d-i, b-ii, a-iii, c-iv
  • D.c-i, a-ii, b-iii, d-iv
Correct Answer: c-i, d-ii, a-iii, b-iv

The matches between pricing strategies and their explanations are as follows:

 

i. Loss Leader - Product Line Pricing:

Loss Leader Pricing is a strategy where a company intentionally sets the price of a product below its cost to attract customers to the store or website. It's often used to lure customers in with the hope that they will also buy other, more profitable items. Loss leader pricing is closely related to Product Line Pricing, where a range of products within the same category is priced at different levels to appeal to different segments of the market. So, the connection here is that loss leaders are typically part of a broader product line pricing strategy.

 

ii. Unchanged Pricing - Oligopoly Pricing:

Unchanged Pricing refers to a strategy where a company maintains a stable price for its products over an extended period, often regardless of market conditions. This strategy can be observed in markets with few dominant competitors, known as an Oligopoly. In an oligopolistic market, competitors are cautious about changing prices because any price change by one firm can have a significant impact on the market and potentially trigger a price war.

 

iii. Basing Point Pricing - Locational Price Differentials:

Basing Point Pricing is a strategy where the seller establishes one or more "basing points" from which they calculate transportation costs to different buyer locations. The price of the product is then determined by adding the transportation cost to the basing point. This strategy is closely related to Locational Price Differentials, where the price of a product can vary based on the geographic location of the buyer. In essence, basing point pricing is a way to account for and standardize the impact of locational price differentials.

 

iv. Skimming Pricing - Products with High Initial Demands:

Skimming Pricing is a strategy where a company sets a relatively high initial price for a new product, especially when there is strong initial demand from early adopters or customers who are willing to pay a premium for the product's unique features or benefits. This approach allows the company to "skim" the highest possible revenue from these customers before gradually lowering the price to attract a broader audience. So, the connection here is that skimming pricing is often applied to Products with High Initial Demands to maximize initial profits

Question 10
A company prices a 2-litre bottle of its mineral water at ₹ 30 but 60 ml of the same water in a moisturizer spray for ₹ 75. This is an example of which one of the following pricing practices? (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.Product-Form pricing
  • B.Customer-segment pricing
  • C.Image pricing
  • D.Location pricing
Correct Answer: Product-Form pricing

In the given scenario, the company prices a 2-litre bottle of mineral water at ₹30, but charges ₹75 for 60 ml of the same water included in a moisturizer spray. This pricing strategy is an example of Product-Form pricing.

 

Product-form pricing is a type of segmented pricing where different versions or forms of the same product are priced differently, without necessarily reflecting differences in their costs. In this case, the mineral water is offered in two different forms: a larger 2-litre bottle and a smaller 60 ml portion as part of a moisturizer spray. Despite the fact that the costs associated with the water itself might be relatively consistent, the pricing is adjusted based on the form in which the water is offered and the context in which it is used.

 

This type of pricing is often used when companies offer variations of a product that cater to different customer preferences, usage contexts, or perceived values. Customers who are willing to pay more for the convenience and specific benefits of the moisturizer spray are charged a higher price for the water contained in that form. On the other hand, the larger bottle of mineral water might be priced lower to appeal to customers seeking more quantity at a lower cost.

Question 11
Which of the following factors does not influence the pricing strategy of a firm?(UGC NET Management Jun 2009)
  • A.Market
  • B.Competition
  • C.Cost
  • D.R & D
Correct Answer: R & D

The factor that does not typically influence the pricing strategy of a firm is (D) R & D (Research and Development).

 

While factors such as the market, competition, and cost are crucial considerations in determining a pricing strategy, research and development activities are not directly related to the pricing decision. R&D focuses on product development, innovation, and improving the quality and features of products or services, but it doesn't directly dictate the pricing strategy. Pricing decisions are more closely tied to factors like production costs, market demand, competitor pricing, and the value perceived by customers.

Question 12
Which of the following statements are applicable to value-based pricing concept? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)a. Design product to deliver desired value at target price.b. Set target price to match customer perceived value.c. Determine costs that can be incurred.d. Convince buyers of product's value.e. Assess customer needs and value perceptions.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a, b, c and e only
  • B.a, b, c and d only
  • C.b, c, d and e only
  • D.a, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, b, c and e only

The correct answer is A.

 

Value-based pricing is a pricing strategy that aims to set the price of a product or service based on the perceived value it provides to the customer. The key idea is to design products and services that deliver the desired value to the customer and set prices that match or exceed the customer's perceived value.

 

Based on this definition, the following statements are applicable to the value-based pricing concept:

a. Design product to deliver desired value at target price.

b. Set target price to match customer perceived value.

c. Determine costs that can be incurred.

e. Assess customer needs and value perceptions.

 

Question 13
XYZ company is in the business of FMCG products focusing on items like Atta, Besan, Maida etc. They are presently operating outside Delhi, in the state of Haryana. Looking at demand in Delhi, they want to market their products in Delhi, covering the entire Delhi. After going through various market reports and market surveys, they found that competition is very high in Delhi. They want to focus on the quality of their products and still want to fight the competition. They want to create a marketing strategy for their business at the time of entering the Delhi market. For doing so, they have appointed you as Manager Marketing (In-charge Delhi) to design a marketing strategy for them.As the Marketing Manager of XYZ company, what type of pricing strategy would you recommend? (UGC NET Management Jun 2021)
  • A.Image pricing
  • B.Complementary pricing
  • C.Captive pricing strategy
  • D.Loss leader strategy
Correct Answer: Captive pricing strategy

Option C is the correct answer.

 

When competition is high and quality needs to be maintained, captive-product pricing is well suited.

 

Captive-product pricing is setting a price for products that must be used along with a main product. It refers to a strategy that helps attract consumers to the main product set at a low price. And then strongly recommend them to buy the accessory that goes with the main product.

Question 14
Under the cost-based pricing, the following methods approaches commonly are commonly used: - (UGC NET Management Jun 2020)a. Marginal costing pricingb. Mark up pricing (cost plus pricing)c. Absorption cost pricing (full cost pricing)d. Return on investment pricingChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.b, c and d only
  • C.a, c and d only
  • D.a, b, c and d - all
Correct Answer: a, b and c only

The correct answer is (A) a, b and c only.

 

Under cost-based pricing, the pricing strategy is determined primarily by considering the costs associated with producing and selling a product or service. Different cost-based pricing methods can be used to set the selling price of a product. Among the methods mentioned:

 

a. Marginal Costing Pricing: Marginal costing pricing, also known as variable costing pricing, involves setting the price based on the variable costs incurred in producing a unit of the product. Variable costs include direct materials, direct labor, and variable overhead. Fixed costs are not considered in this approach. This method is particularly useful when making short-term pricing decisions.

 

b. Mark Up Pricing (Cost Plus Pricing): Mark up pricing involves adding a certain percentage or amount (mark up) to the cost of producing the product to determine the selling price. The mark-up covers both the variable and fixed costs of the product and includes a profit margin. This approach is commonly used in various industries and helps ensure that the company covers its costs while generating a desired level of profit.

 

c. Absorption Cost Pricing (Full Cost Pricing): Absorption cost pricing, also known as full cost pricing, considers both variable and fixed costs when setting the price. It includes direct materials, direct labor, variable overhead, and a portion of fixed overhead costs. This method aims to recover all costs, both variable and fixed, through the selling price. It can be particularly relevant when a company wants to ensure that all costs are covered.

 

d. Return on Investment (ROI) Pricing: Return on Investment pricing focuses on setting the price to achieve a specific target return on the investment made in producing the product. This method takes into account the overall profitability of the investment and aims to ensure that the generated profit aligns with the desired ROI.

 

In this question, options a, b, and c are the cost-based pricing methods that are commonly used. Option d, "Return on Investment pricing," is not included in the list of common methods for cost-based pricing. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) a, b and c only.

Question 15
Penetration price strategy followed under which of the following conditions?I. Where there is a high degree of price elasticity of demandII. When strong competition is expected soon after product introductionIII. When company wants to recoup its research and development expenditureIV. When company must keep demand within its production capacityChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Management Jun 2022)
  • A.I and III only
  • B.II and IV only
  • C.I and II only
  • D.I and IV only
Correct Answer: I and II only

The correct option is (C) I and II only.

 

I. Where there is a high degree of price elasticity of demand: This statement is true. Penetration pricing is often used when demand is price-sensitive or elastic. By setting a lower price initially, the company aims to attract a larger number of price-sensitive customers, achieving higher sales volumes and market share.

 

II. When strong competition is expected soon after product introduction: This statement is true. In competitive markets, where rivals might quickly enter the market or respond with aggressive pricing, penetration pricing can help the company gain a foothold and pre-empt competitors from gaining a significant market share.

 

III. When the company wants to recoup its research and development expenditure: This statement does not align with penetration pricing. Penetration pricing involves setting a lower price to enter the market, while recouping R&D expenditure would typically involve setting a higher price to recover costs quickly.

 

IV. When the company must keep demand within its production capacity: This statement is not directly related to penetration pricing. However, penetration pricing could lead to higher demand, which might pose challenges if a company's production capacity cannot keep up with the increased demand.

Question 16
Indicate the correct code for appropriate combination of the following that constitutes the form of price discriminating strategy: - (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)(i) Postage stamp pricing(ii) Basing point pricing(iii) Incremental pricing(iv) Free On-Board pricingChoose the correct answer from the code given below:Codes:
  • A.Only (iii) and (iv)
  • B.Only (i), (ii) and (iii)
  • C.Only (i), (ii) and (iv)
  • D.Only (ii), (iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: Only (i), (ii) and (iv)

The correct answer is (C) Only (i), (ii) and (iv).

 

Postage stamp pricing: This refers to a pricing strategy where a uniform price is charged for the product or service, regardless of the location of the buyer. It's called "postage stamp" pricing because, like a postage stamp, the price is the same everywhere.

 

Basing point pricing: Basing point pricing involves charging customers a price based on a particular geographic location, usually a central point of production or distribution. The price may include transportation costs from that point to the customer's location.

 

Incremental pricing: Incremental pricing involves charging different prices for units of a product based on the quantity ordered. The price decreases as the quantity ordered increases, encouraging customers to buy in larger quantities.

 

Free On-Board pricing: Free On-Board (FOB) pricing is a shipping term indicating that the seller is responsible for the cost and risk of transportation of the goods until they are delivered to a specific location, often a port of shipment.

Question 17
Indicate the correct code for the points taken into consideration for product line pricing from the following: (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)1.Demand relationships of different products2.Competitive situation in the product market3.Advertising endeavours for different products4.Cost estimates for various productsChoose the correct answer from the code given below:Codes:
  • A.Only (i), (ii) and (iv)
  • B.Only (i), (ii) and (iii)
  • C.Only (ii) and (iii)
  • D.Only (ii), (iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: Only (i), (ii) and (iv)

The correct answer is (A) Only (i), (ii) and (iv).

 

Demand relationships of different products: This involves understanding how the demand for one product within a product line may affect the demand for other products within the same line. For example, the pricing of one product might impact the demand for complementary products or substitutes within the same line.

 

Competitive situation in the product market: Understanding the competitive landscape helps in determining the pricing strategy for different products within a product line. Pricing decisions should consider how the products are positioned in relation to competitors' offerings.

 

Advertising endeavours for different products: While advertising is important for promoting products, it might not directly influence the pricing strategy. However, advertising efforts can impact the perceived value of products, which in turn can affect pricing decisions.

 

Cost estimates for various products: Cost estimates are crucial for setting prices for different products within a product line. Costs include production, distribution, and other associated expenses. Pricing decisions need to ensure that costs are covered while achieving desired profit margins.

Question 18
“Manufacturers of razors and cameras often price these products low and set high mark ups on razor blades and films.” (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)As per the above statement, manufacturers of razors and cameras are using which one of the following?
  • A.Captive-product pricing
  • B.Two-part pricing
  • C.Product-bundling pricing
  • D.By-product pricing
Correct Answer: Captive-product pricing

The pricing strategy described in the statement is an example of captive-product pricing. Captive-product pricing is a strategy where the price of the main product is kept low to attract customers, but the price of complementary products or consumables (such as razor blades and films) is set high to make up for the low price of the main product. The idea is to create a "captive" market for the complementary products, where customers are more likely to continue buying the same brand of consumables instead of switching to a competitor.

Question 19
Which one of the following pricing method is used in regulated industries? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Mark-up Pricing
  • B.Target-Rate-of-Return- Pricing
  • C.Economic-Value-to-Customer Pricing
  • D.Competitive Pricing
Correct Answer: Target-Rate-of-Return- Pricing

The correct answer is (B) Target-Rate-of-Return Pricing.

 

Target-Rate-of-Return Pricing involves setting the price of a product or service at a level that allows the company to achieve a specified rate of return on its investment or capital. The regulatory authorities typically determine this rate of return based on factors such as the company's costs, the risks associated with the industry, and the need for reasonable profits while ensuring that consumers are not charged excessively. This approach helps strike a balance between the interests of the company and the consumers, ensuring that the company has a fair opportunity to recover costs and make a reasonable profit while keeping prices reasonable for consumers.

Question 20
Which among the following is not an internal factor of pricing decision? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Consumer behaviour for given product
  • B.Position of product in product cycle
  • C.Consumer’s expectation from company by past pricing
  • D.Price elasticity as per sales of product
Correct Answer: Consumer behaviour for given product

The correct answer is (A) Consumer behavior for a given product.

 

Consumer behavior for a given product is an external factor that influences pricing decisions. Internal factors generally refer to aspects that are within the control or realm of the company, such as costs, marketing objectives, product lifecycle stage, and desired profit margins. On the other hand, consumer behavior is an external factor as it is influenced by various elements outside the company's direct control, such as market demand, preferences, perceptions, and purchasing power of consumers.

Question 21
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion “A” and the other labelled as Reason “R”. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)Assertion “A”:Purchase decisions are not based on how customers perceive prices but on the marketer’s stated price.Reason “R”:Customers may have a lower price threshold, below which prices signal inferior or unacceptable quality, and an upper price threshold where the product appears not worth the money.Code:
  • A.“A” is incorrect but “R” is correct.
  • B.Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is the right explanation of “A”.
  • C.Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is not the right explanation of “A”.
  • D.Both “A” and “R” are incorrect.
Correct Answer: “A” is incorrect but “R” is correct.

The correct answer is (A) "A" is incorrect, but "R" is correct.

 

Assertion (A) states that purchase decisions are not based on how customers perceive prices but, on the marketer’s, stated price. This assertion is incorrect. Purchase decisions are indeed influenced by how customers perceive prices. Customer perception of the value and fairness of the price is a significant factor in their purchasing decisions.

 

Reason (R) states that customers may have a lower price threshold, below which prices signal inferior or unacceptable quality, and an upper price threshold where the product appears not worth the money. This reason is correct. Customers often have a price range within which they perceive a product to offer good value for the money, and going below or above this range can affect their perception of the product's quality and worth.

Question 22
Given below are two statements – one is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)Assertion A:Auto companies and other consumer goods companies offer cash rebates to encourage purchase of the manufacturer’s products within a specified periodReasons R:The same product is priced differently at different times.In the context of the two statements above related to pricing strategy, which one of the following options is correct?
  • A.Both A and R are correct
  • B.Both A and R are not correct
  • C.A is correct, but R is not correct
  • D.A is not correct, but R is correct
Correct Answer: A is correct, but R is not correct

The correct answer is (C) A is correct, but R is not correct.

 

Assertion (A): Auto companies and other consumer goods companies offer cash rebates to encourage the purchase of the manufacturer’s products within a specified period.

This assertion is correct. Many companies, including auto manufacturers and consumer goods companies, often provide cash rebates or discounts as part of promotional strategies to entice customers to buy their products within a specific timeframe. These incentives are meant to stimulate sales and create a sense of urgency among consumers to make a purchase.

 

Reason (R): The same product is priced differently at different times.

This reason is not directly related to the assertion. The assertion is about offering cash rebates and promotions to encourage purchases within a specified period, not about price variations of the same product at different times. While it is true that product prices may vary based on different factors, it is not the core idea being discussed in the assertion.

Question 23
In which of the following price adjustment strategies, a company reduces prices to reward customer responses such as volume purchases, paying early or promoting the product? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Discount and allowances pricing
  • B.Psychological pricing
  • C.Promotional pricing
  • D.Dynamic pricing
Correct Answer: Discount and allowances pricing

The correct answer is (A) Discount and allowances pricing.

 

Discount and allowances pricing is a strategy where a company reduces prices to incentivize specific customer responses. This can include volume purchases, early payments, or promotional activities. Discounts and allowances are often used to encourage customers to buy more, make prompt payments, or promote the product, thereby stimulating sales and building customer loyalty.

Question 24
Pricing strategy of setting a high price when a product is introduced and gradually lowering its price is known as (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Skimming
  • B.Penetration Pricing
  • C.Peak load pricing
  • D.Dumping
Correct Answer: Skimming

The correct answer is (A) Skimming.

 

Skimming is a pricing strategy where a high price is set for a new product when it is introduced into the market. The initial high price is usually set to target early adopters, enthusiasts, or customers who are willing to pay a premium for the new product. Over time, the price is gradually lowered to attract a broader customer base. This strategy is often used to maximize profits from the early adopters before lowering the price to capture a larger market segment, typically in response to competition or as the product moves through its lifecycle.

Question 25
In penetration pricing a business firm seeks to access deeper market penetration by keeping prices ________________. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Higher
  • B.Competitive
  • C.Low
  • D.Flexible
Correct Answer: Low

The correct answer is (C) Low.

 

In penetration pricing, a business firm seeks to achieve deeper market penetration by keeping prices low. This strategy involves setting the initial prices of products or services at a relatively low level to attract a large number of customers and gain a significant market share quickly. The aim is to enter the market aggressively and capture a substantial customer base, potentially making it more difficult for competitors to enter and establish their foothold. Penetration pricing encourages price-sensitive consumers to try the product and hopefully become loyal customers, contributing to the long-term success of the business.

Question 26
The consumer’s price sensitivity is/are influenced by (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. Who bears the costII. What percentage of total expenditure does the product representIII. Who bears the cost and type of retailer from where customer purchasesIV. Consumption of product by the consumerV. Knowledge about the productChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.I, II, V only
  • B.II, IV only
  • C.I, II, IV only
  • D.I, II, IV, V only
Correct Answer: I, II, IV, V only

The correct answer is (D) I, II, IV, V only.

 

Consumer's price sensitivity is influenced by various factors, and in this case, the correct statements are:

 

I. Who bears the cost: This refers to whether the cost of the product is borne by the consumer, the company, or other parties. The cost-sharing arrangement can affect price sensitivity.

 

II. What percentage of total expenditure does the product represent: Consumers often consider the proportion of their total expenditure that a product represents. If a product represents a significant portion of their budget, they are likely to be more price-sensitive.

 

IV. Consumption of the product by the consumer: The usage or consumption pattern of the product by the consumer can influence their price sensitivity. If the product is essential or used frequently, the consumer may be more price-sensitive.

 

V. Knowledge about the product: Consumers with more knowledge about a product, its features, benefits, and alternatives are likely to make more informed decisions regarding its price and may be less price-sensitive.

 

These factors collectively influence a consumer's price sensitivity and their perception of value concerning the product's price.

Question 27
Penetration pricing strategy delivers results: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)1. where price quality association is weak2. when the product is perceived as a ‘high technology’ product3. when the market is characterized by intensive competition4. when the firm uses it as an entry strategyChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.2, 3 only
  • B.1, 4 only
  • C.1, 3, 4 only
  • D.1, 2, 3 only
Correct Answer: 1, 3, 4 only

The most appropriate answer is (C) 1, 3, 4 only.

 

Price-quality association is weak: Penetration pricing is effective when consumers do not strongly associate price with product quality. It's about gaining market share through competitive pricing without compromising the perceived quality.

 

Market characterized by intensive competition: Penetration pricing can be highly effective in a competitive market. Setting a lower initial price can attract customers and establish a foothold in the market.

 

Firm uses it as an entry strategy: Penetration pricing is often used as a strategy to enter a market aggressively by offering lower prices. It helps in quickly gaining market share and attracting customers.

Question 28
Match the following. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)List I (Pricing Strategies)(a) Ramsay pricing(b) Price skimming(c) Cost plus pricing(d) Penetration pricingList II (Description)(i) Setting a high price when a product is first introduced and gradually lowering price as it gains scale(ii) Firm charges lower price (than the ongoing price) to gain market entry(iii) Price deviations from marginal cost should be inversely proportional to price elasticity of the product(iv) It is full cost pricing strategy that also includes mark up for target return, degree of competition, price elasticity and availability of substitutes.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)
  • D.(a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)

(a) Ramsay pricing → (iii) Price deviations from marginal cost should be inversely proportional to price elasticity of the product. ✅

(b) Price skimming → (i) Setting a high price when a product is first introduced and gradually lowering price as it gains scale. ✅

(c) Cost plus pricing → (iv) It is full cost pricing strategy that also includes mark up for target return, degree of competition, price elasticity and availability of substitutes. ✅

(d) Penetration pricing → (ii) Firm charges lower price (than the ongoing price) to gain market entry. ✅

The correct match is (a) – (iii), (b) – (i), (c) – (iv), (d) – (ii)

Question 29
Skimming pricing strategy delivers results: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)(1) When the size of the market is large and it is a growing market(2) When the product is perceived as enhancing the customer's status in society(3) When the firm uses it as an entry strategy(4) When the target market associates quality of the products with its priceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1 and 2 only
  • B.2 and 4 only
  • C.2 and 3 only
  • D.1, 3 and 4 only
Correct Answer: 2 and 4 only

The correct answer is (B) 2 and 4 only.

 

Skimming pricing strategy is effective in the following scenarios:

 

(2) When the product is perceived as enhancing the customer's status in society: Skimming is often used for products that are seen as prestigious or associated with luxury. Higher prices can create a perception of exclusivity and status, appealing to a specific target market.

 

(4) When the target market associates quality of the products with its price: Some consumers associate higher prices with better quality. Skimming leverages this perception to set higher initial prices, attracting customers who believe that a higher-priced product is of superior quality.

Question 30
Which of the following inputs are considered while deciding economic value-to-customer pricing? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)a. Buyer's image of the product performanceb. Warranty qualityc. Desired rate of returnd. Customer demande. Customer supportChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b, e only
  • B.a, c, d only
  • C.b, d, e only
  • D.a, b, c, d only
Correct Answer: a, b, e only

The correct answer is (A) a, b, e only.

 

When deciding economic value-to-customer pricing, factors such as the buyer's image of the product performance (a), warranty quality (b), and customer support (e) are considered. The desired rate of return (c) and customer demand (d) are not typically directly related to economic value-to-customer pricing.

Question 31
Arrange the following pricing strategies and other practices as per the life-cycle of a new product of which no closesubstituesare available. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)a. Gradual rise in price.b. Product improvement and market segmentation.c. Gradual reduction in price to retain sales.d. Skimming pricing.e. Large price cuts.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.d, a, b, e, c
  • B.e, c, a, b, d
  • C.b, d, c, a, e
  • D.d, a, b, c, e
Correct Answer: d, a, b, c, e

The correct sequence of pricing strategies and other practices for a new product with no close substitutes, as it goes through its life cycle, is as follows (D) d, a, b, c, e.

 

Skimming pricing (d) is often used initially to capture the maximum value from early adopters.

Gradual rise in price (a) can follow as the product establishes itself and gains market share.

Product improvement and market segmentation (b) help to maintain or increase market share.

Gradual reduction in price to retain sales (c) may occur as competition increases.

Large price cuts (e) can be used if necessary to respond to competitive pressures.

Question 32
A company should undergo a step-wise process before selecting a final price. Accordingly, arrange the following steps of pricing-policy process to help ‘XYZ’ company to decide the final price of its product. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)(a) Selecting the pricing method.(b) Examining competitor's costs, prices and offers.(c) Estimating the demand curve and the probable quantities company will sell at each possible price.(d) Selecting the pricing objective of the company.(e) Estimating costs for different levels of output, for different levels of accumulated production experience, and for differentiated marketing offers.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.d, b, e, c, a
  • B.d, c, e, b, a
  • C.a, b, c, e, d
  • D.a, d, e, c, b
Correct Answer: d, c, e, b, a

The correct step-wise process for pricing-policy, as indicated in the question, is as follows:

(d) Selecting the pricing objective of the company.

(c) Estimating the demand curve and the probable quantities the company will sell at each possible price.

(e) Estimating costs for different levels of output, for different levels of accumulated production experience, and for differentiated marketing offers.

(b) Examining competitor's costs, prices, and offers.

(a) Selecting the pricing method.

 

So, the correct order is (B) d, c, e, b, a.

Question 33
Match the items of the List- I with those of the List- II and indicate the correct code: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)List- I(a) Trade Channel Discount(b) Loss Leadership(c) Pricing being non-responsive to changes in the demand and the cost.(d) Basing Point PricingList- II(i) Oligopoly Pricing(ii) Locational Price Differentials(iii) Differential Pricing(iv) Product - Line PricingCodes:
  • A.a- iv, b- iii, c- ii, d- i
  • B.a- iii, b- iv, c-i, d- ii
  • C.a- ii, b- iii, c- iv, d-i
  • D.a-i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv
Correct Answer: a- iii, b- iv, c-i, d- ii

The correct matching of items from List-I with items from List-II is as follows:

 

(a) Trade Channel Discount - iii. Differential Pricing

Trade Channel Discount refers to offering different prices or discounts to different distribution channels or trade partners. This is an example of differential pricing, where different customers or channels are charged different prices for the same or similar products.

 

(b) Loss Leadership - iv. Product-Line Pricing

Loss Leadership is a pricing strategy where a company deliberately sells a product at a loss to attract customers and potentially make up for the loss through the sale of complementary or related products. This is often associated with product-line pricing, where various products within a product line are priced differently based on factors like features, quality, or customer segments.

 

(c) Pricing being non-responsive to changes in the demand and the cost - i. Oligopoly Pricing

In an oligopoly market structure, a small number of firms dominate the industry, and pricing decisions may not be highly responsive to changes in demand and cost. Oligopolists often engage in price leadership or strategic pricing behavior.

 

(d) Basing Point Pricing - ii. Locational Price Differentials

Basing Point Pricing is a method where prices are set based on specific geographic locations, often the location of manufacturing or distribution centers. This can result in locational price differentials, where customers in different geographic areas pay different prices due to factors like transportation costs.

 

So, the correct code is (B) a- iii, b- iv, c- i, d- ii.

Question 34
When electronic markets permit prices to change faster even daily as a function of demand and supply then this practice is called: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.competitive pricing
  • B.e-marketing pricing
  • C.yield management pricing
  • D.none of the above
Correct Answer: yield management pricing

When electronic markets permit prices to change rapidly, often on a daily basis, as a function of demand and supply, this practice is called "yield management pricing."

 

Yield management pricing, also known as dynamic pricing, involves adjusting prices in real-time to optimize revenue based on fluctuations in demand and supply. It is commonly used in industries like airlines, hotels, and e-commerce where prices can change frequently to maximize profitability.

Question 35
Which one of the following is a false statement? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.Ramsey pricing rates to the methodology of pricing to situations where firms are regulated and the maximization of allocative efficiency is the objective of pricing together with the objective of profit-maximization.
  • B.Peak-load pricing is a pricing practice where price varies with time of the day.
  • C.Value-pricing is the practice of pricing where the price is set based on its value to the customer.
  • D.Two-part tariff refers to a price structure which has two parts- a lump sum charge and a variable charge.
Correct Answer: Ramsey pricing rates to the methodology of pricing to situations where firms are regulated and the maximization of allocative efficiency is the objective of pricing together with the objective of profit-maximization.

The false statement is:

 

(A) Ramsey pricing relates to the methodology of pricing to situations where firms are regulated and the maximization of allocative efficiency is the objective of pricing together with the objective of profit-maximization.

 

Ramsey pricing is typically associated with situations where firms are regulated, but its primary objective is to maximize economic efficiency and ensure that prices reflect the marginal cost of production. Profit-maximization is not the primary objective of Ramsey pricing; instead, it aims to achieve allocative efficiency, where prices are set to reflect the true cost of providing a service or product. Therefore, statement (A) is not accurate.

 

Statements (B), (C), and (D) are true and correctly describe different pricing practices: peak-load pricing, value-pricing, and two-part tariff, respectively.

Question 36
The pricing strategy which adjusts the basic price to accommodate differences in customers, products and locations is called: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.Differentiated pricing
  • B.Promotional pricing
  • C.Geographical pricing
  • D.Price discounts and allowances
Correct Answer: Differentiated pricing

The pricing strategy that adjusts the basic price to accommodate differences in customers, products, and locations is called "Differentiated pricing."

 

Differentiated pricing involves setting different prices for different customer segments, products, or geographic locations based on factors such as demand, competition, and customer preferences. This strategy allows a company to maximize its revenue by tailoring prices to specific market conditions and customer segments.

Question 37
Which one of the following is not matched properly? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2010)a. High initial price to be lowered later-i. Product line pricingb. Prices to be proportional to cost- ii. Differential pricingc. Prices to be increased for providing profit- iii. Pioneer pricingd. Prices to be different in different markets- iv. Incremental pricingCodes:
  • A.a and iii
  • B.b andi
  • C.c and iv
  • D.d and ii
Correct Answer: b andi

The match that is not proper in the given options is: (b) Prices to be proportional to cost - ii. Differential pricing

 

Differential pricing typically refers to pricing strategies where different customers or market segments are charged different prices for the same product or service. It may not necessarily mean that prices are proportional to cost.

Question 38
The strategy of introducing a product with high introductory price is called:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2009)
  • A.penetration strategy
  • B.skimming strategy
  • C.pull strategy
  • D.push strategy
Correct Answer: skimming strategy

The strategy of introducing a product with a high introductory price is called (B) Skimming strategy.

 

In a skimming strategy, a company sets a high initial price for a product, often targeting early adopters or customers who are willing to pay a premium for the new product. Over time, the price may be lowered to reach a broader market segment. This strategy is often used for products with unique features or innovations.

Question 39
Buyers are less price sensitive when they cannot easily compare the quality substitutes. Which of the following factors of price sensitivity is reflected from this statement? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.Substitute-awareness effect
  • B.Unique value effect
  • C.Price quality effect
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Substitute-awareness effect

The statement in question discusses the relationship between price sensitivity and the ease of comparing the quality of substitute products. It suggests that when buyers have difficulty comparing the quality of substitute products, they become less price-sensitive. In other words, they are more willing to accept or pay higher prices because they may not have a clear understanding of alternative options.

 

The correct factor of price sensitivity reflected in this statement is the "Substitute-awareness effect," which is represented by option (A). This effect highlights that when consumers are not fully aware of the availability of substitutes or find it challenging to assess the quality of alternative products, they are less likely to be sensitive to price changes. This is because they may perceive the product they are considering purchasing as the best option available to them, even if it is priced higher.

Question 40
Assertion “A”:Marketers can counter requests for a lower price in multiple ways.Reason “R”:Marketers may be able to show evidence that the life-cycle cost of using their product, is lower than for competitors’ products.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

The question revolves around the strategies that marketers can employ to address requests for lower prices.

 

Assertion (A) rightly states that marketers have various methods at their disposal to respond to such requests effectively.

 

Reason (R) provides an explanation for Assertion (A), emphasizing that one effective way to counter these requests is by demonstrating that the total cost of ownership, or the life-cycle cost, of using their product is lower compared to competing products. This is a valid strategy because it helps customers understand the long-term value and cost-effectiveness of the product.

 

Given that both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are correct and Reason (R) offers a logical explanation for Assertion (A), the correct answer is (A) - Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A, in accordance with the provided explanation.

Question 41
Statement I:Solution selling can also alleviate price pressure and comes in different forms.Statement II:Risk and gain sharing can offset price reductions that customers request.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Solution selling can also alleviate price pressure and comes in different forms. Here are three examples:

 

(i) Solutions to Enhance Customer Revenues - Hendrix UTD has used its sales consultants to help farmers deliver an incremental animal weight gain of 5 percent to 10 percent over competitors.

 

(ii) Solutions to Decrease Customer Risks - ICI Explosives formulated a safer way to ship explosives for quarries.

 

(iii) Solutions to Reduce Customer Costs - W.W. Grainger employees work at large customer facilities to reduce materials-management costs.

 

Risk and gain sharing can offset price reductions that customers request. Suppose Medline, a hospital supplier, signs an agreement with Highland Park Hospital promising INR 3,00,000 in savings over the first 18 months in exchange for getting a tenfold increase in the hospital’s share of supplies. Now, if Medline achieves less than this promised savings, it will make up the difference. If Medline achieves substantially more than promised, it participates in the extra savings. To make such arrangements work, the supplier must be willing to help the customer build a historical database, reach an agreement for measuring benefits and costs, and devise a dispute resolution mechanism.

Question 42
Match the following.List – I(a) Psychologicalpricingy(b) Dynamic pricing(c) Discount and allowance pricing(d) Promotional pricingList – II(i) Adjusting prices continually to meet the characteristics and needs of individual customers and situations.(ii) Temporarily reducing prices to spur short-run sales(iii) Reducing prices to reward customer responses such as volume purchases, paying early, or promoting the product(iv) Consumers usually perceive higher-priced products as having higher qualityCodes:
  • A.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iii) d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(iii) d-(ii)
  • C.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(i) c-(iii) d-(ii)

The correct answer is (B) a-(iv) b-(i) c-(iii) d-(ii).

 

(a) Psychological pricing - (iv) Consumers usually perceive higher-priced products as having higher quality

Psychological pricing is a pricing strategy where prices are set to take advantage of the psychological impact on consumers. For example, setting a higher price can create the perception of higher quality, making consumers more likely to buy the product.

 

(b) Dynamic pricing - (i) Adjusting prices continually to meet the characteristics and needs of individual customers and situations

Dynamic pricing is a strategy where prices are adjusted based on real-time data, market demand, and individual customer behavior. It involves continually changing prices to optimize revenue and accommodate various customer segments and market conditions.

 

(c) Discount and allowance pricing - (iii) Reducing prices to reward customer responses such as volume purchases, paying early, or promoting the product

Discount and allowance pricing involves offering price reductions or incentives to encourage specific customer behaviors. For example, offering discounts for bulk purchases or early payment, or providing promotional pricing to stimulate sales.

 

(d) Promotional pricing - (ii) Temporarily reducing prices to spur short-run sales

Promotional pricing is a strategy where prices are temporarily reduced to stimulate short-term sales. This can include limited-time discounts, special offers, or promotions to attract customers and boost sales during specific periods.

Question 43
__________ starts with an ideal selling price based on customer value considerations and then targets costs that will ensure that the price is met.
  • A.Competition-based pricing
  • B.Cost-plus Pricing
  • C.Target Costing Pricing
  • D.Break-even Pricing
Correct Answer: Target Costing Pricing

Target Costing Pricing is a pricing strategy that takes a unique approach to pricing by starting with an ideal selling price based on customer value considerations and then working backward to determine the costs that will allow the company to meet that price. This approach is in contrast to traditional cost-plus pricing, where prices are set by adding a standard markup to the cost of producing the product.

 

There are three primary pricing strategies:

 

Customer Value-Based Pricing: This strategy sets prices based on how customers perceive the value of the product, rather than solely relying on the company's production costs. There are two types of value-based pricing:

  • Good-Value Pricing: Offering a product with the right balance of quality and service at a fair price.
  • Value-Added Pricing: Adding extra features or services to differentiate the product and justify higher prices.

 

Cost-Based Pricing: This approach determines prices by considering the costs associated with producing, distributing, and selling the product, along with a reasonable profit margin. Cost-based pricing includes methods like cost-plus pricing and break-even pricing.

  • Cost-Plus Pricing: Involves adding a standard markup to the cost of production.
  • Break-Even Pricing: Determines the price needed to cover all costs and achieve a target profit, often using break-even analysis.

 

Competition-Based Pricing: In this strategy, prices are set by analyzing competitors' strategies, prices, costs, and market offerings.

 

While all three strategies have their merits, target costing pricing stands out because it begins with the desired selling price, which is derived from customer value considerations. The company then works diligently to align its production and operational costs to meet that price point. This approach is particularly valuable when a company wants to offer a product at a specific price that aligns with customer expectations and market conditions.

Question 44
Pricing Strategy adopted to set prices of products that must be used with main product is called:
  • A.Optional Product Pricing
  • B.Product Line Pricing
  • C.Captive Product Pricing
  • D.Competitive Pricing
Correct Answer: Captive Product Pricing

The correct answer is (C) Captive Product Pricing.

 

Product Mix Pricing Strategies:

 

 

Most products are part of a broader product mix. Consequently, they must be priced accordingly. The Five product mix pricing strategies (or situations) are below: 

 

1. Product Line Pricing: Since firms usually develop product lines rather than single products, product line pricing plays a decisive role in product mix pricing strategies. For example, when you look at a car brand such as Audi, you will see a relation between the different series and their prices. The entry model, the Audi A1, does cost you less than the top-range car A8. 

 

2. Optional Product Pricing: Optional product pricing is the pricing of optional or accessory products along with a main product. In many cases, you can buy optional or accessory products along with the main product. For instance, when you order your new Audi car, you may choose to order a GPS system and an advanced Entertainment system. However, for the company, pricing these options is not easy. They must decide carefully which items to include in the base price and which to offer as options. 

 

3. Captive Product Pricing: We speak of captive product pricing when companies make product that must be used along with the main product. On the contrary, in optional product pricing, we should think of products that can be bought/sold with the main product. Examples for captive product pricing are razor blade cartridges and printer cartridges. Captive product pricing is an extremely powerful strategy in the set of product mix pricing strategies. Producers of the main products, e.g. printers and razors, often price them very low and set high mark-ups on the supplies you need in order to operate the main products. 

 

4. By-Product Pricing: By product pricing refers to setting a price for by-products to make the main product’s price more competitive. It is the result of the fact that producing products and services often generates by-products. Often, these by-products (as singly sold products) would not have any value and getting rid of them is costly. This would then increase the price of the main product. But by using by-product pricing, the company tries to find a market for these by-products to help offset the costs of disposing of them and make the price of the main product more competitive. 

 

5. Product Bundle Pricing: Using product bundle pricing, companies combine several products and offer the bundle at a reduced price. The best example is probably a menu at McDonald’s: you get a bundle consisting of a burger, fries and a soft drink at a reduced price. For the company, product bundle pricing is a very effective product mix pricing strategy: it can promote the sales of products consumers might not otherwise buy.

Question 45
New Product Pricing Strategy through which companies set lower prices to gain large market share is classified as:
  • A.Optional Product Pricing
  • B.Skimming Pricing
  • C.Penetration Pricing
  • D.Captive Product Pricing
Correct Answer: Penetration Pricing

The correct answer is (C) Penetration Pricing.

 

Penetration pricing is a new product pricing strategy in which companies set lower initial prices for their products with the goal of gaining a large market share quickly. This strategy is often used to attract a significant customer base and build brand recognition by offering products at competitive or discounted prices. Over time, companies may adjust their pricing as they secure a stronger market position.

Question 46
Match the followingList-I (Cost-based Pricing)(a) Markup pricing(b) Absorption pricing(c) Rate of return pricing(d) Marginal cost pricingList-II (Example)1. Adding a margin to the cost price2. Normal level of production3. Investment criteria4. Variable cost and proportion of fixed costCodes
  • A.a-1, b-4, c-3, d-2
  • B.a-4, b-2, c-3, d-1
  • C.a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1
  • D.a-3, b-2, c-1, d-4
Correct Answer: a-1, b-4, c-3, d-2

Many firms consider the Cost of Production as a base for calculating the price of the finished goods. Cost-oriented pricing method covers the following ways of pricing:

 

1. Cost-Plus Pricing: It is one of the simplest pricing method wherein the manufacturer calculates the cost of production incurred and add a certain percentage of markup to it to realize the selling price. The markup is the percentage of profit calculated on total cost i.e. fixed and variable cost.

 

2. Markup pricing: This pricing method is the variation of cost plus pricing wherein the percentage of markup is calculated on the selling price.

 

3. Target-Return pricing: In this kind of pricing method, the firm sets the price to yield a required Rate of Return on Investment (ROI) from the sale of goods and services.

 

4. Absorption Pricing: Absorption pricing is a method for setting prices, under which the price of a product includes all of the variable costs attributable to it, as well as a proportion of all fixed costs. The term includes the word "absorbed," because all costs are absorbed into the determination of the final price.

 

5. Marginal cost pricing: is the practice of setting the price of a product at or slightly above the variable cost to produce it. This approach typically relates to short-term price setting situations.

Question 47
Indicate the correct code for appropriate combination of the following that constitutes the form of PriceAdjustmentStrategy:(i) Postage stamp pricing(ii) Basing point pricing(iii) Incremental pricing(iv) Free on Board pricingChoose the correct answer from the code given below:Codes
  • A.Only (iii) and (iv)
  • B.Only (i), (ii) and (iii)
  • C.Only (i), (ii) and (iv)
  • D.Only (ii), (iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: Only (i), (ii) and (iv)

There are 7 Price Adjustment strategies: discount and allowance pricing, segmented pricing, psychological pricing, promotional pricing, geographical pricing, dynamic pricing, and international pricing.

 

Geographical pricing is further divided:

1. FOB origin pricing: A geographical pricing strategy in which goods are placed free on board a carrier; the customer pays the freight from the factory to the destination.

2. Uniform delivered pricing: A geographical pricing strategy in which the company charges the same price plus freight to all customers, regardless of their location.

3. Zone pricing: A geographical pricing strategy in which the company sets up two or more zones. All customers within a zone pay the same total price; the more distant the zone, the higher the price.

4. Basing point pricing: A geographical pricing strategy in which the seller designates some city as a basing point and charges all customers the freight cost from that city to the customer.

 

Incremental Cost Pricing- Method of pricing a good or service in which the price of a unit produced (after all fixed costs of production have been met) is based on variable costs (and not on the total cost) incurred in its production.

Question 48
Pricing strategy in which company divides location into different sectors and charge same price for each sector is classified as
  • A.FOB-origin pricing
  • B.Base-point pricing
  • C.Zone pricing
  • D.Uniform-delivered pricing
Correct Answer: Zone pricing

The correct answer is (C) Zone pricing.

 

Zone pricing is a pricing strategy in which a company divides a geographical location or market into different zones or sectors and charges the same price for all customers within each specific zone. This strategy simplifies pricing by creating consistent pricing tiers based on geographic proximity rather than individual shipping costs. It is commonly used in industries where shipping and distribution costs vary by location.

Question 49
Setting price based on following competitors’ prices rather than on company costs or demand is called:
  • A.Going rate pricing
  • B.Perceived value pricing
  • C.Sealed-bid pricing
  • D.Cost based pricing
Correct Answer: Going rate pricing

The correct answer is (A) Going rate pricing.

 

Going rate pricing is a pricing strategy in which a company sets its prices based on the prices charged by competitors in the market. Instead of primarily considering its own costs or demand, the company aligns its pricing with the prevailing market rates. This approach is often used in competitive markets where pricing is influenced by the prices set by key industry competitors.

Question 50
The term EDLP in Retail Pricing stands for:
  • A.Extra Determined Low Pricing
  • B.Each Day Low Penetration
  • C.Every Day Low Pricing
  • D.Each Distributor Low Pricing
Correct Answer: Every Day Low Pricing

The correct answer is (C) Every Day Low Pricing.

 

EDLP stands for "Every Day Low Pricing." It is a retail pricing strategy where the retailer offers consistently low prices on its products every day, rather than relying on frequent sales, discounts, or promotions. The goal of EDLP is to attract customers with the promise of consistently low prices without the need to wait for special sales events.

Question 51
The Price strategy in which prices are low at the beginning stage is called:
  • A.Economy pricing
  • B.Price penetration
  • C.Price skimming
  • D.Premium pricing
Correct Answer: Price penetration

The correct answer is (B) Price penetration.

 

Price penetration is a pricing strategy in which a company initially sets low prices for its products when entering a new market or introducing a new product. The objective is to quickly gain market share and attract a large customer base by offering products at competitive or lower-than-average prices. Over time, the company may raise prices as it establishes its presence and captures a significant portion of the market.

Question 52
What is/are the way(s) in which a company responds to a competitor’s price cut in the market?
  • A.Raise perceived quality
  • B.Launch low-price band
  • C.Improve quality and increase price
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The correct answer is (D) All of the above.

 

When a company responds to a competitor's price cut in the market, it can employ various strategies, and these strategies can include:

 

(A) Raising perceived quality: The company can emphasize the quality and value of its products to justify higher prices compared to the competitor's lower-priced offerings.

 

(B) Launching a low-price brand: The company may introduce a new, lower-priced product or brand to directly compete with the competitor's lower-priced offerings while maintaining its existing higher-priced products.

 

(C) Improving quality and increasing price: Instead of engaging in a price war, the company may focus on enhancing the quality of its products and, as a result, raise prices to reflect the improved value.

Question 53
Which of the following is NOT a Market-oriented pricing technique?
  • A.Auction Pricing
  • B.Going Rate pricing
  • C.Perceived Value pricing
  • D.Early-cash recovery pricing
Correct Answer: Early-cash recovery pricing

The correct answer is (D) Early-cash recovery pricing.

 

Perceived Value Pricing: In this pricing method, the manufacturer decides the price on the basis of customer’s perception of the goods and services taking into consideration all the elements such as advertising, promotional tools, additional benefits, product quality, the channel of distribution, etc. that influence the customer’s perception.

 

Value Pricing: Under this pricing method, companies design the low priced products and maintain the high-quality offering. Here the prices are not kept low, but the product is re-engineered to reduce the cost of production and maintain the quality simultaneously.

 

Going-Rate Pricing: In this pricing method, the firms consider the competitor’s price as a base in determining the price of its own offerings. Generally, the prices are more or less same as that of the competitor and the price war gets over among the firms. This can be done in three ways:

  • Competitors ‘parity method: A firm may set the same price as that of the major competitor.
  • Premium pricing: A firm may charge a little higher if its products have some additional special features as compared to major competitors.
  • Discount pricing: A firm may charge a little lower price if its products lack certain features as compared to major competitors.

 

Auction Type Pricing: This type of pricing method is growing popular with the more usage of internet. Several online sites such as eBay, Quikr, OLX, etc. provides a platform to customers where they buy or sell the commodities. There are three types of auctions:

  • English Auctions: There is one seller and many buyers. The seller puts the item on sites such as Yahoo and bidders raise the price until the top best price is reached.
  • Dutch Auctions: There may be one seller and many buyers or one buyer and many sellers. In the first case, the top best price is announced and then slowly it comes down that suit the bidder whereas in the second kind buyer announces the product he wants to buy then potential sellers competes by offering the lowest price.
  • Sealed-Bid Auctions: This kind of method is very common in the case of Government or industrial purchases, wherein tenders are floated in the market, and potential suppliers submit their bids in a closed envelope, not disclosing the bid to anyone.

 

Differential Pricing: This pricing method is adopted when different prices charged for the same product or service. There are four types of differential pricing:

  • Customer segment pricing: Here different customer groups are charged different prices for the same product or service depending on the size of the order, payment terms, and so on.
  • Time pricing: Here different prices are charged for the same product or service at different timings or season. It includes off-peak pricing, where low prices are charged during low-demand tunings or season.
  • Area pricing: Here different prices are charged for the same product in different market areas. For instance, a firm may charge a lower price in a new market to attract customers.
  • Product form pricing: Here different versions of the product are priced differently but not proportionately to their respective costs. For instance, soft drinks of 200,300, 500 ml, etc., are priced according to this strategy.

 

Early cash recovery pricing is one of the cost-oriented pricing methods. Hence, early cash recovery is the answer.

Question 54
New product pricing strategy through which companies set lower prices to gain large market share is classified as:
  • A.Optional Product Pricing
  • B.Skimming Pricing
  • C.Penetration Pricing
  • D.Captive Product Pricing
Correct Answer: Penetration Pricing

The correct answer is (C) Penetration Pricing.

 

Penetration pricing is a new product pricing strategy in which companies set lower initial prices for their products with the goal of gaining a large market share quickly. This strategy is often used to attract a significant customer base and build brand recognition by offering products at competitive or discounted prices. Over time, companies may adjust their pricing as they secure a stronger market position.

Question 55
Assertion “A”:Odd Pricing aims at maximizing profit by making micro-adjustments in pricing structure. (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)Reasoning “R”:Odd Pricing refers to a price ending in 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. When examining a price, the first digits carry more weight than the last ones.Codes:
  • A.A is correct and R is incorrect.
  • B.A is incorrect and R is correct.
  • C.Both A and R are correct.
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct.

The correct answer is (C) Both A and R are correct.

 

Assertion (A): "Odd Pricing aims at maximizing profit by making micro-adjustments in pricing structure."

This assertion is correct. Odd pricing is a pricing strategy where prices are set just below a round number, often ending in digits like 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. The idea behind odd pricing is to create a perception of a lower price in the minds of consumers. For example, setting a product's price at $9.99 instead of $10.00. This small adjustment can make a significant difference in how consumers perceive the price and can lead to increased sales. It is indeed a strategy aimed at maximizing profit through subtle pricing adjustments.

 

Reasoning (R): "Odd Pricing refers to a price ending in 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. When examining a price, the first digits carry more weight than the last ones."

This reasoning is also correct. In the field of price perception psychology, researchers have found that consumers tend to focus more on the first digits of a price when evaluating its magnitude. This phenomenon is known as the "left-digit effect." For example, consumers are more likely to perceive a price difference between $9.99 and $10.00 as more significant than the one-cent difference it actually represents. This understanding of how consumers perceive prices underscores the effectiveness of odd pricing in influencing consumer behavior.

Question 56
In India, which pricing practice is not permissible?
  • A.Penetrating pricing
  • B.Skimming pricing
  • C.Predatory pricing
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Predatory pricing

In India, predatory pricing is not permissible.

 

Predatory pricing refers to the practice of setting very low prices for goods or services with the intention of driving competitors out of the market or preventing new competitors from entering. It is considered anti-competitive behavior and can harm consumers in the long run by reducing competition. Predatory pricing practices are typically regulated to ensure fair competition.
