Therefore, option (C) Predatory pricing is not permissible in India, as it is generally prohibited to protect fair competition. Options (A) Penetrating pricing and (B) Skimming pricing are pricing strategies commonly used in the market, and they are permissible in India when they do not violate competition laws.

Question 57
Pricing decisions are most complex at which stage of the Product Life Cycle (PLC)? (UGC NET Management Jun 2014)
  • A.Decline stage
  • B.Introductory stage
  • C.Growth stage
  • D.Maturity stage
Correct Answer: Maturity stage

Pricing decisions are most complex at maturity stage of the product life cycle as product has reached to boom, has generated a good revenue for the firm and is on the verge of declining now. The same pricing is not beneficial as buyer’s may tend to consider competitor’s product in this stage. The most favorable step to revive the product in this stage would be lowering down the price along with modifications required to survive in the market.

Question 58
The price-setting method which most closely corresponds to the concept of product positioning is: (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Cost-plus pricing
  • B.Going-rate pricing
  • C.Perceived value pricing
  • D.Psychological pricing
Correct Answer: Perceived value pricing

Perceived Value Pricing: In this pricing method, the manufacturer decides the price on the basis of customer’s perception of the goods and services taking into consideration all the elements such as advertising, promotional tools, additional benefits, product quality, the channel of distribution, etc. that influence the customer’s perception. Product positioning also involves creating a unique image in customer’s mind or in other word, managing how the customer perceives company’s products or services. Therefore, we can say that perceived value pricing most closely corresponds to the concept of product positioning.

Question 59
The Pricing method adopted when different prices have to be charged from the different group of customers is called as:
  • A.Differential pricing
  • B.Promotional pricing
  • C.Geographical pricing
  • D.Price discounts and allowances
Correct Answer: Differential pricing

Differential pricing, also known as price discrimination, is a pricing strategy used when a company charges different prices for the same product or service to different groups of customers or in different market segments. This strategy recognizes that not all customers are willing to pay the same price, and it aims to maximize revenue by tailoring prices to specific customer segments. There are several forms of differential pricing:

  • Customer Segment Pricing: In this approach, different customer groups are charged different prices based on various factors such as their purchasing behavior, demographics, location, or willingness to pay. For example, airlines often offer different ticket prices for economy class, business class, and first-class passengers.
  • Time Pricing: Differential pricing based on time involves charging different prices for the same product or service during different times or seasons. For instance, hotels may offer lower rates during off-peak seasons to attract more customers.
  • Geographical Pricing: Geographical pricing involves setting different prices for the same product in different geographic areas or markets. This can be influenced by factors like shipping costs, local demand, or competition.
  • Product Form Pricing: This form of pricing entails charging different prices for various versions or sizes of the same product, even though the cost differences may not be proportional. For example, soft drink companies may price differently for 200ml, 300ml, and 500ml bottles of the same beverage.
Question 60
A reduction from the list price that is offered by a seller to buyers in payment for marketing functions the buyers will perform is known as: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.Trade Discount
  • B.Functional Discount
  • C.Cash Discount
  • D.Both Trade and Functional Discount
Correct Answer: Both Trade and Functional Discount

The correct answer is (D) Both Trade and Functional Discount.

 

Both Trade Discount and Functional Discount involve reductions from the list price offered by a seller to buyers for various reasons:

 

Trade Discount: A trade discount is typically offered by a seller to a buyer as a reduction from the list price. This discount is often provided to intermediaries or resellers in the distribution channel, such as wholesalers or retailers. It serves as a reward or incentive for their role in marketing and distributing the seller's products. Trade discounts are common in B2B (business-to-business) transactions.

 

Functional Discount: A functional discount is also a reduction from the list price and is offered to buyers based on the functions they will perform in the distribution process. These functions may include warehousing, transportation, promotional activities, or other marketing functions. Functional discounts are often provided to encourage buyers to take on these distribution responsibilities.

Question 61
The practice of selling below cost, with an intention to destroying the competitor is referred to as: (UGC NET ManagementJun 2015)
  • A.Loss-leader pricing
  • B.Predatory pricing
  • C.Price discrimination
  • D.Penetration pricing
Correct Answer: Predatory pricing

The correct answer is (B) Predatory pricing.

 

Predatory pricing is the practice of selling a product or service at a price below its cost with the intention of harming or driving competitors out of the market. It is considered an anti-competitive strategy aimed at eliminating competition rather than maximizing profit. Predatory pricing can lead to monopolistic or dominant market positions and is often regulated to maintain fair competition.

 

Loss-leader pricing- In this the product priced lower to attract customers to the store in hopes that they will buy other items at normal markup.

 

Price discrimination- the practice of unfairly pricing the same quality, grade, and quantity of goods differently for different customers. Price discrimination that is aimed at reducing competition is forbidden. Marketers can charge different prices when prices are justified by cost differentials; represent a good-faith effort to match competitors' prices rather than to reduce competition; and reflect changing market conditions


Penetration Pricing- Penetration pricing sets an initial low price in order to penetrate the market quickly and deeply—to attract a large number of buyers quickly and win a large market share.

Question 62
Match the items/persons included in List – I with the items in List – II and indicate the correct pairing through codes given below:List – Ia) CCIb) Cognitive dissonancec) Everett M. Rogersd) Theodore LevittList – IIi) Consumer buying decision processii) ‘Marketing Myopia’iii) Diffusion of Innovationiv) Predatory pricingCodes:
  • A.a-iv b-iii c-ii d-i
  • B.a-iii b-iv c-ii d-i
  • C.a-ib-ii c-iv d-iii
  • D.a-iv b-i c-iii d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iv b-i c-iii d-ii

Competition Commission of India (CCI) is a statutory body of the Government of India responsible for enforcing The Competition Act, 2002 throughout India and to prevent activities that have an appreciable adverse effect on competition in India. According to CCI, Predatory Pricing is illegal.

Diffusion of innovations is a theory that seeks to explain how, why, and at what rate new ideas and technology spread. This theory was given by a communications professor, Everett M. Rogers.

 

Marketing myopia: The term was first used by Theodore Levitt, an economist and editor of Harvard Business Review, who is also famous for the term `globalization'. Management gurus define marketing myopia as a company's short-sighted, temporary or narrow-minded approach while marketing their product. Companies need to adapt themselves to the changing market. When a firm changes its marketing focus from customer to its product or the company itself, it is also called marketing myopia.

 

Cognitive dissonance: the state of having inconsistent thoughts, beliefs, or attitudes, especially as relating to behavioral decisions and attitude change. It is post-purchase behavior (last step of consumer buying decision process).

Question 63
A Market Penetration Pricing Strategy is suitable when: (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.lower price encourages actual competition.
  • B.the demand of the product is inelastic.
  • C.the production and distribution costs fall with increasing production.
  • D.a high price discourages competitors from entering the market.
Correct Answer: the production and distribution costs fall with increasing production.

The correct answer is (C) the production and distribution costs fall with increasing production.

 

A Market Penetration Pricing Strategy is suitable when production and distribution costs decrease as production volume increases. This strategy involves setting lower initial prices for a product to enter a market and gain market share. It is often used when a company can take advantage of economies of scale, meaning that per-unit production costs decrease as production levels rise.

Question 64
Which one of the following is NOT a factor that reduces price sensitivity of a product?
  • A.The product is more distinctive.
  • B.Buyers are fully aware of substitutes.
  • C.Buyers cannot store the product.
  • D.The product is assumed to have more quality, prestige, or exclusiveness.
Correct Answer: Buyers are fully aware of substitutes.

The correct answer is (B) Buyers are fully aware of substitutes.

 

Buyers being fully aware of substitutes actually increases price sensitivity of a product. When buyers are aware of alternative products or substitutes, they have more options to consider, and this can make them more price-sensitive because they can easily switch to a substitute if the price of the current product is too high.

Question 65
Consider the following Statements:(1) Exclusive dealing amounts to a restrictive agreement under the Competition Act, 2002.(2) The rate of growth in the service sector in India is highest among all the other sectors of economy.(3) Predatory pricing is not regulated under any law.(4) A company using sales force promotion and trade promotion is using “Pull” strategy.Indicate the correct answer out of the following:
  • A.While statements (1) and (2) are true, (3) and (4) are not.
  • B.While statements (1) and (3) are true, rest are not.
  • C.While statement (2) is true, others are not.
  • D.All the statements are true.
Correct Answer: While statements (1) and (2) are true, (3) and (4) are not.

The correct answer is (A) While statements (1) and (2) are true, (3) and (4) are not.

 

(1) Exclusive dealing amounts to a restrictive agreement under the Competition Act, 2002.

This statement is true. Exclusive dealing arrangements can be considered anticompetitive and may be regulated under competition laws.

 

(2) The rate of growth in the service sector in India is highest among all the other sectors of the economy.

This statement is true. The service sector has been one of the fastest-growing sectors in the Indian economy.

 

(3) Predatory pricing is not regulated under any law.

This statement is not true. Predatory pricing is a strategy where a company sets very low prices with the intention of driving competitors out of the market. It can be subject to regulation under competition laws.

 

(4) A company using sales force promotion and trade promotion is using a "Pull" strategy.

This statement is not true. When a company uses sales force promotion and trade promotion, it is typically using a "Push" strategy to push its products through the distribution channel. A "Pull" strategy would involve creating consumer demand to pull the product through the distribution channel.

Question 66
A company prices a 2 L bottle of its mineral water at Rs 30 but 60 ml of the same water in a moisturizer spray for Rs 75. This is an example of which one of the following pricing practices?
  • A.Product-Form pricing
  • B.Customer-segment pricing
  • C.Image pricing
  • D.Location pricing
Correct Answer: Product-Form pricing

The correct answer is (A) Product-Form pricing.

 

This pricing practice involves pricing different versions or forms of the same product differently based on factors such as packaging, quantity, or format. In this case, the company is pricing a 2 L bottle of mineral water differently from a 60 ml moisturizer spray, even though the contents are the same (mineral water).

Question 67
Select the correct sequence of steps in Setting a Pricing Policy:(UGC NET Management Jan 2017)(a) Determining Demand(b)Analyzingcompetitors’ Costs, Prices and Offers(c) Selecting the Final Price(d) Selecting the Pricing Objective(e) Estimating costs(f) Selecting a pricing methodCodes
  • A.(d), (a), (e), (b), (f) and (c)
  • B.(a), (e), (b), (d), (f) and (c)
  • C.(a), (b), (e), (d), (f) and (c)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d), (e) and (f)
Correct Answer: (d), (a), (e), (b), (f) and (c)

The correct sequence of steps in setting a pricing policy is as follows:

 

(d) Selecting the Pricing Objective

(a) Determining Demand

(e) Estimating costs

(b) Analyzing competitors’ Costs, Prices, and Offers

(f) Selecting a pricing method

(c) Selecting the Final Price

 

So, the correct option is (A) (d), (a), (e), (b), (f), and (c).

Question 68
Temporarily reducing prices to increase short-run sales is an example of which one of the following. (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.Segmented pricing
  • B.Promotional pricing
  • C.Dynamic pricing
  • D.Geographical pricing
Correct Answer: Promotional pricing

The correct answer is (B) Promotional pricing.

 

List of Price Adjustment Strategies is:

Discount and allowance pricing reduces prices to reward customer responses such as paying early or promoting the product. Like Discounts, Allowances

 

Segmented pricing is used when a company sells a product at two or more prices even though the difference is not based on cost. It is done by Customer segment pricing, Product form segment pricing or Location pricing.

 

Psychological pricing occurs when sellers consider the psychology of prices and not simply the economics

 

Promotional pricing is when prices are temporarily priced below list price or cost to increase demand. "Loss leaders" are products sold below cost to attract customers in the hope they will buy other items at normal markups. Example, a grocery store owner temporarily lowering the price of eggs in the hope that customer will buy milk bread and other supplies with eggs at normal prices.

 

Geographical pricing is used for customers in different parts of the country or the world. "FOB (free on board) pricing" means that the goods are delivered to the carrier and the title and responsibility passes to the customer. "Uniformed delivery pricing" means the company charges the same price plus freight to all customers, regardless of location. "Zone pricing" means that the company sets up two or more zones where customers within a given zone pay a single total price. "Basing point pricing" means that a seller selects a given city as a “basing point” and charges all customers the freight cost associated from that city to the customer location regardless of the city from which the goods are actually shipped.

 

Dynamic pricing is when prices are adjusted continually to meet the characteristics and needs of the individual customer and situations.

 

International pricing is when prices are set in a specific country based on country-specific factors like Economic conditions, Competitive conditions, Laws and regulations, Infrastructure, Company marketing objective.

Question 69
Match the items of List - I with that of List - II and suggest the correct code:(UGC NET Management Nov2017)List - I (Pricing Strategies)(a) Customary pricing(b) Skimming(c) Penetration pricing(d) Psychological pricingList – II (Explanations)(i) Ending a price with 99 Paise.(ii) pricing a product based on perceived expectations of customers.(iii) Setting a high price which gradually reduces as competitors enter the market.(iv) Offering at a low price for a new product during its initial offering.Codes
  • A.a-(i) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(ii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(i)
  • D.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i)

The correct matching of List I with List II is as follows:

 

(a) Customary pricing - (ii) pricing a product based on perceived expectations of customers.

(b) Skimming - (iii) Setting a high price which gradually reduces as competitors enter the market.

(c) Penetration pricing - (iv) Offering at a low price for a new product during its initial offering.

(d) Psychological pricing - (i) Ending a price with 99 Paise.

 

1) Market-Skimming Pricing- Many companies that invent new products set high prices to “skim” revenues layer by layer from the market. 

 

2) Market Penetration Pricing- Market-penetration pricing sets an initial low price in order to penetrate the market quickly and deeply—to attract a large number of buyers quickly and win a large market share.

 

3) Psychology Pricing refers to techniques that marketers use to encourage customers to respond on emotional levels rather than logical ones.

For example, setting the price of a watch at $199 is proven to attract more consumers than setting it at $200, even though the true difference here is quite small.

 

4) Customary Pricing- A method of determining the price for a good or service based on the perceived expectations of customers. Customary pricing is generally used for products with a relatively long market history of being sold for a particular amount, and is driven by intuitive notions of value on the part of buyers.

 

5) Bundle Pricing- With bundle pricing, small businesses sell multiple products for a lower rate than consumers would face if they purchased each item individually. 

 

So, the correct code is (B) a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i).

Question 70
Consider the following statements and indicate the correct answer:(UGC NET Management Aug 2016)Statement I:Companies that adopt value pricing win loyal customers by charging reasonable price for a high-quality offering.Statement II:Value pricing is a matter of re-engineering the company’s operations to become a low-cost producer without sacrificing quality.Codes:
  • A.Only statement I is correct.
  • B.Only statement II is correct.
  • C.Both statements I and II are correct.
  • D.Both statements I and II are wrong.
Correct Answer: Both statements I and II are correct.

The correct answer is (C) Both statements I and II are correct.

 

Statement I: "Companies that adopt value pricing win loyal customers by charging a reasonable price for a high-quality offering."

This statement highlights the essence of value pricing. Value pricing is a pricing strategy in which companies aim to offer high-quality products or services to customers at a price that is considered reasonable or provides excellent value for the customer. By doing so, these companies seek to attract and retain loyal customers. In this strategy, the focus is not solely on charging the highest possible price but on delivering a superior product or service that justifies the price paid by the customer. Customers perceive the value in what they receive, which fosters loyalty to the brand or company.

 

Statement II: "Value pricing is a matter of re-engineering the company’s operations to become a low-cost producer without sacrificing quality."

This statement emphasizes an important aspect of value pricing. To offer high-quality products or services at a reasonable price, companies often need to optimize their internal operations. This involves streamlining processes, reducing unnecessary costs, and increasing operational efficiency to become a low-cost producer. However, it's crucial to note that achieving cost savings should not come at the expense of product quality. The goal is to provide value by delivering both quality and affordability.

Question 71
Match the following. (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)List - I(a) Customer-segment pricing(b) Product-form pricing(c) Location pricing(d) Time pricingList - II(i) Pricing products differently but not proportionately to their costs(ii) Pricing products differently even though the cost of offering at that arena is the same(iii) Pricing differently even though the products are same(iv) Pricing differently for the different seasonsCodes:
  • A.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • B.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(i) b-(iv) c-(iii) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iv)

The match provided in option (B) for the pricing strategies correctly pairs the pricing strategies in List - I with their respective explanations in List - II.

 

(a) Customer-segment pricing - (iii) Pricing differently even though the products are the same

Customer-segment pricing involves charging different prices to different customer segments for the same product or service. This means that even though the core product remains the same, different customer groups may perceive its value differently, allowing the company to charge varying prices to maximize its revenue from each segment.

 

(b) Product-form pricing - (i) Pricing products differently but not proportionately to their costs

Product-form pricing is a strategy where different versions or forms of a product are priced differently, but this pricing isn't necessarily directly proportional to the costs associated with each version. It takes into account factors like perceived value and customer willingness to pay for each form of the product.

 

(c) Location pricing - (ii) Pricing products differently even though the cost of offering at that arena is the same

Location pricing involves charging different prices for the same product or service in different geographical locations or areas. Even if the cost of offering the product remains the same across these locations, pricing may be adjusted to account for factors like local demand, competition, and consumer preferences.

 

(d) Time pricing - (iv) Pricing differently for different seasons

Time pricing is a strategy where prices for products or services vary depending on the time of purchase or season. It may involve offering discounts or premium pricing during specific seasons or time periods to align with consumer demand patterns and maximize revenue.

Question 72
When the Companies pay less attention to its own costs or demands and bases its price largely on competitors' prices, then it is known as: (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)
  • A.Value Pricing
  • B.Going rate pricing
  • C.Image pricing
  • D.Psychological pricing
Correct Answer: Going rate pricing

Option (B) "Going rate pricing" is the correct answer.

 

Going rate pricing is a pricing strategy in which a company pays less attention to its own costs or demand and, instead, bases its prices largely on competitors' prices. This approach is often used when the company believes that the market is competitive, and it wants to align its prices with prevailing market rates to remain competitive. It essentially follows the pricing practices set by competitors rather than setting prices based on its internal cost structure or other factors.

Question 73
The practice of selling two or more separate products together for a single price is: (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Bundling
  • B.Dumping
  • C.Both A. and B.
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Bundling

Option (A) "Bundling" is the correct answer.

 

Bundling is the practice of selling two or more separate products or services together as a package deal for a single price. This pricing strategy is often used to increase sales and offer customers added value. Customers may be more inclined to purchase a bundle of products or services at a discounted price compared to buying each item individually. It can also be a strategy to promote related or complementary products.

Question 74
A company using high price and high promotion policy is adopting the following strategy: (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Slow skimming
  • B.Rapid Penetration
  • C.Slow Penetration
  • D.Rapid Skimming
Correct Answer: Rapid Skimming

Option (D) "Rapid Skimming" is the correct answer.

 

Rapid Skimming is a pricing strategy where a company sets a high initial price for a new product and uses aggressive promotion to quickly "skim" revenue layers from the market. This strategy is typically used for innovative products or services that have unique features or benefits that justify the high price. It aims to maximize profit in the short term by targeting early adopters and customers willing to pay a premium price for the new offering.

Question 75
When the firm searches for a set of prices that maximizes profits on the total mix it is known as
  • A.Marketing Mix Pricing
  • B.Product Mix Pricing
  • C.Brand Line Pricing
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Product Mix Pricing

Option (B) "Product Mix Pricing" is the correct answer.

 

Product mix pricing refers to the pricing strategy where a firm considers a combination or portfolio of products it offers as a whole, rather than pricing each product individually. The goal is to find a set of prices for the products within the product mix that maximizes overall profitability or achieves specific objectives.

 

It involves determining the prices for different products within the product line or mix, taking into account factors such as cost, demand, competition, and customer value perceptions. This strategy helps companies optimize their pricing decisions for a range of products to achieve their financial and strategic goals.

 

Marketers must modify their price-setting logic when the product is part of a Product mix. We can distinguish 6 situations calling for Product mix pricing:

(i) Captive-product pricing: Some products require the use of ancillary or captive products. Manufacturers of razors and cameras often price them low and set high markups on razor blades and film. This form of pricing is known as Captive-product pricing.

 

(ii) Two-part pricing: Service firms engage in two-part pricing, consisting of a fixed fee plus a variable usage fee. For instance, cell phone users pay a minimum monthly fee plus charges for calls that exceed their allotted minutes.

 

(iii) By-product pricing: The production of certain goods such as meats, petroleum products, and other chemical, often results in by-products that should be priced on their value. Any income earned on the by-products will make it easier for the company to charge a lower price on its main product if competition forces it to do so.

 

(iv) Product-bundling pricing: Sellers often bundle products and features either as pure or mixed bundle. Pure bundling occurs when a firm offers its products only as a bundle. For example, a talent agency might insist that a lead actor can be signed to a film only if the film company also accepts other talents the agency represented such as directors or writers. This is a form of tied-in sales.  In mixed bundling, the seller offers goods both individually and in bundles, normally charging less for the bundle than if the items were purchased separately. For example, an auto manufacturer might offer an option package at less than the cost of buying all the options separately.

 

(v) Product line pricing: In this form of pricing, companies normally develop product lines rather than single products and introduce price steps. For instance, a men’s clothing store might carry men’s suits at three price levels: INR. 1000, INR. 1600, and INR. 2000, which customers associate with low, average, and high-quality. The seller’s task is to establish perceived quality differences that justify the price differences.  

 

(vi) Optional-feature pricing: In this form of pricing, companies offer optional products with their main product. For instance, a buyer of the 2010 Subaru Outback 2.5i can order four-way power passenger seats, an All-Weather package, and a power moon roof as optional features.

Question 76
Statement I:Optional-feature pricing is when companies develop product lines rather than single products and introduce price step.Statement II:Product-line pricing is when companies offer non-compulsory products with their main product.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect

Both statements are incorrect in their descriptions of optional-feature pricing and product-line pricing.

 

Statement I: Optional-feature pricing is when companies develop product lines rather than single products and introduce price step.

This statement is not accurate. Optional-feature pricing is a strategy where a company offers additional features or enhancements for a product at an additional cost. It doesn't necessarily involve developing product lines or introducing price steps. Instead, it allows customers to customize a product by choosing from a list of optional features or upgrades, each with its associated price.

 

Statement II: Product-line pricing is when companies offer non-compulsory products with their main product.

This statement is also not accurate. Product-line pricing refers to the strategy of setting different prices for a range of related products within a product line. These products may vary in terms of features, quality, or target market, but they are typically part of the same product line and serve different customer needs. Whether the products are compulsory or non-compulsory is not a defining characteristic of product-line pricing.

Question 77
Match the following.List I (Product Mix Pricing)(a) Captive-Product Pricing(b) Two-Part Pricing(c) By-Product PricingList II (Description)(i) Used by firms whose production results in by-products(ii) Used by a service firm and includes a fixed fee plus a variable fee(iii) Used when some products require the use of ancillary productsChoose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)

The correct answer is (A) a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i).

 

(a) Captive-Product Pricing: This strategy is used when a company has multiple products, and some of these products require the use of other ancillary or complementary products. In other words, customers are "captured" into buying the main product because they need the additional product. For example, razor blades are often priced lower because they are useless without the razor handle. So, the company might sell the razor handle at a higher price and the blades at a lower price, ensuring customers purchase both.

 

(b) Two-Part Pricing: This pricing strategy is commonly used by service firms. It involves charging customers a fixed fee (like a membership fee or subscription fee) and then adding a variable fee based on the level of service or usage. For instance, a gym might charge a monthly membership fee (fixed fee) and then an additional fee per personal training session (variable fee) for members who opt for personal training.

 

(c) By-Product Pricing: By-product pricing is used by companies whose production process generates by-products, which are secondary products that have some value but are not the main focus of production. Companies may choose to sell these by-products at a price to recover some costs or generate additional revenue. For example, a sugar mill may produce molasses as a by-product, which can be sold separately.

Question 78
The price setting method most closely corresponding of the concept of product positioning is (UGC NET Management Jun 2014)
  • A.Cost-plus pricing
  • B.Psychological pricing
  • C.Going-rate pricing
  • D.Perceived-value pricing
Correct Answer: Perceived-value pricing

Perceived-value pricing is the price setting method that closely corresponds to the concept of product positioning. This approach involves determining the price of a product or service based on the value that customers perceive it to have. Perceived value encompasses various factors, including the buyer's perception of product performance, the quality of warranty, customer support, and other intangible attributes such as the reputation and trustworthiness of the supplier.

 

When using perceived-value pricing, companies strive to deliver the value promised by their value proposition, ensuring that customers perceive this value. They utilize various marketing strategies such as advertising, sales force efforts, and online presence to communicate and enhance the perceived value in the minds of buyers.

 

By aligning price with perceived value, companies can effectively position their products in the market. Product positioning involves creating a unique and desirable image or perception of the product in the minds of consumers, differentiating it from competitors. It entails identifying a distinctive selling proposition and presenting the product in a way that resonates with the target market.

 

In contrast, the other options mentioned in the question do not directly correspond to the concept of product positioning.

 

Cost-plus pricing involves setting prices based on the cost of production with a predetermined profit margin added. This method does not directly consider the perceived value or positioning of the product.

 

Psychological pricing, on the other hand, utilizes pricing techniques based on the psychological impact they have on customers. This approach may include using price points just below a round number (e.g., $9.99 instead of $10) or employing pricing cues to create a perception of value. While psychological pricing can influence customer perceptions, it does not directly relate to product positioning.

 

Going-rate pricing is based on setting prices in line with prevailing market prices or the prices charged by competitors. This strategy is commonly used in industries with intense price competition, where companies follow market prices to avoid price wars. Going-rate pricing focuses more on market dynamics and competition rather than the unique value proposition and positioning of the product.

Question 79
Find the most appropriate sequence of life cycle of price for a product, from the initial stage to the mutual stage. (UGC NET Management Jun 2014)
  • A.Target price → penetration price →value- based price → limit price → niche price
  • B.Penetration price → limit price→ value- based price→ target price→ niche price
  • C.Penetration price→ target price→ limit price→ value- based price→ niche price
  • D.Penetration price→ niche price→ target price→ limit price→ value- based price
Correct Answer: Target price → penetration price →value- based price → limit price → niche price

The question pertains to the sequence of the price life cycle stages for a product, from its initial introduction to the mature stage. The correct answer is (A) "Target price → penetration price → value-based price → limit price → niche price."

 

Stages:

 

Target Price: This is the price level that a company aims to achieve based on its business goals and the value proposition of the product. It serves as a guiding point for the pricing strategy.

 

Penetration Price: In the early stages of a product's life cycle, a company might use a penetration pricing strategy to gain market share. This involves setting a low price to attract customers and establish the product's presence in the market.

 

Value-Based Price: As the product gains recognition and value in the market, a value-based pricing strategy is adopted. The price is determined based on the perceived value of the product to the customers. This approach reflects the benefits and features of the product that customers find valuable.

 

Limit Price: At this stage, the price might be set at a certain limit to maximize profit while remaining competitive. This pricing strategy takes into account factors such as production costs, competition, and market demand.

 

Niche Price: As the market matures and segmentation becomes more apparent, a company might adopt a niche pricing strategy. This involves targeting specific customer segments with unique pricing tailored to their preferences and willingness to pay.

Question 80
After determining its pricing objectives, what is the next logical step a company should take in setting its pricing policy? (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Analyse its competitor’s cost, price and offer
  • B.Determine the demand of the product
  • C.Estimate the cost of the product
  • D.Select the pricing method
Correct Answer: Determine the demand of the product

The correct answer is (B) Determine the demand of the product.

 

After determining its pricing objectives, the next logical step a company should take in setting its pricing policy is to determine the demand of the product. This is the second step in the pricing process. Determining demand involves analyzing how different price levels affect the level of demand for the product. The relationship between price and demand is usually inverse, meaning that higher prices generally lead to lower demand, and vice versa. However, this relationship can vary based on factors such as the nature of the product and consumer perceptions.

Understanding demand is essential for setting the right price, as it helps the company find a balance between pricing too high, which might reduce demand significantly, and pricing too low, which could leave potential profits on the table. By analysing demand, a company can align its pricing strategy with its objectives and find a price point that maximizes both customer interest and profitability.

 

Steps in setting a Pricing Policy

1. Selecting the Pricing Objective

2. Determining Demand

3. Estimating Costs

4. Analyzing Competitors’ Costs, Prices, and Offers

5. Selecting a Pricing Method

6. Selecting the Final Price

Question 81
Which of the following is not a market-oriented pricing technique? (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Penetration pricing
  • B.going rate pricing
  • C.perceived value pricing
  • D.Early-cash recovery pricing
Correct Answer: Early-cash recovery pricing

Among the given options, (D) Early-cash recovery pricing is not a market-oriented pricing technique.

 

Market-oriented pricing techniques focus on understanding and responding to the market conditions, customer preferences, and competitive landscape. These techniques aim to align the pricing strategy with the market demand and customer perceptions.

 

(i) Penetration Pricing: This is a market-oriented pricing technique where a company sets a relatively low price for its product or service to quickly gain a large market share. The idea is to attract customers with a lower price and then potentially raise the price once a strong market presence is established.

 

(ii) Going Rate Pricing: Also known as competitive pricing, this technique involves setting a price based on what competitors are charging for similar products or services. It's market-oriented because it takes into account the pricing strategies of competitors in the market.

 

(iii) Perceived Value Pricing: This technique focuses on pricing a product based on the value that customers perceive it to have. It aligns with market preferences and customer perceptions, making it a market-oriented approach.

Question 82
An appropriate pricing strategy for a new product to be introduced in the market will be (UGC NET Management Dec 2013)
  • A.Average/Marginal cost-plus pricing
  • B.Skimming/Penetrating pricing
  • C.Product-line pricing
  • D.Differential pricing
Correct Answer: Skimming/Penetrating pricing

In the context of introducing a new product to the market, the most appropriate option is Option (B) - Skimming/Penetrating Pricing, depending on the product's characteristics and the company's market entry goals.

Average/Marginal Cost-Plus Pricing:

  • This pricing strategy involves calculating the average or marginal cost of producing a product and then adding a certain markup or profit margin to determine the selling price.
  • The markup is usually expressed as a percentage of the cost.
  • This approach is relatively straightforward and ensures that costs are covered while generating a profit.
  • However, it may not consider the value perceived by customers or competitive pricing, and it might not be suitable for new products with unique features.

 

Skimming/Penetrating Pricing:

  • Skimming Pricing involves setting a high initial price to capture maximum revenue from early adopters who highly value the new product. Over time, the price is gradually lowered.
  • Penetrating Pricing, on the other hand, involves setting a low initial price to quickly gain a large market share. It aims to attract many buyers in a short period.
  • Skimming is suitable for products with unique features and a premium image, while Penetrating Pricing is effective for rapidly entering and establishing a market.

 

Product-Line Pricing:

  • Companies often offer a range of products within a product line, catering to different customer segments and needs.
  • Product-Line Pricing involves setting different prices for various products in the line based on factors like quality, features, and customer perceptions.
  • Prices are strategically set to reflect differences in value and customer willingness to pay for specific features.

 

Differential Pricing:

  • Differential Pricing involves charging different prices to different customer segments or in different markets, based on factors such as location, time, customer type, or quantity.
  • This strategy aims to capture maximum revenue from each customer segment or market.
  • It can be complex to implement and requires careful segmentation and pricing analysis.

Quiz Attempt #119606

Total Questions: 66
Question 1
Companies use _______ when they lack financial resources to carry out direct marketing and when they can earn more by doing so.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)
  • A.Intermediaries
  • B.Internationalisation
  • C.Influencers
  • D.Innovation
Correct Answer: Intermediaries

Let us consider each of the given option one by one.

  • Intermediaries: Companies may use intermediaries such as wholesalers, retailers, or agents when they lack the financial resources or capabilities to carry out direct marketing themselves. Intermediaries can help reach a wider customer base and distribute products more efficiently, especially when companies are unable to invest in their own direct marketing channels.
  • Internationalization: Internationalization refers to the process of expanding business operations into international markets. While internationalization can involve various strategies, it is not directly related to the situation described in the question.
  • Influencers: Influencers are individuals or entities with the ability to affect the purchasing decisions of others due to their authority, knowledge, position, or relationship with their audience. While influencers can be part of a marketing strategy, they are not directly related to the lack of financial resources for direct marketing.
  • Innovation: Innovation involves the development and implementation of new ideas, products, or processes to improve business performance. While innovation can certainly play a role in marketing strategies, it is not specifically related to the situation described in the question regarding financial constraints and direct marketing.
  •  

Therefore, the most appropriate term in this context is intermediaries, as companies may use intermediaries when they lack financial resources to carry out direct marketing and when they can earn more by doing so.

Question 2
Channel power is the ability to alter channel members' behaviour so that they take actions they would not have taken otherwise. From the following channel powers, list the ones which are subjective in nature. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)a. Legal Powerb. Coercive Powerc. Expert Powerd. Referent Powere. Reward PowerChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.d, a and c only
  • B.d, a and b only
  • C.a, b and e only
  • D.a, c and e only
Correct Answer: d, a and c only

The correct answer is (A) d, a and c only.

 

Channel power refers to the ability of one member of a distribution channel to influence the behavior of other members, often leading them to take actions they might not have taken otherwise. These powers can be subjective (based on relationships, perception, or influence) or objective (based on tangible control like legal enforcement or rewards).

 

Subjective powers in this context are those that rely on relationships, perceptions, and personal influence, as opposed to objective powers which are based on direct control or authority.

 

Referent Power (d): This is subjective. It is based on the personal charisma or influence of one channel member over others. If a member is admired, respected, or liked, others may follow their lead. It is not based on formal authority but rather on personal influence.

 

Legal Power (a): This is subjective as well. It involves the ability to compel others to act in a certain way based on legal or contractual obligations, but the power is interpreted and enacted subjectively through legal frameworks, which depend on the perception and application of the law.

 

Expert Power (c): This is subjective. Expert power comes from a channel member’s perceived knowledge or expertise in a particular area. Others follow this power because they believe the individual has specialized knowledge, which is subjective and dependent on the relationship and perception of expertise.

 

Coercive Power (b) and Reward Power (e) are objective in nature:

Coercive Power involves the ability to punish others, which is based on the threat of negative consequences.

Reward Power is based on the ability to offer positive outcomes or rewards, which also has a tangible, objective basis.

Question 3
Given below are two statements one is labelled as Assertion 'A'and the other is labelled as Reason 'R'.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)Assertion 'A':Consumers may prefer to choose the channels based on their own shopping goals as well as price, product assortment and convenience.Reason 'R':Some consumers are unwilling to ‘trade-up’ to retailers doing higher-end goods, and ‘trade down’ to discount retailers for private-label.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ arecorrectand 'R' is the correct explanation of 'A'.
  • B.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ arecorrectbut 'R' is NOT the correct explanation of 'A'.
  • C.‘A’ iscorrectbut ‘R’ is not correct.
  • D.‘A’ is notcorrectbut ‘R’ is correct.
Correct Answer: Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ arecorrectand 'R' is the correct explanation of 'A'.

The correct answer is option A.

Assertion (A): Consumers may prefer to choose the channels based on their own shopping goals as well as price, product assortment, and convenience.

This assertion is correct because consumers often select retail channels that best meet their specific needs and preferences. Factors such as price, product variety, and convenience play significant roles in their decision-making process.

 

Reason (R): Some consumers are unwilling to ‘trade-up’ to retailers doing higher-end goods, and ‘trade down’ to discount retailers for private-label.

This reason is also correct as it accurately describes consumer behavior patterns where some consumers resist moving to higher-end retailers or discount retailers due to their preferences or perceptions of value.

Question 4
Arrange the given steps involved in designing a channel system in the logical order -(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)A. Evaluating the distribution environmentB. Evaluating the short-listed alternative designs and selecting the one that suits the firm best C. Matching the channel design to customer needs/characteristicsD. Choosing the channel intensity and number of tiersE. Evaluating competitors channel designChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, E, B, D
  • B.C, A, E, D, B
  • C.C, E, D, A, B
  • D.C, A, E, B, D
Correct Answer: C, A, E, B, D

Here’s the logical order for designing a channel system:

C. Matching the channel design to customer needs/characteristics: Start by understanding and aligning the channel design with the needs and characteristics of the target customers.

A. Evaluating the distribution environment: Assess the market and distribution conditions to understand any constraints or opportunities.

E. Evaluating competitors' channel design: Analyze how competitors have set up their channel systems to identify best practices or potential gaps.

B. Evaluating the short-listed alternative designs and selecting the one that suits the firm best: Compare the possible channel options and choose the most suitable one.

D. Choosing the channel intensity and number of tiers: Decide on the level of distribution coverage and the number of intermediary tiers to effectively reach the target market.

Thus, the correct sequence is C, A, E, B, D.

Question 5
‘A channel structure in which producers, wholesalers, and retailers act as a unified system. One channel member owns the others, has contracts with them or has so much power that they all cooperate.’(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)The above description pertains to which of the following concepts?
  • A.Conventional Distribution Channel
  • B.Vertical Marketing System
  • C.Franchise System
  • D.Horizontal Marketing System
Correct Answer: Vertical Marketing System

The description provided pertains to the concept of a Vertical Marketing System (VMS). In a Vertical Marketing System, producers, wholesalers, and retailers collaborate closely, often under common ownership or through contractual agreements, to form a unified distribution channel. This alignment facilitates efficient coordination of activities, such as production, distribution, and marketing, leading to streamlined operations and enhanced value delivery to customers. Unlike conventional distribution channels where each member operates independently, a VMS enables greater control, integration, and synergy among channel partners, thereby optimizing overall channel performance and competitiveness.

Question 6
‘Creating a seamless cross-channel buying experience that integrates in-stone, online, and mobile shopping’. The above is the description of which of the following?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)(A) In store Marketing(B) Direct Marketing(C) Omni Channel Retailing(D) Online Marketing(E) Digital MarketingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(D) Only
  • B.(C) Only
  • C.(A) and (B) Only
  • D.(D) and (E) Only
Correct Answer: (C) Only

The description "Creating a seamless cross-channel buying experience that integrates in-store, online, and mobile shopping" refers to a retail strategy that ensures customers can shop seamlessly across multiple channels, whether they are shopping in a physical store, online, or using a mobile device. This integrated approach is characteristic of option (C) – Omni Channel Retailing.

 

Omni-channel retailing is specifically designed to provide a unified and consistent experience for customers across all shopping channels. It focuses on integrating all sales and marketing channels to create a cohesive customer experience.

Question 7
Arrange the following channels in the increasing order of value-addition of sales.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)A. Retail StoreB. Sales forceC. InternetD. Value-added partnersE. DistributorsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, E, C, D, B
  • B.C, A, E, B, D
  • C.C, A, E, D, B
  • D.B, C, A, E, D
Correct Answer: C, A, E, D, B

The increasing order of value-addition in sales depends on how much service, customization, and support each channel provides.

Internet (C) offers the least value addition as it is mostly self-service.

Retail Stores (A) provide some assistance but are primarily for direct sales.

Distributors (E) add more value by managing bulk sales and logistics.

Value-added partners (D) provide additional services like integration and support.

Sales Force (B) contributes the highest value by offering customized solutions, consultations, and direct client engagement.

Question 8
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Management Jun 2022)Statement I:Effective channel management call for selecting intermediaries and training and motivating them in order to build long term partnership.Statement II:Channel integration must recognize the distinctive strengths of online and offline selling and maximize their joint contributions.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I iscorrectbut Statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I isincorrectbut Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

The correct option is (A) Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

 

Statement I: Effective channel management calls for selecting intermediaries and training and motivating them in order to build long-term partnerships. This statement is correct. Effective channel management involves carefully selecting intermediaries (distributors, retailers, etc.) who can help reach the target market efficiently. Training and motivating these intermediaries are essential to ensure that they represent the brand well and contribute to building strong, mutually beneficial relationships.

 

Statement II: Channel integration must recognize the distinctive strengths of online and offline selling and maximize their joint contributions. This statement is also correct. Channel integration refers to the seamless combination of different distribution channels, including both online and offline selling. Recognizing the unique strengths of each channel and finding ways to leverage their combined benefits is essential for maximizing sales, reaching a wider audience, and offering customers more convenient options.

Question 9
A manufacturer, to market its products, focuses on the following marketing channel alternatives: (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)1. Telemarketing2. Distributors3. Sales force4. Internet5. Retail stores6. Value-added partnersSelect the code of correct sequence of the channel alternatives in order of increasing cost per transaction.Codes:
  • A.(i), (iv), (v), (ii), (iii), (vi)
  • B.(i), (iv), (ii), (v), (iii), (vi)
  • C.(iv), (i), (v), (ii), (vi), (iii)
  • D.(iv), (v), (i), (vi), (i). (iii)
Correct Answer: (iv), (i), (v), (ii), (vi), (iii)

The correct answer is (C) (iv), (i), (v), (ii), (vi), (iii)

 

Internet (iv): Internet marketing typically has a relatively low cost per transaction. It allows for reaching a wide audience with minimal overhead and transaction costs.

 

Telemarketing (i): Telemarketing can be cost-effective for reaching customers over the phone. While there are costs associated with staffing and equipment, it is often less expensive than some other methods.

 

Retail stores (v): Operating retail stores involves higher costs due to expenses related to rent, utilities, staff, and physical store maintenance. These costs can contribute to a higher cost per transaction.

 

Distributors (ii): Using distributors can be cost-effective but involves sharing a portion of the revenue with them. This sharing of profits can increase the cost per transaction compared to direct methods like internet and telemarketing.

 

Value-added partners (vi): Partnering with value-added partners might involve additional costs, such as commissions or fees for their services, which can raise the cost per transaction.

 

Sales force (iii): Maintaining a dedicated sales force can be the most expensive channel alternative. It involves salaries, commissions, training, and other expenses associated with a direct sales team. This often results in the highest cost per transaction among the listed alternatives.

Question 10
A Vertical Marketing System (VMS) combining successive stages of production and distribution under single ownership, is known as: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.Corporate VMS.
  • B.Administered VMS.
  • C.Contractual VMS.
  • D.Conventional VMS.
Correct Answer: Corporate VMS.

The correct answer is (A) Corporate VMS.

 

In a VMS, things work differently. Here, producers, wholesalers, and retailers come together as a unified system. One key member, known as the channel captain or steward, has a lot of power or ownership over others. This person ensures cooperation among members, not through commands, but by convincing everyone to work together for everyone's benefit.

Corporate VMS: A corporate VMS integrates various stages of production and distribution under a single owner. For instance, Sears used to get over half of its goods from companies it owned. Even companies like Sherwin-Williams, which produces paint, also own, and run retail outlets.

 

Administered VMS: In an administered VMS, one member's size and influence coordinate the production and distribution stages. Leading brands like Frito-Lay, Procter & Gamble, and Campbell Soup get strong support from resellers for displays, promotions, and pricing. A sophisticated approach here involves distribution programming, creating a well-planned and professionally managed vertical marketing system.

 

Contractual VMS: Contractual VMSs involve independent firms at different levels of production and distribution joining forces through contracts. This collaboration yields more efficiencies and sales impact than working alone. There are three kinds of contractual VMSs:

Wholesaler-Sponsored Voluntary Chains: Wholesalers organize groups of independent retailers to standardize practices and compete with larger chains.

Retailer Cooperatives: Retailers initiate a new business entity for wholesaling and potentially production. Members pool purchases, coordinate advertising, and share profits proportionally.

Franchise Organizations: A franchisor connects several stages in production and distribution. Franchising is a rapidly growing trend, with examples in various industries like auto rental, fast food, and motels. This can involve the franchisor owning and running units or licensing them to others.

Question 11
Which of the following are true when an organization uses intensive distribution of its products? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)A. Customers are moderate in number.B. Widespread market coverageC. Customers are brand-consciousD. Mass advertisingE. Pleasant shopping conditionsChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.B, D and E only
  • B.A, B and C only
  • C.B and D only
  • D.B, C and D only
Correct Answer: B and D only

When an organization uses intensive distribution of its products, it means that the organization aims for widespread market coverage by making its products available in as many retail outlets as possible.

 

A. Customers are moderate in number: This statement is not necessarily true for intensive distribution. Intensive distribution is typically used when there is a large number of customers or when the goal is to reach as many potential customers as possible.

 

B. Widespread market coverage: This statement is true. Intensive distribution involves making the product available in a wide range of retail outlets to cover as much of the market as possible.

 

C. Customers are brand-conscious: Intensive distribution does not necessarily imply that customers are brand-conscious. In fact, it's often used for products that have mass appeal and may not be highly brand-dependent.

 

D. Mass advertising: Intensive distribution may be associated with mass advertising, but it's not a direct consequence of it. Mass advertising can be used to support products distributed intensively, but it's not a requirement.

 

E. Pleasant shopping conditions: Intensive distribution doesn't inherently ensure pleasant shopping conditions. It's more about availability and accessibility rather than the shopping environment.

 

Given the above explanations, the most appropriate answer is (C) B and D only. Intensive distribution aims for widespread market coverage and may be associated with mass advertising, but it doesn't necessarily relate to the number of customers or customer brand-consciousness, nor does it directly impact shopping conditions.

Question 12
Choose the correct code for the following statements being correct or incorrect. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)Statement I: A well-chosen marketing channel must be aligned tocompany’smarketing strategy with respect to segmentation, targeting and positioning.Statement II: Marketingchannelare set of interdependent organizations participating in the process of making the product available for the use of consumption.Code:
  • A.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • B.Both the statements I and II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement II is correct, but Iisincorrect.
  • D.Both the statements I and II are correct.
Correct Answer: Both the statements I and II are correct.

The correct answer is (D) Both the statements I and II are correct.

 

Statement I: A well-chosen marketing channel must be aligned to the company’s marketing strategy with respect to segmentation, targeting, and positioning.

This statement is correct. When a company formulates its marketing strategy, it involves identifying and understanding its target market (segmentation), determining the specific group of customers to focus on (targeting), and defining how the company wants to position its products or services in the minds of the consumers (positioning). The marketing channel, which includes the path or route through which products move from the manufacturer to the consumer, should be carefully selected and aligned with these strategic aspects. The chosen channel should effectively reach and resonate with the targeted segments, aligning with the company's positioning strategy.

 

Statement II: Marketing channels are a set of interdependent organizations participating in the process of making the product available for use or consumption.

This statement is also correct. Marketing channels are comprised of various intermediaries or organizations involved in the distribution and delivery of products from the manufacturer to the end-users. These organizations work collaboratively, each playing a specific role in the process to ensure the product is available, accessible, and consumable by the intended customers. These intermediaries can include wholesalers, retailers, agents, distributors, and more, all functioning together to facilitate the flow of products through the market.

Question 13
The channel alternativesisNOT to be assessed on the basis of (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.economic criteria
  • B.control criteria
  • C.adaptive criteria
  • D.accumulation criteria
Correct Answer: accumulation criteria

The correct answer is (D) Accumulation criteria.

 

The assessment of channel alternatives typically considers economic criteria, control criteria, and adaptive criteria. These criteria help in evaluating the efficiency, control, and adaptability of different channel options. However, "accumulation criteria" is not a standard criterion used in assessing channel alternatives in the context of marketing and distribution channels.

 

(A) Economic Criteria: Economic criteria are fundamental factors considered when evaluating channel alternatives. This involves assessing the economic feasibility and efficiency of the distribution channels. Factors such as the cost of the channel, potential profits, cost-effectiveness, and overall financial implications are taken into account to determine the economic viability of a particular channel.

 

(B) Control Criteria: Control criteria involve assessing the level of control a company can have over a specific distribution channel. This includes factors such as the extent to which a company can manage and direct the channel's activities, branding and messaging control, and overall strategic alignment with the company's objectives. Assessing control criteria is crucial to ensure that the chosen channel aligns with the company's branding and operational requirements.

 

(C) Adaptive Criteria: Adaptive criteria involve evaluating the flexibility and adaptability of a distribution channel to changing market conditions, consumer preferences, and other dynamic factors. A distribution channel needs to be capable of adjusting and evolving in response to changes in the market, technology, regulations, and consumer behavior. Channels that are easily adaptable and responsive to changes are preferred for long-term success.

Question 14
Channel conflicts can be (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. VerticalII. HorizontalIII. DiagonalIV. CircularV. TriangularChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.I, III only
  • B.II, III only
  • C.I, II only
  • D.I, II, III only
Correct Answer: I, II only

Channel conflicts refer to disputes, disagreements, or tensions that can arise within the distribution channel or supply chain involving different entities or levels of the channel. These conflicts can be categorized based on the parties involved and the nature of the conflict. Here's an explanation of the categories mentioned in the question:

 

I. Vertical Channel Conflict: Vertical channel conflict occurs between entities at different levels of the distribution channel. For example, it can involve conflicts between manufacturers and wholesalers or between wholesalers and retailers. These conflicts typically arise when there are disagreements over issues such as pricing, terms, product availability, or distribution strategies.

 

II. Horizontal Channel Conflict: Horizontal channel conflict occurs at the same level of the distribution channel. It involves disputes and conflicts between entities that operate at the same level. For example, it can occur when competing retailers in the same geographical area vie for the same customer base. This type of conflict often involves competition for market share.

 

Given the above explanations, the correct answer is (C) I, II only, as vertical and horizontal conflicts are commonly recognized types of channel conflicts that involve entities at different levels or at the same level of the distribution channel.

Question 15
Which of the following is NOT true while determining length of distribution channel? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.The larger the market size, the longer the channel.
  • B.If the average lot size is large, it is better to have a longer channel.
  • C.If the product and the market require a high level of service, it is advisable to keep a shorter channel.
  • D.If customers shop for an assortment of products, it demands for a water channel of distribution.
Correct Answer: If the average lot size is large, it is better to have a longer channel.

The statement that is NOT true while determining the length of a distribution channel is (B) If the average lot size is large, it is better to have a longer channel.

 

In distribution channel design, the length of the channel is often influenced by various factors, including market size, the level of service required, and customer shopping behavior. However, the size of the average lot (quantity of products) being distributed typically does not dictate the length of the distribution channel.

Question 16
Match the following.  (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)List Ia. Value added by Channel Members – Low; Market Growth Rate – Lowb. Value added by Channel Members – High; Market Growth Rate – Lowc. Value added by Channel Members – Low; Market Growth Rate – Highd. Value added by Channel Members – High; Market Growth Rate – HighList IIi. Introductory stageii. Growth stageiii. Mature stageiv. Decline stageChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a-i, b-iv, c-iii, d-ii
  • B.a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii

The correct match between List I and List II is (C) a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii.

 

a. Value added by Channel Members – Low; Market Growth Rate – Low

This combination corresponds to a declining stage in the product life cycle. In declining markets, the value added by channel members is low, and the overall market growth rate is low.

 

b. Value added by Channel Members – High; Market Growth Rate – Low

This combination corresponds to the introductory stage of the product life cycle. In this stage, channel members add a high value, but the overall market growth rate is low as the product is just being introduced.

 

c. Value added by Channel Members – Low; Market Growth Rate – High

This combination represents the mature stage of the product life cycle. In a mature stage, the value added by channel members is relatively low, but the market growth rate is high.

 

d. Value added by Channel Members – High; Market Growth Rate – High

This combination corresponds to the growth stage of the product life cycle. During this stage, channel members add substantial value, and the market experiences a high growth rate.

Question 17
Experimental characteristics/factors influencing distribution decisions are: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)(1) Government policy(2) State of economy(3) Social activism(4) Technological and infrastructure developments(5) Statutory provisionsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1 and 4 only
  • B.2, 3 and 5 only
  • C.1, 3 and 4 only
  • D.1, 2, 4 and 5 only
Correct Answer: 1, 2, 4 and 5 only

The correct answer is (D) 1, 2, 4 and 5 only.

 

Government policy (1): Government policies play a significant role in shaping distribution decisions. Regulations related to distribution, trade practices, import-export policies, and more can impact how a product is distributed.

 

State of economy (2): Economic conditions influence distribution decisions. In a booming economy, businesses might opt for more extensive distribution networks to meet increased demand, while in a recession, they might reevaluate and streamline their distribution strategies.

 

Technological and infrastructure developments (4): Advancements in technology and improvements in infrastructure can greatly impact distribution decisions. For example, the rise of e-commerce and improvements in transportation have transformed distribution strategies.

 

Statutory provisions (5): Statutory provisions, including legal requirements related to distribution, can influence how products are distributed. Compliance with laws and regulations is crucial in determining the distribution channels and methods.

 

Social activism (3) is not directly related to experimental characteristics or factors influencing distribution decisions and is not included in the correct answer.

Question 18
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)Statement I:Distribution channels are sets of interdependent organizations participating in the process of making a product available for consumption.Statement II:All marketing channels have the potential for conflict and competition resulting from goal incompatibility.In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I istruebut Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I isfalsebut Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.

The correct answer is (A) Both Statement I and Statement II are true.

 

Statement I: Distribution channels are sets of interdependent organizations participating in the process of making a product available for consumption.

This statement is true. Distribution channels, also known as marketing channels, are pathways or routes through which products or services move from the manufacturer to the end consumer. These channels involve various entities such as manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers, and agents who work together to make products or services available to the end-users.

 

Statement II: All marketing channels have the potential for conflict and competition resulting from goal incompatibility.

This statement is true. In distribution channels, different organizations or entities may have varying goals and interests. For example, a manufacturer may want to increase sales, while a retailer may focus on maximizing profits. These differing objectives can lead to conflicts and competition within the channel as each entity works to achieve its own goals, potentially resulting in disagreements over pricing, promotions, allocation of resources, or other aspects of the distribution process. Effective channel management involves addressing these conflicts and finding ways to align goals for mutual benefit.

Question 19
Statement I:Designing a distribution system for a service (for-profit or non-business context) involvesto selectthe parties only through which ownership will pass.Statement II:The ownership channel for most of the services is long and quite complex because of inseparability characteristic.Statement III:Short channels usually mean more control on the part of the seller.Identify the correct code of being the statements correct or incorrect. These statements relate to channel strategies of products/services. (UGC NET Commerce July 2018)
  • A.Statements I and II are correct but III is not correct.
  • B.Statements I and III are correct but II is not correct.
  • C.Statements I and II are not correct but III is correct.
  • D.Statements I, II and III all are not correct.
Correct Answer: Statements I and II are not correct but III is correct.

The correct answer is (C) Statements I and II are not correct, but III is correct.

 

Statement I: "Designing a distribution system for a service (for-profit or non-business context) involves selecting the parties only through which ownership will pass."

This statement is not entirely correct. Distribution systems for services are not just about selecting parties through which ownership passes; they also involve defining how the service will be delivered, accessed, and experienced by the customer.

 

Statement II: "The ownership channel for most of the services is long and quite complex because of the inseparability characteristic."

This statement is not correct. Inseparability in services refers to the idea that services are often produced and consumed simultaneously. It doesn't necessarily make the ownership channel long and complex.

 

Statement III: "Short channels usually mean more control on the part of the seller."

This statement is generally correct. Shorter distribution channels in both products and services can provide more control to the seller over the distribution process.

Question 20
A conflict between Domino’s Pizza and its franchises is to be referred to as:(UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)
  • A.Vertical conflict
  • B.Horizontal conflict
  • C.Lateral conflict
  • D.Bi-lateral conflict
Correct Answer: Vertical conflict

The conflict between Domino's Pizza and its franchises would be referred to as (A) Vertical conflict.

 

Vertical conflict arises between different levels of the distribution channel, such as between a manufacturer (Domino's Pizza in this case) and its intermediaries or distributors (the franchises). In this scenario, the conflict occurs between the franchisor (Domino's Pizza) and the franchisees (individual store owners).

Question 21
In modern marketing, which of the following functions of a distribution middleman is gaining maximum importance? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.Making persuasive communication
  • B.Price negotiation
  • C.Keeping adequate inventory
  • D.Gathering market information
Correct Answer: Gathering market information

In modern marketing, the function of gathering market information (Option D) is gaining maximum importance for distribution middlemen.

 

The role of gathering market information has become increasingly vital due to advancements in technology, data analytics, and the need for real-time market insights. Distribution middlemen are now expected to provide valuable information about consumer preferences, market trends, competitor activities, and demand fluctuations. This information helps businesses make informed decisions, tailor their marketing strategies, optimize inventory management, and improve overall market responsiveness. Therefore, gathering market information is a critical function in modern marketing.

Question 22
Which one of the following is not the mode of Direct Distribution System? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2011)
  • A.Trading mediators
  • B.Vending machines
  • C.Own sales depot
  • D.Franchise shops
Correct Answer: Trading mediators

In a Direct Distribution System, the company sells its products directly to consumers without intermediaries. Among the options provided:

(A) Trading mediators - These are intermediaries and not part of a direct distribution system.

(B) Vending machines - These are a form of direct distribution where products are dispensed directly to consumers.

(C) Own sales depot - This involves the company's direct sales outlets, which is a form of direct distribution.

(D) Franchise shops - Franchise shops can also be a form of direct distribution where the franchisor sells products directly through franchisee outlets.

 

Option (A) "Trading mediators" is not a mode of direct distribution as it involves intermediaries or middlemen in the distribution process. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Trading mediators.

Question 23
Exchange concept of marketing dealsdealswith: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2010)
  • A.Exchange of products between sellers and buyers covering distribution and price aspects.
  • B.Mere appendage to production.
  • C.Achieving marketing success through product attributes.
  • D.Aggressively promote and push the products.
Correct Answer: Exchange of products between sellers and buyers covering distribution and price aspects.

The exchange concept of marketing, as the very name indicates, holds that the exchange of a product between the seller and the buyer is the central idea of marketing. While exchange does form a significant part of marketing, to view marketing as a mere exchange process would amount to a gross undermining of the essence of marketing.

 

A proper scrutiny of the marketing process would readily reveal that marketing is very broader than exchange. Exchange, at best, covers the distribution aspect and the price mechanism involved in marketing.

 

The other important aspects of marketing, such as – concern for the customer, the generation of value satisfaction, the creative selling and integrated action for serving the customer get completely overshadowed in the exchange concept of marketing.

Question 24
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Communication channels deliver and receive messages from target buyers.Statement II:Firms communicate through the look of their retail stores and Web sites and other media.Codes
  • A.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is incorrect
