  • C.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is correct

Marketing channels are how businesses reach customers. Marketers use 3 kinds of marketing channels – communication channels, distribution channels and service channels.

 

Communication channels deliver and receive messages from target buyers and include newspapers, magazines, radio, television, mail, telephone, billboards, posters, fliers, CDs, audiotapes, and the Internet. Beyond these, firms communicate through the look of their retail stores and Web sites and other media. Marketers are increasingly adding dialogue channels such as e-mail, blogs, and toll-free numbers to familiar monologue channels such as ads.

 

Distribution channels are the delivery method for products. They are used by marketers to display, sell, or deliver the physical product or service(s) to the buyer or user. These channels may be direct via the Internet, mail, or mobile phone or telephone, or indirect with distributors, wholesalers, retailers, and agents as intermediaries.

 

Service channels are used to carry out transactions with potential buyers and include warehouses, transportation companies, banks, and insurance companies.

Marketers clearly face a design challenge in choosing the best mix of communication, distribution, and service channels for their offerings.

Therefore, both statements are correct.

Question 25
Identify correct statement.Statement I:When a company acquires competitors or expands upstream or downstream, its aim is to capture a higher percentage of supply chain value.Statement II:The supply chain is a longer channel than market channels stretching from raw materials to components to finished products carried to final buyers.
  • A.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is correct

This question focuses on statements related to supply chains and their significance in a company's strategic decisions.

 

Statement I correctly assert that when a company engages in actions like acquiring competitors or expanding its presence upstream or downstream in the supply chain, its objective is to increase its share of the supply chain's overall value. These strategic moves allow the company to capture a larger portion of the value generated within the supply chain.

 

Statement II accurately describes the nature of the supply chain in comparison to other marketing channels. It highlights that the supply chain encompasses a more extended channel, spanning from the sourcing of raw materials to the production of components and finished products, ultimately reaching the end consumers. This extended coverage emphasizes the complexity and length of the supply chain.

 

Given the provided explanation, both Statement I and Statement II are correct. Statement I discuss a strategic objective related to the supply chain, and Statement II correctly characterizes the nature of the supply chain when compared to other marketing channels.

Question 26
Match the following.List I(a) Resellers(b) Physical Distribution Firms(c) Marketing services agencies(d) Financial intermediariesList II(i) Research firms(ii) Bank and credit companies.(iii) Help company find customers.(iv) Help the company stock goods.Choose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(ii) d-(i)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)

The correct option is (D).

 

Resellers - (iii) Help company find customers:

Resellers are entities or businesses that purchase products or services from manufacturers or wholesalers and then sell them to end consumers or other businesses. They play a crucial role in distribution by connecting products with customers.

 

Physical Distribution Firms - (iv) Help the company stock goods:

Physical distribution firms are responsible for the efficient movement and storage of products. They assist in managing inventory, warehousing, transportation, and logistics to ensure that products are available when and where they are needed.

 

Marketing services agencies - (i) Research firms:

Marketing services agencies are companies that provide various marketing-related services to businesses. These services may include market research, advertising, public relations, and promotional activities. Research firms, under this category, specialize in conducting research to gather valuable market insights.

 

Financial intermediaries - (ii) Bank and credit companies:

Financial intermediaries are institutions or entities that act as intermediaries between savers and borrowers in the financial markets. They include banks, credit companies, and other financial institutions that provide financial services such as loans, credit, and investment opportunities.

Question 27
Statement I:Establishing a customer–supplier relationship creates tension between safeguarding (ensuring predictable solutions)and adaptation.Statement II:Horizontal coordination can facilitate stronger customer–seller ties but at the same time may increase the risk to the customer’s and supplier’s specific investments.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect

The statement discusses the concept of horizontal coordination in customer–seller relationships and its potential implications.

 

Horizontal coordination refers to the collaboration and alignment of activities between partners or entities at the same level of the supply chain or business relationship. In this context, it focuses on the coordination between customers and suppliers.

 

The statement correctly highlights that horizontal coordination can have both positive and negative effects:

 

Positive Effect: It can facilitate stronger customer–seller ties, indicating that when customers and suppliers collaborate and coordinate effectively, their relationship tends to become stronger. This collaboration can lead to mutual benefits and value creation.

 

Negative Effect: However, it may also increase the risk to the customer’s and supplier’s specific investments. Specific investments are expenditures tailored to a particular company and its value chain partner. These investments can include company-specific training, equipment, operating procedures, or systems. While these investments can enhance profitability and positioning, they can also become risky if the collaborative relationship faces challenges or changes.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) - Statement I is correct, and Statement II is incorrect, as per the provided explanation.

Question 28
_________ investments are those expenditures tailored to a particular company and value chain partner.
  • A.Particular
  • B.Special
  • C.Specific
  • D.Customized
Correct Answer: Specific

Specific investments are those expenditures tailored to a particular company and value chain partner (investments in company-specific training, equipment, and operating procedures or systems). They help firms grow profits and achieve their positioning. 

 

Specific investments, however, also entail considerable risk to both customer and supplier. Transaction theory from economics maintains that because these investments are partially sunk, they lock firms into a particular relationship. Sensitive cost and process information may need to be exchanged. A buyer may be vulnerable to holdup because of switching costs; a supplier may be more vulnerable because it has dedicated assets and/or technology/knowledge at stake.

Question 29
Producers of convenience goods typically prefer: (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.Exclusive distribution
  • B.Intensive distribution
  • C.Selective distribution
  • D.Intermittent distribution
Correct Answer: Intensive distribution

Producers of convenience goods typically prefer (B) Intensive distribution.

 

1. Intensive Distribution, the product is sold to as many appropriate retailers or wholesalers as possible. Intensive distribution is appropriate for products such as chewing gum, candy bars, soft drinks, bread, film, and cigarettes where the primary factor influencing the purchase decision is convenience.

 

2. Selective Distribution, the number of outlets that may carry a product is limited, but not to the extent of exclusive dealing. By carefully selecting wholesalers or retailers, the manufacturer can concentrate on potentially profitable accounts and develop solid working relationships to ensure that the product is properly merchandised. The producer also may restrict the number of retail outlets if the product requires specialized servicing or sales support. Selective distribution may be used for product categories such as clothing, appliances, televisions, stereo equipment, home furnishings, and sports equipment. 

 

3. Exclusive distribution to sell the product in a geographic area, the arrangement is referred to as exclusive distribution. Products such as specially automobiles, some major appliances, certain brands of furniture, and lines of clothing that enjoy a high degree of brand loyalty are likely to be distributed on an exclusive basis.

 

There is nothing termed as intermittent distribution.

Question 30
Which of the following is the additional intermediary between wholesaler and retailer in 3-Level consumer marketing channel?
  • A.Broker
  • B.Jobber
  • C.Agent
  • D.Co-retailer
Correct Answer: Jobber

Channel levels consist of consumer marketing channel or the industrial marketing channels. A factor common among both channel levels is that both include the producer as well as the end customer.

 

Zero Level channel / Direct Marketing Channel – Consists of a manufacturer directly selling to the end consumer. This might mean door to door sales, direct mails, or telemarketing. Dell online sale is a perfect example of a zero-level channel marketing.

 

One Level Channel – As the name suggests, the one level channel has an intermediary (Retailer) in between the producer and the consumer. An example of this can be insurance in which there is an insurance agent between the insurance company and the customer.

 

Two level Channel – A widely used marketing channel especially in the FMCG and the consumer durables industry which consists of a Wholesaler and a Retailer.

 

Three level Channel – Again observed in both the FMCG and the consumer durables industry, the three-level channel has Wholesaler, Jobber and Retailer. A jobber purchases the manufacturer's product from a larger wholesaler and distributes it to smaller retail accounts.

Question 31
Channel Conflict occurs mainly because of:
  • A.Goal Incompatibility
  • B.Differences in Perceptions of the Market:
  • C.Role Ambiguity
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Channel conflict in marketing channels can occur for various reasons, and it often arises due to a combination of factors. These factors can include:

 

(A) Goal Incompatibility: When different channel members have conflicting objectives or goals, it can lead to channel conflict. For example, a manufacturer may want to increase profit margins, while retailers may want lower prices to attract more customers.

 

(B) Differences in Perceptions of the Market: When channel members have different views on market conditions, customer preferences, or the effectiveness of marketing strategies, it can create conflict. These differences in perception can lead to disagreements on how to approach the market.

 

(C) Role Ambiguity: When the roles and responsibilities of different channel members are not clearly defined, it can result in conflicts over who should perform specific tasks or functions within the channel.

 

So, the correct answer is (D) All of the above, as channel conflict can be caused by any or all of these factors.

Question 32
Conflicts that occur in marketing channels working at same level is classified as:
  • A.Vertical Level Conflict
  • B.Multi-channel Conflict
  • C.Slope Conflict
  • D.Horizontal Level Conflict
Correct Answer: Horizontal Level Conflict

Channel Conflict: There can be 3 types of channel conflict among channel members:

 

Vertical Level Conflict is the conflict between the higher and lower-level channels i.e. between the wholesaler and manufacturer. Another example of the vertical conflict is the non-cooperation and boycott of pharmaceutical companies by their wholesalers and chemists.

 

Horizontal Level Conflict is the conflict between the same level of channel members i.e. between the same retailers on the issue of price and territory jumping.

 

Multi-channel Level Conflict is when the middleman comes in conflict with the manufacturer using both direct and indirect means of distribution. For example, the firm may have its own shop in the area, and in the same area it may be distributing the product through recognized middlemen. The former is direct distribution and the latter is indirect. The conflict occurs when the shop prices are lower than that of the middlemen or dealers.

 

*Slope conflict is not a marketing concept.

Question 33
A firm have its own shop in one area, and in the same area, it is distributing the product through recognized intermediaries. The former is directdistributionand the latter is indirect. This may lead to:
  • A.Vertical Channel conflict
  • B.Horizontal Channel conflict
  • C.Intra-Channel Conflict
  • D.Multi-Channel Conflict
Correct Answer: Multi-Channel Conflict

The correct answer is (D) Multi-Channel Conflict.

 

Multi-channel conflict, also known as dual distribution or hybrid distribution, occurs when a company uses multiple distribution channels to reach customers in the same market or area. In this scenario, the firm has both its own shop (a direct distribution channel) and recognized intermediaries (an indirect distribution channel) in the same area.

 

This can lead to conflicts and challenges because the company may face issues related to pricing, competition, territory, and channel management. Managing multiple channels simultaneously can create tensions and conflicts between the company's direct and indirect distribution partners, which is characteristic of multi-channel conflict.

Question 34
“The manufacturer reminds the channel partner to carry out their activities in accordance with the contract they have entered into at the time they became the channel partners”, refers to which one of the following channel powers?
  • A.Referent power
  • B.Coercive power
  • C.Legitimate power
  • D.Reward power
Correct Answer: Legitimate power

The Channel Power refers to the ability of any one channel member to alter or modify the behavior of other members in the distribution channel, due to its relatively strong position in the market. There are five types of channel powers:

 

1) Coercive Power: The manufacturer threatens to terminate the relationship with other channel partners or withdraw the resources deployed with them. With this power, the manufacturer can dominate the others and keep them under his control. But the negative side is, the channel partners may lose their faith in the manufacturer and may enter into inter-conflicts.

 

2) Reward Power: The manufacturer provides several additional benefits to the intermediaries, with the intention to motivate them to perform certain activities as required. This power is very useful since it brings in the maximum efforts from each channel partner, but this may sometimes be negative as the channel partners may always seek for the benefits in case, they are required to do some other activity.

 

3) Legitimate Power: Here the manufacturer reminds the channel partner to carry out their activities in accordance with the contract they have entered into at the time they became the channel partners.

 

4) Expert power: The manufacturer has power over channel partners because of his expertise and knowledge about the field.

 

5) Referent Power: The manufacturer should develop its image in such a way, that the intermediaries must feel proud to be associated with it. The manufacturer with the influential image can get varied options with regard to the channel partners. But if the manufacturer is weak then intermediaries may not like to get associated with it because that might spoil their market image.

Question 35
_______ channel retailing is cross-channel buying experience that integrates in-store, online and mobile shopping.
  • A.Cross channel retailing
  • B.Store channel retailing
  • C.Omni channel retailing
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Omni channel retailing

The correct answer is (C) Omni channel retailing.

 

Omni-channel retailing refers to a seamless and integrated approach to retailing that provides customers with a unified and consistent shopping experience across various channels, including physical stores, online platforms, mobile apps, and other touchpoints. It allows customers to browse, purchase, and interact with a retailer using multiple channels, and their experience is consistent and interconnected across all these channels.

 

This approach aims to eliminate silos between different sales channels and offers customers the flexibility to shop and interact with the retailer in a way that is most convenient for them. It also involves features such as click-and-collect, in-store pickup for online orders, and the ability to return items through multiple channels.

 

Omni-channel retailing recognizes that customers may use a combination of in-store and digital channels during their shopping journey, and it seeks to provide a cohesive and convenient experience that meets their preferences and expectations.

Question 36
For the following 2 statements ofStatementI and Statement II indicate the correct code:Statement I:In a corporate VMS,one member of the distribution channel owns the other members.Statement II:In contractual VMSindependent firms joined together for their mutual benefit.Codes:
  • A.Statement I and Statement II both are correct.
  • B.Statement I isincorrectand Statement II is correct.
  • C.Statement I and Statement II both are incorrect.
  • D.Statement I iscorrectand Statement II is incorrect.
Correct Answer: Statement I and Statement II both are correct.

Vertical Marketing Systems

In conventional marketing systems, producers, wholesalers, and retailers are separate businesses that are all trying to maximize their profits. When the effort of one channel member to maximize profits comes at the expense of other members, conflicts can arise that reduce profits for the entire channel. To address this problem, more and more companies are forming vertical marketing systems. A vertical marketing system (VMS) is one in which the main members of a distribution channel—producer, wholesaler, and retailer—work together as a unified group in order to meet consumer needs. Vertical marketing systems can take several forms.

 

In a corporate VMS, one member of the distribution channel owns the other members. Although they are owned jointly, each company in the chain continues to perform a separate task.

In an administered VMS, one member of the channel is large and powerful enough to coordinate the activities of the other members without an ownership stake.

Finally, a contractual VMS consists of independent firms joined together by contract for their mutual benefit. One type of contractual VMS is a retailer cooperative, in which a group of retailers buy from a jointly owned wholesaler. Another type of contractual VMS is a franchise organization, in which a producer licenses a wholesaler to distribute its products. So, the answer is contractual VMS.

Question 37
Match the following.List-I (Physical Distribution Activities)(a) Order Processing(b) Packaging(c) Warehousing(d) Customer ServiceList-II (Example)1. Storage2. Repair3. Catalogue4. ProtectionCodes:
  • A.a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2
  • B.a-4, b-2, c-3, d-1
  • C.a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1
  • D.a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4
Correct Answer: a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2

The correct match for the Physical Distribution Activities in List-I and their examples in List-II is:

 

(a) Order Processing - 3. Catalogue

(b) Packaging - 4. Protection

(c) Warehousing - 1. Storage

(d) Customer Service - 2. Repair

 

An order is processed once the customer selects a product from company’s catalogue. Product catalogues help determine the types of products a service provider can sell, to whom they can sell, for how much and under what terms.

 

Packaging is done to ensure that the product, that is being ordered by the customer reaches his door steps without any damages. Thus it is done to protect the product from being damaged.

 

A warehouse is a place where company stores its finished products or raw material.

Customer service is required to look into post-purchase customer complaints, like repair, replacement or return of faulty product.

 

So, the correct answer is (A) a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2.

Question 38
A type of situation which arises when actions of one channel member prevents another channel member to achieve its objectives is classified as:
  • A.Channel Disturbance
  • B.Channel Conflict
  • C.Channel Mismanagement
  • D.Channel Ordination
Correct Answer: Channel Conflict

Channel Conflict is disagreement among marketing channel members on goals, roles, and rewards—who should do what and for what rewards. The Channel Conflict occurs largely because of financial and non-financial reasons. So, it is a situation where actions of one channel member prevents another channel member to achieve its objectives.

Question 39
The ____________ are firms that help the company to promote, sell and distribute its goods to final buyers. They include resellers, physical distribution firms, marketing services agencies.
  • A.Marketing suppliers
  • B.Marketing intermediaries
  • C.Marketing carriers
  • D.Marketing agents
Correct Answer: Marketing intermediaries

The correct answer is (B) Marketing intermediaries.

 

Marketing intermediaries are firms or individuals that assist a company in promoting, selling, and distributing its products or services to the final buyers. They play a crucial role in the marketing channel, helping to bridge the gap between the manufacturer and the end consumers. This category includes resellers, physical distribution firms (like transportation companies), and marketing services agencies (such as advertising agencies).

Question 40
A wholesaler who does not take title to goods and whose function is to bring buyers and sellers together and assist in negotiation is known as:
  • A.Agent
  • B.Retailer
  • C.Broker
  • D.Merchant
Correct Answer: Broker

The correct answer is (C) Broker.

 

A broker is a wholesaler who does not take title to goods but plays a role in bringing buyers and sellers together and assisting in negotiation between them. They act as intermediaries in facilitating transactions between parties but do not take ownership of the products they help sell.

Question 41
Manufacturers of cars andmotor cyclestypically seek_______ distribution. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Selective
  • B.Intensive
  • C.Exclusive
  • D.Restrictive
Correct Answer: Exclusive

The correct answer is (C) Exclusive.

 

Restrictive distribution arrangements result from agreements between suppliers and reseller-buyers of merchandise in which one of the parties or both of them accept limitations on the scope of managerial discretion with respect to certain marketing practices, such as the selection of sales territories, customers, products, or prices. Restrictive arrangements differ greatly in form and substance and in the particular marketing contexts in which they are applied. 

 

Intensive distribution, the product is sold to as many appropriate retailers or wholesalers as possible. Intensive distribution is appropriate for products such as chewing gum, candy bars, soft drinks, bread, film, and cigarettes. 

 

In selective distribution, the number of outlets that may carry a product is limited, but not to the extent of exclusive dealing. By carefully selecting wholesalers or retailers, the manufacturer can concentrate on potentially profitable accounts and develop solid working relationships. 

 

When a single outlet is given an exclusive franchise to sell the product in a geographic area, the arrangement is referred to as exclusive distribution.

Question 42
Who among the following take(s) both title to and possession of goods from the preceding member(s) and channelize them to the subsequent members? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)(a) Agent intermediaries(b) Merchant intermediariesCodes
  • A.(a) only
  • B.(b) only
  • C.Both (a) and (b)
  • D.Neither (a) nor (b)
Correct Answer: (b) only

The correct answer is (B) (b) only.

 

Merchant intermediaries are the ones who take both title to and possession of goods from the preceding members and channelize them to the subsequent members. Agent intermediaries, on the other hand, do not take title to or possession of the goods; they simply facilitate transactions between buyers and sellers.

Question 43
Horizontal marketing system comprises of: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.the producer, wholesaler and retailer acting in a unified system.
  • B.multi-channel marketing.
  • C.2 or more marketing channels to reach one or more customer segments.
  • D.2 or more unrelated companies put together resources to exploit an emerging market.
Correct Answer: 2 or more unrelated companies put together resources to exploit an emerging market.

The correct answer is (D) 2 or more unrelated companies put together resources to exploit an emerging market.

 

A horizontal marketing system refers to a situation where two or more unrelated companies or organizations come together to pool their resources and exploit a new or emerging market opportunity. It involves cooperation and collaboration among these entities to achieve a common marketing goal, typically in a market where none of them has a dominant position. Horizontal marketing systems are formed to leverage the complementary strengths and resources of different organizations to gain a competitive advantage in the target market.

Question 44
Which type of differentiation is used to gain competitive advantage through the way a firm designs its distribution coverage, expertise, and performance? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.Channel differentiation
  • B.Services differentiation
  • C.People differentiation
  • D.Product differentiation
Correct Answer: Channel differentiation

The correct answer is (A) Channel differentiation.

 

Various types of differentiation are given below:

Channel Differentiation

A firm can also gain competitive advantage by channel differentiation. This means that the firm differentiates itself by differentiating their channel’s coverage, expertise and performance. So how does the firm get goods to the customer? It might be through a smooth-functioning, speedy direct channel.

 

Product Differentiation

Product Differentiation refers to differentiating the market offer based on features, performance, style or design. A sandwich-maker could differentiate itself by offering healthy, low-fat products. A car manufacturer might use extremely large engine as a point of differentiation. Thus, your product is better, faster, cheaper, healthier, greener etc.

 

Service Differentiation

Service Differentiation is based on aspects such as speedy or careful delivery, opening hours, customer care etc. Thus, the service is differentiated. For instance, an airline could differentiate itself by means of extraordinary customer care and very attentive and graceful stewardesses. This type of differentiation may then become experience differentiation.

 

People Differentiation

Companies can also differentiate themselves by people differentiation. People differentiation means nothing else than hiring and training better people than competitors do. Staff can be more friendly, competent, courteous etc. Certainly, this mainly appeals to customer contact staff.

 

Image Differentiation

Image Differentiation refers to the image a company or a brand has in consumers’ minds. The development of a strong and distinctive image requires creativity and a lot of work. Only over a long period, an image in consumers’ minds can be attained. If you want to differentiate your company by high quality, this image must be supported by absolutely everything your company does.

Question 45
Which of the following statements are correct? Select the correct code. (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)Statement I:Horizontal conflict between channel members is caused due to channel members impinge on the market territory of other intermediaries at different level.Statement II:Vertical conflict is caused due to intense price competition, disagreement about promotional activities, attempts to bypass intermediary and distribute direct, differing expectations as to channel or intermediary performance.Statement III:Hybrid channel conflict arises due to grey marketing.Codes
  • A.I and III
  • B.I and II
  • C.II and III
  • D.I, II and III
Correct Answer: II and III

The correct answer is (C) II and III.

 

Statement I: Horizontal conflict between channel members is caused due to channel members impinge on the market territory of other intermediaries at different levels.

This statement is not correct. Horizontal conflict typically occurs when channel members at the same level of the distribution channel (for example, two retailers or two wholesalers) compete with each other in the same market territory. It arises when businesses at the same level in the distribution chain, offering similar products or services, clash in their efforts to capture a larger share of the market.

 

Statement II: Vertical conflict is caused due to intense price competition, disagreement about promotional activities, attempts to bypass intermediaries and distribute direct, differing expectations as to channel or intermediary performance.

This statement is correct. Vertical conflict occurs between channel members at different levels of the distribution channel, such as between manufacturers and wholesalers, or wholesalers and retailers. It can be caused by various factors, including disagreements over pricing, promotional strategies, attempts by manufacturers to bypass intermediaries and sell directly to end customers, and differences in expectations regarding the performance of channel partners.

 

Statement III: Hybrid channel conflict arises due to grey marketing.

This statement is correct. Hybrid channel conflict can indeed arise due to grey marketing. Grey marketing involves the unauthorized distribution or sale of products in a market where the manufacturer did not intend for them to be sold. This can create conflict within a distribution channel, especially when authorized channel partners are affected by the presence of unauthorized sellers.

Question 46
The following are the steps in designing the market driven distribution: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)1. Know what customers want2. Determine the costs3. Review assumptions4. Decide on the outlet5. Compare alternatives6. Implement changesSelect the right sequence of the steps from the codes given below:Codes
  • A.1, 4, 2, 5, 3, 6
  • B.1, 2, 3, 5, 4, 6
  • C.1, 3, 4, 5, 2, 6
  • D.2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1
Correct Answer: 1, 4, 2, 5, 3, 6

The correct sequence of steps in designing the market-driven distribution is:

1. Know what customers want

2. Decide on the outlet

3. Determine the costs

4. Compare alternatives

5. Review assumptions

6. Implement changes

 

So, the correct answer is (A) 1, 4, 2, 5, 3, 6.

Question 47
Who plays their significant role in distribution of goods when they do not sell to ultimate users or consumers? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.Retailer
  • B.Wholesaler
  • C.Mediator
  • D.Commission agent
Correct Answer: Wholesaler

A wholesaler is an intermediary entity in the distribution channel that buys in bulk and sells to resellers rather than to consumers. In its simplest form, a distributor performs a similar role but often provides more complex services. Distributors and wholesalers often work together as channel partners.

 

Retailers: They own and run a single shop selling directly to the end consumer and determine their policies independently. For example, stand-alone grocery shops, florists, stationery shops, book shops, etc.

 

Commission agents: Take physical possession of products and negotiate sales. Used most often in agricultural marketing by farmers who do not want to sell their own output. Takes a truckload of commodities to a central market, sells it for the best price, deducts a commission and expenses, and remits the balance to the producers.

 

Mediator: A mediator is a person engaged in dealing with two parties on terms of money and delivery and other terms. The parties maybe manufacturer and wholesaler, wholesaler and retailer.

Question 48
Physical distribution provides: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)
  • A.Place utility
  • B.Time utility
  • C.Place and Time utility
  • D.Form utility
Correct Answer: Place and Time utility

The correct answer is (C) Place and Time utility.

 

Physical distribution in marketing and logistics is the process of efficiently moving products from the manufacturer to the end consumer. It involves various activities and functions aimed at ensuring that products are available at the right place and time for customers to purchase. Here's an explanation of the utilities provided by physical distribution:

 

Place Utility: Place utility refers to the value added to a product or service by making it available in the right location or place for customers to access and purchase. Physical distribution plays a crucial role in ensuring that products are distributed to various distribution channels, retail locations, or points of sale where customers can conveniently buy them. This utility eliminates the need for customers to travel long distances to acquire the product.

 

Time Utility: Time utility, on the other hand, involves making products available to customers at the right time when they need them. Physical distribution ensures that products are delivered or stocked in a timely manner, minimizing delays, and ensuring that customers can obtain the product when it is most convenient for them. This can involve efficient transportation, inventory management, and order fulfillment processes.

Question 49
Manufacturers of convenience goods typically seek ________ distribution. (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Exclusive
  • B.Intensive
  • C.Restrictive
  • D.Selective
Correct Answer: Intensive

Manufacturers of convenience goods typically seek intensive distribution.

 

Intensive distribution involves making a product available in as many retail outlets as possible within a given geographic area. This strategy is commonly used for convenience goods, which are everyday items that consumers frequently purchase without much effort or consideration. Examples of convenience goods include snacks, soft drinks, toiletries, and other low-cost, frequently consumed products. Manufacturers of these goods want them to be readily available to consumers wherever they shop, so they use intensive distribution to ensure broad coverage in various retail locations.

Question 50
Selling the products only through a single wholesaler or retailer is called: (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Extensive distribution strategy
  • B.Selective distribution strategy
  • C.Exclusive distribution strategy
  • D.Mass merchandise strategy
Correct Answer: Exclusive distribution strategy

Selling products only through a single wholesaler or retailer is called exclusive distribution strategy.

 

In an exclusive distribution strategy, a manufacturer or supplier restricts the number of intermediaries or retailers that are authorized to carry and sell their products. This approach is often used for premium or specialty products where the manufacturer wants to maintain tight control over the distribution and positioning of their goods. It can create an exclusive and high-end image for the product, as consumers can only find it in select locations.

Question 51
“The manufacturer threatens to withdraw a resource or terminate a relationship if intermediaries fail to cooperate”, refers to which one of the following channel powers?
  • A.Referent power
  • B.Coercive power
  • C.Legitimate power
  • D.Reward power
Correct Answer: Coercive power

In 1959, French and Raven described 5 bases of power:

1. Legitimate Power – This comes from the belief that a person has the formal right to make demands, and to expect others to be compliant and obedient.

2. Reward Power – This results from one person's ability to compensate another for compliance.

3. Expert Power – This is based on a person's high levels of skill and knowledge.

4. Referent Power – This is the result of a person's perceived attractiveness, worthiness and right to others' respect.

5. Coercive Power – This comes from the belief that a person can punish others for noncompliance.

 

6 years later, Raven added an extra power base:

Informational Power – This results from a person's ability to control the information that others need to accomplish something.

Question 52
Which of the following is NOT a function of distribution agency? (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Transportation
  • B.Servicing
  • C.Inventorying
  • D.Manufacturing
Correct Answer: Manufacturing

The correct answer is (D) Manufacturing.

 

A distribution agency is primarily involved in activities related to the distribution and delivery of products, such as transportation, servicing, and inventory management. Manufacturing is a separate function that involves the production of goods, which is distinct from the role of a distribution agency.

Question 53
One-level channel consists of: (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Producer-consumer
  • B.Producer-dealer-consumer
  • C.Producer-dealer-retailer - consumer
  • D.Producer-dealer-wholesaler- retailer- consumer
Correct Answer: Producer-dealer-consumer

A one-level channel, also known as a direct channel, is a distribution channel that involves a straightforward path from the producer to the consumer with only one intermediary, which is the dealer. Here is an explanation of each element in this type of distribution channel:

  • Producer: This is the manufacturer or producer of the goods or products. They create or produce the items that will eventually reach the end consumer.
  • Dealer: The dealer acts as the intermediary between the producer and the consumer. They purchase products directly from the producer and are responsible for distributing these products to the end consumers. Dealers can take on various forms, such as distributors, agents, or retailers, depending on the industry and the specific distribution arrangement.
  • Consumer: The consumer is the final recipient of the product. They purchase and use the product for personal or business purposes.

 

In a one-level channel, the dealer plays a crucial role in facilitating the distribution process. They may buy products in bulk from the producer and then sell them to individual consumers or other businesses. This type of channel is common in situations where the producer wants more control over the distribution process and maintains a close relationship with a specific dealer or set of dealers.

Question 54
The following statements relate to the functions of the marketing channel members. Indicate the statements being correct or incorrect.Statement I:Channel members do not gather information about potential and current customers, competitors and other actors and forces in the marketing environment.Statement II:Channel members acquire the funds to finance inventories at different levels in the marketing channel. (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)Codes
  • A.Both the Statements are correct.
  • B.Both the Statements are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct while Statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.

The correct answer is (B) Both the Statements are incorrect.

 

Statement I is incorrect because channel members do gather information about potential and current customers, competitors, and other actors and forces in the marketing environment. This information is crucial for making informed decisions and adapting to changes in the market.

 

Statement II is also incorrect. Channel members do play a role in acquiring funds to finance inventories at different levels in the marketing channel. They may engage in activities such as trade credit, financing agreements, or other financial arrangements to ensure that inventory is adequately funded and available when needed.

Question 55
Which one of the following is a system of partnerships and alliances that a firm creates to source, augment, and deliver its offerings? (UGC NET ManagementNov 2017)
  • A.Value network
  • B.Omni-channel marketing
  • C.Integrated marketing channel system
  • D.Direct marketing channel
Correct Answer: Value network

The correct answer is (A) Value network.

 

Value network- Partnerships that a firm creates to source, augment and deliver its offerings. Value delivery network is a part of supply chain of a company and includes all its direct participants involved in production, distribution, marketing, customer service, etc for given geographical area.

 

Integrated marketing channel system- Integrated Marketing is an approach to creating a unified and seamless experience for consumers to interact with the brand/enterprise; it attempts to meld all aspects of marketing communication such as advertising, sales promotion, public relations, direct marketing, and social media, through their respective mix of tactics, methods, channels, media, and activities, so that all work together as a unified force.

 

Omni-channel marketing- Omni-channel marketing has become key to marketing success as customers engage with companies in a variety of ways, including in a physical store, online via websites and mobile apps, through physical and virtual catalogs, and through social media.

 

Direct Marketing Channel – Consists of a manufacturer directly selling to the end consumer. This might mean door to door sales, direct mails or telemarketing. Dell online sales is a perfect example of a zero-level channel marketing.

Question 56
Which of the following is NOT primarily a responsibility of producers for their channel members? (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)
  • A.Establishing Price Policies
  • B.Condition of sales
  • C.Distributors' territorial rights
  • D.Establishing distribution efficiencies
Correct Answer: Establishing distribution efficiencies

The responsibility of establishing distribution efficiencies primarily lies with the channel members and not with the producers. Producers are typically responsible for setting price policies, conditions of sales, and distributors' territorial rights. So, the correct answer is (D) Establishing distribution efficiencies.

Question 57
Arrange the steps of Order Processing in correct order.(i) Order and invoice shipment(ii) Inventory and production scheduling(iii) Transmission by the salesperson.(iv) Order entry and customer credit checkCodes
  • A.(ii), (i), (iii), (iv)
  • B.(i), (iv), (iii), (ii)
  • C.(i), (iii), (ii), (iv)
  • D.(iii), (iv), (ii), (i)
Correct Answer: (iii), (iv), (ii), (i)

Market Logistics: Planning, implementing, and controlling, the physical flow of materials, final goods, and related information from points of origin to points of consumption to meet customer requirements at a profit.

 

Market-logistics strategies must be derived from business strategies, rather than solely from cost considerations. The logistics system must be information-intensive and establish electronic links among all the significant parties. The firm must make 4 major decisions about its market logistics: Order Processing, Warehousing, Inventory and Transportation.

 

Order Processing: Most companies today are trying to shorten the order-to-payment cycle—that is, the elapsed time between an order’s receipt, delivery, and payment. This cycle has many steps, including order transmission by the salesperson, order entry and customer credit check, inventory and production scheduling, order and invoice shipment, and receipt of payment. The longer this cycle takes, the lower the customer’s satisfaction and the lower the company’s profits.

 

Warehousing: Every company must store finished goods until they are sold, because production and consumption cycles rarely match. On the one hand, more stocking locations mean goods can be delivered to customers more quickly, but warehousing and inventory costs are higher. To reduce these costs, the company might centralize its inventory in one place and use fast transportation to fill orders. Some inventory is kept at or near the plant, and the rest in warehouses in other locations. 

The company might own private warehouses and also rent space in public warehouses. 

 

Types of Warehouses:

  • Storage warehouses store goods for moderate to long periods of time. 
  • Distribution warehouses receive goods from various company plants and suppliers and move them out as soon as possible. 
  • Automated warehouses employ advanced materials-handling systems under the control of a central computer and are increasingly becoming the norm.

 

So, the correct answer is (D) (iii), (iv), (ii), (i).

Question 58
Given below are two statements - one islabeledas Assertion and the other islabeledas Reason.Assertion "A":The company needs to balance order-processing costs and inventory-carrying costs.Reason "R":Optimal order quantity can be determined by observing how order-processing costs and inventory-carrying costs sum up at different order levels.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R arecorrectand R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A

The correct answer is (A) Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion (A): The company needs to balance order-processing costs and inventory-carrying costs.

In supply chain and inventory management, one of the critical challenges for companies is finding the right balance between order-processing costs and inventory-carrying costs. Order-processing costs are the expenses associated with receiving and processing customer orders, which can include administrative costs, labor, and paperwork. On the other hand, inventory-carrying costs refer to the costs incurred by holding and storing inventory, including warehousing, storage, insurance, and the opportunity cost of tying up capital in unsold goods.

 

Reason (R): Optimal order quantity can be determined by observing how order-processing costs and inventory-carrying costs sum up at different order levels.

To determine the optimal order quantity, companies need to consider both order-processing costs and inventory-carrying costs. By analyzing how these costs change at various order quantity levels, companies can identify the point at which the total costs are minimized. This point represents the optimal order quantity, where the expenses related to processing orders and holding inventory are balanced most efficiently.

Question 59
Which among the following is not an indirect distribution channel?
  • A.Internet
  • B.Wholesales
  • C.Retails
  • D.Warehouses
Correct Answer: Internet

The marketer uses distribution channels to display, sell, or deliver the physical product or service(s) to the buyer or user. These channels may be direct via the Internet, mail, or mobile phone or telephone, or indirect with distributors, wholesalers, retailers, and agents as intermediaries.

Question 60
One-level channel of distribution consists of (UGC NET Management Dec 2010):
  • A.Producer – consumer
  • B.Producer – dealer – consumer
  • C.Producer – dealer – retailer – consumer
  • D.Producer – dealer – wholesaler – retailer – consumer
Correct Answer: Producer – dealer – consumer

A one-level channel of distribution has only one intermediary between the producer and the consumer.

  • Example: Producer → Retailer (Dealer) → Consumer.

Option (A) is zero-level channel (direct distribution).

Option (C) is a two-level channel (retailer + wholesaler).

Option (D) is a three-level channel (agent/wholesaler + retailer).

Question 61
In multi-level channel arrangement Jobber stands in between ________. (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.manufacturer and wholesaler
  • B.wholesaler and retailer
  • C.retailer and consumer
  • D.none of these
Correct Answer: manufacturer and wholesaler

  • A Jobber is a middleman who buys in bulk from manufacturers (sometimes on advance payment) and sells to wholesalers, dealers, or small retailers.

  • Historically, in Indian markets (especially textiles, stock exchanges, etc.), the Jobber operated as a link between the manufacturer and the wholesaler.

Question 62
Franchise organisation is an example of ______ vertical marketing system. (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.Corporate
  • B.Administered
  • C.Contractual
  • D.Co-operative
Correct Answer: Contractual

Franchise organization is an example of a Contractual vertical marketing system.

 

In a vertical marketing system, different entities in the distribution channel work together to efficiently bring a product or service to the end consumer. Vertical marketing systems can be categorized into three main types: corporate, contractual, and administered.

 

Corporate Vertical Marketing System

In a corporate VMS, a single entity owns and operates all levels of the distribution channel. This means that a single company controls manufacturing, distribution, and retailing. This approach provides tight control over the entire process.

 

Administered Vertical Marketing System

In an administered VMS, a dominant member of the distribution channel (often a large manufacturer or retailer) coordinates the activities of independent firms at different levels of the channel. This coordination is achieved through informal leadership, power, and influence rather than through ownership.

 

Contractual Vertical Marketing System

In a contractual VMS, independent firms at different levels of the distribution channel formally agree to cooperate and work together under a contractual arrangement. Franchising is a classic example of a contractual VMS. In a franchise system, a franchisor (the owner of the brand or business concept) grants the right to operate a business using its brand and systems to franchisees in exchange for fees and royalties. Both parties (franchisor and franchisee) have a contractual relationship, and they work together to promote and distribute the product or service.

Question 63
Which of the following marketing channel function helps tofulfillthe completed transactions? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)
  • A.Gathering and distributing information about consumers.
  • B.Reaching an agreement on price and other terms.
  • C.Communicating with prospective buyers.
  • D.Assuming the risks of carrying out the channel work.
Correct Answer: Assuming the risks of carrying out the channel work.

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Assuming the risks of carrying out the channel work is an important function of marketing channels, as it involves taking on the risks associated with the distribution and sale of products or services. This includes risks such as inventory management, transportation, and payment processing. By assuming these risks, the marketing channel helps to ensure that the completed transactions are fulfilled successfully and that customers receive the products or services they have purchased.

Question 64
XYZ company is in the business of FMCG products focusing on items like Atta, Besan, Maida etc. They are presently operating outside Delhi, in the state of Haryana. Looking at demand in Delhi, they want to market their products in Delhi, covering the entire Delhi. After going through various market reports and market surveys, they found that competition is very high in Delhi. They want to focus on the quality of their products and still want to fight the competition. They want to create a marketing strategy for their business at the time of entering the Delhi market. For doing so, they have appointed you as Manager Marketing (In-charge Delhi) to design a marketing strategy for them.For distribution of FMCG products like Atta,Baisan, Maida etc, what type of distribution strategy will you recommend?(UGC NET Management Jun 2021)
  • A.Intensive distribution
  • B.Selective distribution
  • C.Exclusive distribution
  • D.Dual level of distribution
Correct Answer: Intensive distribution

Option A is the correct answer. For FMCG products intensive distribution is the best distribution strategy.

 

3 strategies of distribution based on the number of intermediaries are – exclusive distribution, selective distribution, and intensive distribution.

 

Exclusive distribution means severely limiting the number of intermediaries. It’s appropriate when the producer wants to maintain control over the service level and outputs offered by the resellers, and it often includes exclusive dealing arrangements.

 

Selective distribution relies on only some of the intermediaries willing to carry a particular product. Whether established or new, the company does not need to worry about having too many outlets; it can gain adequate market coverage with more control and less cost than intensive distribution.

 

Intensive distribution places the goods or services in as many outlets as possible. This strategy serves well for snack foods, soft drinks, newspapers, candies, and gum—products consumers buy frequently or in a variety of locations.

Question 65
This system of distribution channel consists of producers, wholesaler and the retailers acting as a unified system. One channel member owns their other, has contracts with them or wields so much power that they must cooperate. Name this system of channel distribution -(UGC NET Management Jun 2020)
  • A.Convectional Distribution Channel
  • B.Vertical Marketing System (VMS)
  • C.Consumer Distribution System
  • D.National Marketing Distribution System
Correct Answer: Vertical Marketing System (VMS)

The correct answer is (B) Vertical Marketing System (VMS).

 

A Vertical Marketing System (VMS) is a distribution channel arrangement in which various entities within the distribution chain, including producers, wholesalers, and retailers, work together as a unified system. In a VMS, the channel members collaborate closely, often through ownership, contracts, or significant influence. This cooperative approach is aimed at maximizing the efficiency and effectiveness of the distribution process.

 

Unlike traditional distribution channels where each channel member operates independently, a VMS involves a higher degree of integration and coordination. This integration can result in improved supply chain management, better communication, and a streamlined flow of products from the manufacturer to the end consumer.

 

VMS can take different forms:

 

  • Corporate VMS: In this type, a single entity owns multiple levels of the distribution channel. For example, a manufacturer might own the wholesaler and retailer levels.
  • Contractual VMS: Here, independent entities at different levels of the distribution channel enter into contractual agreements to collaborate. This could involve franchises, retailer cooperatives, or distribution agreements.
  • Administered VMS: In this case, a dominant player in the channel wields significant power and influence over other members, encouraging their cooperation without formal ownership or contracts.

 

The Vertical Marketing System provides advantages such as better control over the distribution process, coordinated marketing efforts, and enhanced economies of scale. It can also create challenges related to power dynamics, potential conflicts of interest, and the need for effective communication and collaboration.

Question 66
Retailer cooperatives belong to which of the following distribution channel systems? (UGC NET Management June 2022)
  • A.Contractual
  • B.Administered
  • C.Horizontal
  • D.Corporate
Correct Answer: Contractual

Retailer cooperatives belong to the (A) "Contractual" distribution channel system.

 

(A) Contractual: In a contractual distribution channel system, independent businesses (in this case, retailers) come together under a contractual agreement to work collaboratively. Retailer cooperatives are a prime example of this system. In a retailer cooperative, independent retailers pool their resources, such as purchasing power, marketing efforts, or distribution logistics, to achieve common goals. They enter into contracts or agreements to cooperate while retaining their individual ownership. This allows them to benefit from economies of scale and compete more effectively with larger retail chains.

 

(B) Administered: In an administered distribution channel system, one dominant member or entity holds significant power and control over the channel. This dominant member often dictates terms, policies, and decisions within the channel, and other members follow suit. Retailer cooperatives, by contrast, involve collaboration among equals, where no single member dominates the group.

 

(C) Horizontal: A horizontal distribution channel system involves businesses at the same level of the distribution chain, such as competitors or businesses offering similar products or services, working together. Retailer cooperatives, on the other hand, often involve businesses at the retail level collaborating with each other and potentially with suppliers or manufacturers.

 

(D) Corporate: In a corporate distribution channel system, a single entity owns and controls all the stages of the distribution process, from manufacturing to retailing. Retailer cooperatives are characterized by independent retailers collaborating rather than being owned and controlled by a single corporate entity.

Quiz Attempt #119607

Total Questions: 41
Question 1
Match List I with II(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)List-I (Retail Store Format)A. DiscountB. SpecialtyC. Category KillerD. Super marketerList-II (Product assortment)I. Very narrow and deepII. Broad and shallowIII. Broad and deepIV. Narrow and very deepChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A-II, B-I, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • C.A-IV, B-II, C-III, D-I
  • D.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
Correct Answer: A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III

The correct answer is option B – A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV.

 

The provided options match different types of retail store formats with their corresponding product assortments. Let's match them correctly:

 

A. Discount (Retail Store Format) - I. Very narrow and deep (Product assortment)

Discount stores typically focus on offering a limited selection of products at lower prices.

 

B. Specialty (Retail Store Format) - II. Broad and shallow (Product assortment)

Specialty stores focus on a specific category or type of product, offering a wide variety of choices within that category.

 

C. Category Killer (Retail Store Format) - III. Broad and deep (Product assortment)

Category Killer stores are specialized retailers that offer a vast selection within a particular product category, often aiming to dominate that category.

 

D. Supermarket (Retail Store Format) - IV. Narrow and very deep (Product assortment)

Supermarkets offer a broad range of products across different categories, creating a deep assortment within each category.

Question 2
‘A furnishing retailer company opens a new generation of furniture galleries that are part store, part interior design studio and part restaurant’.(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)This is an example of which of the following?
  • A.Franchise Retailing
  • B.Experiential Retailing
  • C.Departmental Store Retailing
  • D.Mega Retailing
Correct Answer: Experiential Retailing

Experiential Retailing - This focuses on creating an engaging and interactive experience for customers, often going beyond just selling products. The furniture gallery described fits this perfectly, combining shopping with design consultation and dining.

Question 3
Which of the following is a type of off-price retailer?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)
  • A.Super store
  • B.Category killer
  • C.Factory outlet
  • D.Discount store
Correct Answer: Factory outlet

A factory outlet is a type of off-price retailer that sells products directly from the manufacturer, typically at a discount. These stores often offer surplus stock, discontinued items, or products with minor imperfections.

 

Super store (A) refers to a large retail store that sells a wide variety of products, including groceries and household goods.

 

Category killer (B) is a retail chain that specializes in a particular product category, often dominating that market (e.g., a large electronics store).

 

Discount store (D) generally refers to retailers that sell goods at lower prices, but they are not classified as off-price retailers in the same sense as factory outlets.

 

Therefore, the correct type of off-price retailer from the options provided is (C) Factory outlet.

Question 4
Identify the most important type of retail stores: - (UGC NET Management Jun 2020)a. Convenienceb. Online storec. Departmental storesd. Direct selling storese. SuperstoreChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.a, c and e only
  • C.b, c and d only
  • D.a, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, c and e only

Among the provided options, the most important type of retail stores can be identified as follows:

 

a. Convenience Stores: Convenience stores are small retail outlets that offer a limited variety of everyday items, such as snacks, beverages, toiletries, and basic groceries. They are designed for quick and easy shopping, often located in easily accessible locations. Convenience stores are crucial for providing essential items to customers on-the-go.

 

c. Departmental Stores: Department stores are large retail establishments that offer a wide range of products across various categories, such as clothing, accessories, home goods, cosmetics, and electronics. They provide a one-stop shopping experience and attract customers looking for a variety of items under one roof.

 

e. Superstores: Superstores are retail stores that combine the characteristics of a supermarket and a department store. They offer an extensive range of products, including groceries, clothing, electronics, home goods, and more. Superstores aim to fulfill diverse shopping needs and provide convenience to customers.

 

Hence, the correct answer is (B) a, c and e only, as convenience stores, departmental stores, and superstores play significant roles in the retail industry by catering to different customer needs and preferences.

Question 5
Modern organized retail business has a multitude of formats. These formats can be classified according to the following: (UGC NET Management Dec 2019)
  • A.Merchandise offered only
  • B.Size of store area only
  • C.Customer groups only
  • D.Merchandise offered and size of the store area
Correct Answer: Merchandise offered and size of the store area

In the context of modern organized retail business, the classification of different retail formats is a crucial consideration for effectively targeting specific customer segments and optimizing store operations. Among the various classification criteria, the question revolves around categorizing these formats based on "Merchandise offered" and the "size of the store area."

 

The correct answer is (D) Merchandise offered and size of the store area.

 

This option combines two significant factors in classifying retail formats. "Merchandise offered" refers to the type of products and goods the store sells, which can vary from groceries to electronics, fashion, or specialty items. The "size of the store area" refers to the physical space occupied by the retail store, which can range from small convenience stores to large hypermarkets. By combining both merchandise and store size, this classification approach provides a comprehensive way to differentiate various retail formats, considering both the products sold and the scale of operations. This is a more holistic approach compared to considering either merchandise or store size alone.

 

The other options (A, B, and C) consider only a single factor for classification, which does not capture the full complexity of modern retail formats. Therefore, option (D) is the correct choice as it offers a more accurate and detailed way of categorizing the diverse retail formats in the organized retail business landscape.

Question 6
The strategic issues to which a retailing firm has to respond are: (UGC NET Management Dec 2019)(a) Location decisions(b) Brand building decisions(c) Merchandise mix decisions(d) Target market sectionWhich of the following option is correct?
  • A.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • B.(a) and (c) only
  • C.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
  • D.(a), (c) and (d) only
Correct Answer: (a), (c) and (d) only

The correct option is (D) (a), (c), and (d) only.

 

(a) Location decisions: Retail firms need to make strategic decisions about where they should locate their stores. The choice of location can significantly impact the store's visibility, accessibility to the target market, and overall success.

 

(c) Merchandise mix decisions: Determining the right mix of products or merchandise to offer is a critical strategic decision for retail firms. They must consider factors like customer preferences, market trends, competition, and pricing to create an appealing assortment of products.

 

(d) Target market selection: Identifying and selecting the appropriate target market is a fundamental strategic decision for retailers. Understanding the specific demographics, psychographics, and buying behaviors of their target audience helps in tailoring marketing efforts and product offerings.

 

So, the correct option is (D), which includes location decisions, merchandise mix decisions, and target market selection as the strategic issues to which a retailing firm has to respond.

Question 7
Fine Speciality store falls into [UGC NET Management June 2019]
  • A.High-mark up, lower volume group
  • B.High-mark up, higher volume group
  • C.Low-mark up;lower volume group
  • D.Low-mark up; higher volume group
Correct Answer: High-mark up, lower volume group

A "Fine Specialty Store" typically falls into the category of (A) "High-mark up, lower volume group."

 

(A) High-mark up, lower volume group: Fine specialty stores often carry high-quality, niche, or luxury products that come with a higher price tag. Due to the exclusivity and premium nature of their products, these stores can afford to charge a significant markup (profit margin) on each item they sell. However, because these products cater to a specific, often affluent, and discerning customer base, the volume of sales is relatively lower compared to stores that sell more mainstream or lower-priced items.

 

In the context of fine specialty stores, this means that they have a smaller customer base willing to pay a premium for unique and high-quality products, resulting in higher profit margins (markup) per sale but lower sales volume due to the specialized nature of their offerings.

 

The other options (B, C, and D) don't typically apply to fine specialty stores:

 

(B) High-mark up, higher volume group: This category may apply to stores that offer high-priced products in higher volumes, but fine specialty stores are often more focused on exclusivity and quality rather than high sales volumes.

 

(C) Low-mark up; lower volume group: This category suggests lower profit margins and lower sales volumes. Fine specialty stores are known for higher profit margins due to the premium nature of their products.

 

(D) Low-mark up, higher volume group: This category typically refers to businesses that rely on high sales volumes with lower profit margins. Fine specialty stores, as mentioned earlier, usually focus on higher markups to justify the premium quality of their products.

 

So, the correct classification for a "Fine Specialty Store" is (A) "High-mark up, lower volume group."

Question 8
Huge stores that combine supermarket, discount and warehouse retailing are called: (UGC NET Management June 2022)
  • A.Discount store
  • B.Category killer
  • C.Hyper market
  • D.Off price retailer
Correct Answer: Hyper market

The correct answer is (C) Hypermarket.

 

Hypermarkets are expansive retail establishments that amalgamate the characteristics of supermarkets, discount stores, and warehouse retailers. They boast an extensive array of merchandise, including groceries, household essentials, apparel, electronics, and more. Hypermarkets are recognized for their substantial size and diverse product selection, frequently featuring both nationally recognized brands and store-brand products.

 

Discount Store: Discount stores primarily prioritize providing goods at prices lower than those found in conventional retail outlets. However, they may not encompass the comprehensive blend of features present in a hypermarket.

 

Category Killer: Category killers are retail stores that specialize in a particular product category and seek to dominate that category by offering an expansive range of products within it. They do not inherently encompass the amalgamation of attributes found in a hypermarket.

 

Off-Price Retailer: Off-price retailers supply products at prices lower than standard retail prices, typically by procuring surplus inventory or discontinued merchandise from other retailers or manufacturers. Their focus is typically on discounted branded merchandise and may not include the diverse product categories associated with a hypermarket.

Question 9
Which one of the following types of retailers is “D Mart”? (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)
  • A.Discount store
  • B.Convenience store
  • C.Super market
  • D.Catalogue store
Correct Answer: Super market

"D Mart" is a type of retailer categorized as a Supermarket. Supermarkets are larger retail stores that offer a wide variety of food and non-food products, including groceries, household items, and sometimes apparel and electronics. They often focus on providing customers with a convenient and comprehensive shopping experience.

 

(A) Discount store: Discount stores primarily focus on offering products at lower prices than traditional retail stores. They often feature a wide range of products but emphasize cost savings. D Mart, while it may offer discounts, is more aligned with the characteristics of a supermarket.

 

(B) Convenience store: Convenience stores are typically small retail outlets that emphasize convenience for customers by offering a limited selection of essential items and extended operating hours. D Mart is larger and offers a broader range of products compared to a convenience store.

 

(D) Catalogue store: Catalogue stores primarily operate through mail-order catalogs or online platforms, allowing customers to browse and purchase products from a catalog. D Mart is a physical brick-and-mortar retailer with physical store locations, not a catalog-based store.

Question 10
Which type of retailers involve in comparatively low prices as a major selling point combined with the reduced costs of doing business? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Convenience stores
  • B.Discount retailers
  • C.Limited line retailers
  • D.Category killer stores
Correct Answer: Discount retailers

The correct answer is (B) Discount retailers.

 

Discount retailers are the type of retailers that emphasize comparatively low prices as a major selling point, often achieved through reducing the costs of doing business. They typically offer products at discounted prices compared to traditional retail outlets. These retailers focus on providing value to customers by minimizing operating expenses and passing the savings on to consumers in the form of lower prices. Examples of discount retailers include stores like Walmart, Target, and Dollar General, which are known for offering a wide range of products at competitive prices.

Question 11
Which type of retail stores generally has the highest operating costs? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Department store
  • B.Supermarket
  • C.Chain store
  • D.Co-operative Store
Correct Answer: Department store

Department stores generally have the highest operating costs among the options listed.

 

Department stores typically offer a wide variety of products and services, including clothing, home goods, electronics, and more, often within a multi-level store. They have higher operating costs due to factors such as maintaining a large physical space, a broad range of inventory, a large staff, and the need for extensive marketing and advertising efforts to attract customers. These factors contribute to their relatively higher operating expenses compared to other types of retail stores like supermarkets, chain stores, or co-operative stores.

Question 12
Which out of the following is not a type of non-store retailing? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2009)
  • A.Limited line stores
  • B.Automatic vending
  • C.Direct selling
  • D.Telemarketing
Correct Answer: Limited line stores

Limited line stores are not a type of non-store retailing.

 

Non-store retailing methods include automatic vending, direct selling, and telemarketing, all of which involve selling products or services without the traditional brick-and-mortar store format. Limited line stores, on the other hand, typically refer to physical retail stores that specialize in a limited range of products or product lines, and they are not considered a form of non-store retailing.

Question 13
Which one of the following is an example of non-store retailing? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2009)
  • A.Limited Line Stores
  • B.Discount Stores
  • C.Tele Marketing
  • D.Super Markets
Correct Answer: Tele Marketing

The correct example of non-store retailing from the options provided is (C) Tele Marketing.

 

Non-store retailing refers to retail methods that do not involve traditional physical stores. Tele marketing involves selling products or services over the telephone, making it a form of non-store retailing. This method allows businesses to reach customers directly through phone calls and offer products or services without the need for a physical store location.

Question 14
Choose the correct Statement(s) among the following.Statement I:Department store is a store that carries several Product lines- typically clothing, home furnishings and household goods.Statement II:Supermarket is a large, low cost, low margin, high volume, self-service operation designed to serve the consumer’s total needs for grocery and household productsCodes
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect.
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct.
  • C.Statement I and Statement II both are incorrect.
  • D.Statement I and Statement II both are correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I and Statement II both are correct.

. The correct answer is (D) Statement I and Statement II both are correct.

 

Statement I: Department store is a store that carries several product lines - typically clothing, home furnishings, and household goods.

This statement is correct. A department store is a type of retail store that offers a wide variety of product lines or categories within a single establishment. These product lines often include clothing, home furnishings, household goods, cosmetics, electronics, and more. Department stores are known for their diverse product offerings, making them a one-stop shopping destination for consumers seeking a range of items.

 

Statement II: Supermarket is a large, low-cost, low-margin, high-volume, self-service operation designed to serve the consumer’s total needs for grocery and household products.

This statement is also correct. A supermarket is a large retail store specializing in the sale of groceries and various household products. Supermarkets are characterized by their focus on high volume and low margins, which means they sell products at relatively low prices with a narrow profit margin per item. They are typically self-service stores where customers can select products from shelves and pay at the checkout.

Question 15
Which one of the following types of retailers is “D Mart”?
  • A.Discount store
  • B.Convenience store
  • C.Supermarket
  • D.Catalogue store
Correct Answer: Supermarket

D Mart is a well-known retail chain in India, and it falls into the category of a supermarket. Supermarkets are large retail stores that offer a wide variety of products, including groceries, fresh produce, household items, clothing, electronics, and more, all under one roof. These stores are designed to provide customers with a convenient and comprehensive shopping experience.

Question 16
A type of wholesaler who does not carry inventory or handle products and on receiving order, they simply select manufacturer who then ships the merchandise directly to the consumer is referred to as:
  • A.Drop shippers
  • B.Rack jobbers
  • C.Truck jobbers
  • D.Producers’ cooperatives
Correct Answer: Drop shippers

The correct answer is (A) Drop shippers.

 

Following are the different types of wholesalers:

 

a) Full-service wholesalers - Provide a full line of services: carrying stock, maintaining a sales force, offering credit, making deliveries, and providing management assistance. Full-service wholesalers include wholesale merchants and industrial distributors. 

 

b) Wholesale merchants - Sell primarily to retailers and provide a full range of services. General merchandise wholesalers carry several merchandise lines, whereas general line wholesalers carry one or two lines in great depth. Specialty wholesalers specialize in carrying only part of a line.

 

c) Industrial distributors - Sell to manufacturers rather than to retailers. Provide several services, such as carrying stock, offering credit, and providing delivery. May carry a broad range of merchandise, a general line, or a specialty line.

 

d) Limited-service wholesalers - Offer fewer services than full-service wholesalers. Limited-service wholesalers are of several types:

1. Drop Shippers - Do not carry inventory or handle the product. On receiving an order, drop shippers select a manufacturer, who then ships the merchandise directly to the customer. Drop shippers operate in bulk industries, such as coal, lumber, and heavy equipment. In India, IndiaMart is an example of a drop shipper type wholesaler.

2. Truck wholesalers (or truck jobbers) - Perform primarily a selling and delivery function.
