Carry a limited line of semi perishable merchandise (such as milk, bread, snack foods), which is sold for cash as deliveries are made to supermarkets, small groceries, hospitals, restaurants, factory cafeterias, and hotels.

3. Rack jobbers - Serve grocery and drug retailers, mostly in nonfood items. Rack jobbers send delivery trucks to stores, where the delivery people set up toys, paperbacks, hardware items, health and beauty aids, or other items. Rack jobbers price the goods, keep them fresh, set up point-of-purchase displays, and keep inventory records.

4. Producers’ cooperatives - Farmer-owned members that assemble farm produce for sale in local markets. Producers’ cooperatives often attempt to improve product quality and promote a co-op brand name, such as Sunkist oranges, Adani Farm-Pik.

5. Cash-and-carry wholesalers - Carry a limited line of fast-moving goods and sell to small retailers for cash. Normally do not deliver.

Question 17
Collection of activities for selling products directly to end user for non-business use is classified as:
  • A.Inter-Modeling
  • B.Distribution Operation
  • C.Wholesaling
  • D.Retailing
Correct Answer: Retailing

The correct answer is (D) Retailing.

 

Retailing refers to the collection of activities involved in selling products or services directly to the end-users (consumers) for their non-business use.Retailers are business that operate at the final stage of the distribution channel and provide goods or services to individual customers.

Question 18
Public Distribution System relates to (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.Marketing system
  • B.Retailing system
  • C.Industrial system
  • D.Selling system
Correct Answer: Retailing system

The Public Distribution System (PDS) is a government-sponsored program that involves a network of shops responsible for distributing essential food and non-food items to disadvantaged segments of society at subsidized prices. This system is a form of planned retailing and plays a crucial role in ensuring food security and reducing hunger among vulnerable population.The PDS is a cooperative effort between the central and the state governments. The central government handles procurement , storage, transportation, and bulk allocation of food grains, while state governments oversee the distribution process through Fair Shops(FPS). State government are also responsible for operational aspects, including identifying families below the poverty line, issuing ration cards, and monitoring the functioning of FPSs.

In essence, the Public Distribution System is a part of the retailing system and is designed to provide essential commodities to those in need at affordable prices.

Question 19
Which form of retail outlet has the highest operating costs? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Super market
  • B.Consumer co-operative store
  • C.Department store
  • D.Retail chain store
Correct Answer: Department store

The correct answer is (C) Department Store.

Department stores typically have higher operating costs compared to other forms of retail outlets.This is because department stores offer a wide range of products and services, often in large and elaborate physical spaces. They have higher expenses related to store maintanance employee, salaries , inventory management , advertising and overhead costs due to their size and the variety of products they carry.

In contrast, supermarkets, consumer co-operative stores, and retail chain stores may have lower operating costs because they often focus on specific products categories or have more streamlined operations.

Question 20
Non-Store Retailing includes:
  • A.Home selling
  • B.V.P.P.
  • C.Vending Machines
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Non-store retailing includes various methods of selling products or services to consumers without the need for a physical storefront. It encompasses a wide range of approaches to reach customers. The options provided in the question all fall under the category of non-store retailing:

 

(A) Home selling involves salespeople demonstrating and selling products directly to customers in their homes.

 

(B) V.P.P. stands for "Value Payable Post" and refers to a postal service where customers can pay for goods upon delivery. It is a non-store retailing method used for mail-order sales.

 

(C) Vending machines are automated machines that dispense products to customers after they insert money or make a payment.

Question 21
Match the following. (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)List - I (Type of store Retailers)(a) Specialty store(b) Drug store(c) Super store(d) Catalogue showroomList – II (Formats)(i) Broad selection of high-mark up, fast moving, brand name goods sold by a list(ii) Narrow product line(iii) Prescription and pharmacies(iv) Huge selling spaceCodes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii) b-(ii) c-(iv) d-(i)
  • D.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i)

The correct match of types of store retailers with their respective formats is as follows:

Specialty store: Narrow product line

Drug store: Prescription and pharmacies

Super store: Broad selection of high-markup, fast-moving, brand-name goods sold by a list

Catalogue showroom: Huge selling space

 

Catalogue showrooms: Catalogue retailers are those where the customer comes and places the order through a catalogue of the product/s that he would like to buy and then arrangement is done to bring the product from the warehouse for purchase by the customer. It usually consists of high mark up and fast moving branded goods.

 

Specialty stores: A specialty store refers to a store that stores a particular type of merchandise or a single product of durable goods like furniture, household goods, consumer electronics etc. Such a business model is characterized by a high level of sender or product information being made available to customers.

 

Supermarkets: Supermarkets are usually characterized by large, low cost, low margin, high volume self-service market designed to meet the food and nonfood items need of the consumers. 

 

Superstores: A very large retail store which sells a vast variety of product lines ranging apparels, footwears, sports goods, electronic devices, computers, home appliances, food, cosmetics and many more. The major difference between a supermarket and a superstore is its size and the number of product lines that they sell. A superstore is always much bigger than a supermarket and sells more number of product lines. The examples of superstores are Wall mart, Hypercity etc.

 

Drug store: A store that sells health care products and medicine. Customers can buy both over-the-counter and prescription medication at a drug store. It is not uncommon for drug stores to carry other frequently used household products and merchandise.

 

So, the correct match is (D) a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i).

Question 22
In which one of the following types of store retailers, large, low-cost, low margin, high-volume, self-service store attributes are designed to meet total needs for food and household products? (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.Supermarket
  • B.Superstore
  • C.Discount store
  • D.Convenience store
Correct Answer: Supermarket

The correct answer is (A) Supermarket.

A supermarket is a type of store retailer characterized by its large size, low-cost operations, low profit margins, high volume of sales, and a wide range of products, particularly food and household items. Supermarkets are designed to meet the total needs of consumers when it comes to grocery shopping and other essential household products.

Question 23
All the activities involved in selling goods or services directly to final consumers for personal non-business uses are done by (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)
  • A.Wholesalers
  • B.Retailers
  • C.Mediators
  • D.Commission Agents
Correct Answer: Retailers

The correct answer is (B) Retailers.

 

Retailers are the entities or businesses that engage in the activities involved in selling goods or services directly to final consumers for their personal, non-business use. They play a critical role in the distribution channel by making products accessible to consumers through various channels, such as physical stores, online platforms, or other means.

 

Wholesalers, mediators, and commission agents are different types of intermediaries within the distribution channel, but they are not primarily engaged in selling goods or services directly to final consumers. Instead, they may facilitate the distribution process by buying products from manufacturers and selling them to retailers or other businesses.

Question 24
A concept in retailing that helps explain the emergence of new retailers is called the ________ hypothesis. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Product Life Cycle
  • B.Service Assortment
  • C.Retail Life Cycle
  • D.Wheel-of-Retailing
Correct Answer: Wheel-of-Retailing

The concept in retailing that helps explain the emergence of new retailers is called the "Wheel-of-Retailing" hypothesis. This hypothesis suggests that new retailers often enter the market as low-cost, low-price operators with limited service and product offerings. Over time, as they gain market share and customer loyalty, they may add more services, expand their product assortment, and increase prices. This gradual transformation resembles the movement of a wheel, hence the name "Wheel-of-Retailing."

Question 25
Given below are 2 statements - one is labeled as Assertion and the other is labeled as Reason.Assertion “A”:For Retailing to be happened, it matters how or where the goods or services are sold.Reason “R”:A retail store is any business enterprise whose sales volume comes primarily from retailing.
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: A is incorrect but R is correct

In this case, the Assertion "A" is incorrect, and the Reason "R" is correct.

 

Assertion "A": "For Retailing to be happened, it matters how or where the goods or services are sold."

This assertion suggests that the success of retailing depends on how and where products are sold. However, this statement is not accurate. Retailing primarily focuses on the sale of goods or services to the end consumer, regardless of the specific method or location of the sale. Retailers can operate in physical stores, online, or through various other channels, but what defines them as retailers is their role in selling to individual consumers.

 

Reason "R": "A retail store is any business enterprise whose sales volume comes primarily from retailing."

This reason correctly defines a retail store. It states that a retail store is a business where the majority of sales come from retailing activities, which involve selling products directly to consumers. This is a valid and accurate statement about the nature of retail businesses.

Question 26
Match the following.List I (Retailing Services)(a) Self-service(b) Self-selection(c) Limited Service(d) Full ServiceList II (Aspect)(i) Credit and merchandise-return privileges.(ii) Locate-compare-select.(iii) Customers find their own goods.(iv) Customers who like to be waited on prefer this type of store.Choose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)

The correct answer is option (B) a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv).

 

(a) Self-service with (ii) Locate-compare-select

Self-service is a retailing service where customers are responsible for finding and selecting products themselves. They typically browse through the store, locate the items they need, compare different options, and make their selections independently. The aspect "Locate-compare-select" perfectly describes the nature of self-service, where customers have the freedom to explore products and make choices based on their preferences.

 

(b) Self-selection with (iii) Customers find their own goods

Self-selection is another term used to describe the retail service where customers independently find and pick the items they want to purchase. This aligns with the aspect "Customers find their own goods" because it highlights the role of customers in selecting products from the store's shelves or displays based on their preferences.

 

(c) Limited Service with (i) Credit and merchandise-return privileges

Limited service in retailing often refers to a middle-ground between self-service and full service. It may include some customer assistance, but it is not as extensive as full service. The aspect "Credit and merchandise-return privileges" relates to the idea that limited-service retailers may offer certain conveniences like facilitating returns or providing credit options to customers while not offering full-service assistance.

 

(d) Full Service with (iv) Customers who like to be waited on prefer this type of store

Full-service retailers offer a high level of assistance and customer support. They cater to customers who prefer personalized assistance and guidance in their shopping experience. The aspect "Customers who like to be waited on prefer this type of store" accurately represents full-service retail establishments where knowledgeable staff attend to customers' needs, answer questions, and provide a more hands-on shopping experience.

 

So, the matches are as follows:

 

Self-service (a) corresponds to "locate-compare-select" aspect (ii).

Self-selection (b) corresponds to the customers finding their own goods (iii).

Limited Service (c) corresponds to offering credit and merchandise-return privileges (i).

Full Service (d) corresponds to customers who prefer to be waited on (iv).

 

These matches help explain the various types of retailing services and their associated aspects or characteristics.

Question 27
Match the following.List I (Non-store Retailing)(a) Direct Selling(b) Direct Marketing(c) Automatic Vending(d) Buying ServiceList II (Description)(i) Include impulsive goods(ii) Storeless retailer serving a specific clientele.(iii) Network Marketing(iv) E-Commerce firmsCodes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)

The correct answer is (D) a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii).

 

(a) Direct Selling with (iii) Network Marketing

Direct selling is a retail strategy where products or services are sold directly to consumers typically through a network of individual sellers. Network Marketing, also known as multi-level marketing (MLM), is a specific form of direct selling. In network marketing, individuals not only sell products but also recruit others to become sellers, building a network or downline. These recruits can, in turn, recruit others, and so on. Network marketing emphasizes team-building and often involves a commission-based compensation plan. This form of direct selling is characterized by a structured network or hierarchy of sellers.

 

(b) Direct Marketing with (iv) E-Commerce firms

Direct marketing is a marketing strategy where companies communicate and promote their products or services directly to consumers, often using channels like mail, email, telemarketing, or online advertising. E-Commerce firms align closely with direct marketing because they sell products or services directly to consumers through online platforms, eliminating the need for physical stores. Direct marketing techniques are often used in online advertising and email marketing to reach and engage potential customers, making it a suitable match for e-commerce businesses.

 

(c) Automatic Vending with (i) Include impulsive goods

Automatic vending involves the use of vending machines that dispense products without the need for human assistance. These machines are commonly found in public places and dispense items like snacks, beverages, cigarettes, and other small products. "Include impulsive goods" fits well with automatic vending because vending machines are strategically placed in locations where people may make impulsive purchases, such as grabbing a snack or drink while waiting in a public area.

 

(d) Buying Service with (ii) Storeless retailer serving a specific clientele

Buying services are a type of non-store retailing where intermediaries help consumers purchase products or services tailored to their specific needs. These services often cater to a particular clientele, such as businesses or individuals seeking specialized items. The description "Storeless retailer serving a specific clientele" aligns with buying services because they provide a personalized shopping experience without the need for a physical store. Buying services help customers locate and purchase unique or hard-to-find items, making them a valuable resource for niche markets.

These matches illustrate how different forms of non-store retailing cater to distinct consumer preferences and market segments, offering diverse retail experiences to meet various needs.

Question 28
Given below are 2 statements - one is labeled as Assertion and the other is labeled as Reason.Assertion “A”Franchising benefits both franchisor and franchisee.Reason “R”:Franchisees gain the motivation employees who are entrepreneurs rather than “hired hands,” whereas Franchisors benefit from buying into a business with a well-known and accepted brand name.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: A is correct but R is incorrect

The correct option is (C) A is correct but R is incorrect.

 

The assertion that franchising benefits both franchisors and franchisees is generally true. Franchising offers benefits to both parties. Franchisees gain the advantage of operating a business with an established brand name, proven business model, and ongoing support from the franchisor. They have the opportunity to run their own business and potentially earn higher profits than they might as employees. Franchisees are often motivated entrepreneurs who are invested in the success of their business.

 

However, the reason provided in statement "R" is not entirely accurate. It suggests that franchisees are motivated employees, which is not the case. Franchisees are not employees; they are independent business owners who have purchased the right to operate a business under the franchisor's brand and guidance. They are not "hired hands." Instead, they are individuals who have made a financial investment in the franchise.

Question 29
Given below are two statements - one is labeled as Assertion and the other is labeled as Reason.Assertion “A”:The retailer’s product assortment must match the target market’s shopping expectations in breadth and depth.Reason “R”:A restaurant can offer a narrow and shallow assortment (small lunch counters), a narrow and deep assortment (delicatessen), a broad and shallow assortment (cafeteria), or a broad and deep assortment (large restaurant).In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

The correct option is (A) Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion "A" states that the retailer's product assortment must match the target market's shopping expectations in breadth and depth. This means that the range and variety of products offered by a retailer should align with what the target customers expect when they shop at that retailer. This assertion is correct.

 

Reason "R" provides an explanation for why the retailer's product assortment should match customer expectations. It uses the example of a restaurant to illustrate that a restaurant can offer various assortments based on breadth (range of food types) and depth (variety within each food type). This explanation reinforces the idea that the retailer's product assortment should align with customer expectations.

Question 30
___________ is a way of measuring a product’s handling costs from the time it reaches the warehouse until a customer buys it in the retail store
  • A.Direct Product Profitability
  • B.Cost Benefit Analysis
  • C.High mark-up margins
  • D.Low mark-up margins
Correct Answer: Direct Product Profitability

The correct answer is (A) Direct Product Profitability.

 

Direct Product Profitability (DPP) is a method used to measure a product's handling costs and profitability from the time it reaches the warehouse until a customer buys it in the retail store. DPP takes into account various costs associated with a product, including transportation, storage, handling, and any other expenses related to getting the product to the point of sale. It helps retailers assess the profitability of individual products and make decisions about pricing, stocking, and promotions based on their impact on overall profitability.

Question 31
Identify correct statement.Statement I:All retailers would like high turns × earns (high volumes and high gross margins), but the two don’t usually go together.Statement II:Most retailers fall into the high-markup, lower-volume group (mass merchandisers) or the low-markup, higher-volume group (specialty stores).
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect

The correct answer is (C) Statement I is correct, and Statement II is incorrect.

 

Statement I: All retailers would like high turns × earns (high volumes and high gross margins), but the two don’t usually go together.

This statement is correct. Retailers typically aim for high sales volumes (high turnover) and high gross margins, but it can be challenging to achieve both simultaneously. Often, retailers have to strike a balance between the two.

 

Statement II: Most retailers fall into the high-markup, lower-volume group (mass merchandisers) or the low-markup, higher-volume group (specialty stores).

This statement is incorrect. Mass merchandisers are known for offering low prices and high volumes, while specialty stores often have higher markups but lower sales volumes due to their specialized product offerings. So, the statement has reversed the characteristics of these two types of retailers.

Question 32
Match the following.List I (Retailer Services)(a) Pre-purchase services(b) Post-purchase services(c) Ancillary servicesList II (Association)(i) Repairing(ii) Alterations and tailoring(iii) Interior DisplayCodes
  • A.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(ii)
  • B.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)
  • D.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)

The correct answer is (C) a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i).

 

(a) Pre-purchase services - Interior Display

Pre-purchase services are services provided to customers before they make a purchase. Interior display refers to how a retailer showcases its products in the store to attract and engage customers before they decide to buy.

 

(b) Post-purchase services - Alterations and tailoring

Post-purchase services are services provided to customers after they have made a purchase. Alterations and tailoring fall under post-purchase services because they involve making adjustments to the purchased clothing to ensure a proper fit for the customer.

 

(c) Ancillary services - Repairing

Ancillary services are additional services that a retailer may offer to enhance the overall shopping experience. Repairing is an example of an ancillary service because it involves fixing or repairing products that customers may have purchased from the retailer.

Question 33
Identify correct statement.Statement I:The key to retail success are often said to be “location."Statement II:Retailers must decide on the most advantageous locations in view of the relationship between high traffic and high rents.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (A) Statement I is correct, and Statement II is correct.

 

Statement I is correct because "location" is indeed a key factor in the success of many retail businesses. The choice of a store's location can significantly impact its visibility, accessibility to customers, and overall sales potential.

 

Statement II is also correct because retailers must carefully consider the trade-off between high traffic (which can lead to more customers and higher sales) and high rents (which can increase operating costs). Finding the right balance between these factors is crucial in selecting the most advantageous location for a retail store.

Question 34
A brand that retailers and wholesalers develop is called
  • A.Private label brand
  • B.Distributor brand
  • C.Reseller brand
  • D.All of the Above
Correct Answer: All of the Above

The correct answer is (D) All of the Above.

 

A Private label brand (also called a reseller, store, house, or distributor brand) is a brand that retailers and wholesalers develop. For example, Benetton, The Body Shop, and Marks & Spencer carry mostly own-brand merchandise.

 

Intermediaries sponsor these private label brands because these brands can be more profitable. They search for manufacturers with excess capacity that will produce private label goods at low cost. Other costs, such as research and development, advertising, sales promotion, and physical distribution, are also much lower, so private labels can generate a higher profit margin. Retailers also develop exclusive store brands to differentiate themselves from competitors. Many price-sensitive consumers prefer store brands in certain categories. These preferences give retailers increased bargaining power with marketers of national brands.

 

Private label or store brands should be distinguished from generics. Generics are unbranded, plainly packaged, less expensive versions of common products such as spaghetti, paper towels, and canned peaches. They offer standard or lower quality at a price that may be as much as 20 percent to 40 percent lower than nationally advertised brands. The lower price is made possible by lower-cost labeling and packaging and minimal advertising, and sometimes lower-quality ingredients. Generics can be found in a wide range of different products, even medicines.

 

Slotting Fees: In the confrontation between manufacturers and private labels, retailers have many advantages and increasing market power. Because shelf space is scarce, many supermarkets charge a slotting fee for accepting a new brand, to cover the cost of listing and stocking it. Retailers also charge for special display space and in-store advertising space. They typically give more prominent display to their own brands and make sure they are well stocked.

Question 35
Given below are 2 statements - one is labeled as Assertion and the other is labeled as Reason.Assertion “A”:Wholesalers differ from retailers in a number of ways.Reason “R”:Wholesalers pay less attention to promotion, atmosphere, and location, their transactions are larger and are regulated differently.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

The correct answer is (A) Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion (A): Wholesalers differ from retailers in a number of ways.

This assertion is correct. Wholesalers and retailers have distinct roles and functions within the distribution channel. Wholesalers primarily act as intermediaries between manufacturers or producers and retailers. They purchase products in large quantities from manufacturers and then distribute these products to retailers, who, in turn, sell them to end consumers. Wholesalers focus on facilitating the movement of goods efficiently and at scale, often dealing with bulk quantities.

 

Reason (R): Wholesalers pay less attention to promotion, atmosphere, and location; their transactions are larger and are regulated differently.

This reason is also correct and provides an explanation for why wholesalers and retailers differ. Wholesalers typically pay less attention to factors such as promotion (advertising and marketing to end consumers), store atmosphere (as they don't operate physical stores for consumers), and location (since they serve a B2B market). Their primary concern is to handle large-scale transactions efficiently, and they may operate in a business-to-business (B2B) environment.

Question 36
The concept which states that new retailers begin as low price and low margin retailers and then covert into high priced retailers they have replaced is called
  • A.Wheel of Mega Retailers Concept
  • B.Wheel of Retailing Concept
  • C.Cycle of Retailers Concept
  • D.Retailers Discount Concept
Correct Answer: Wheel of Retailing Concept

The correct answer is (B) Wheel of Retailing Concept.

 

The Wheel of Retailing is a concept in retail management that describes how retail firms evolve and change over time. According to this concept, new retailers typically start as low-price, low-margin establishments with a limited range of products and services. Over time, as they gain experience and customer recognition, they tend to upgrade their offerings and facilities, which often results in higher prices and margins.

Question 37
Statement I:A form of non-store retailing that uses advertising to contact consumers who, in turn, purchase products without visiting a retail store is called Direct Selling. (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)Statement II:A form of non-store retailing in which personal contact between a sales person and a consumer occurs away from a retail store is called Direct Marketing.In the light of above statements, identify the correct code of statements being correct or incorrect.
  • A.Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.
  • B.Statement I is not correct but Statement II is correct.
  • C.Both the statements are correct.
  • D.Both the statements are not correct.
Correct Answer: Both the statements are not correct.

Direct selling refers to selling products directly to the consumer in a non-retail environment. Instead, sales occur at home, work, or other non-store location. This system often eliminates several of the middlemen involved in product distribution, such as the regional distribution center and wholesaler. Instead, products go from manufacturer to the direct sales company, to the distributor or representative, and to the consumer. 

 

Direct Marketing – Direct communications with carefully targeted individual consumers to obtain an immediate response and cultivate lasting customer relationships is called as direct marketing.

Hence, both the given statements are incorrect.

Question 38
____________ not only communicates features and benefits but also connects a product or service with unique and interesting experiences.
  • A.Door-to-door marketing
  • B.Experiential marketing
  • C.Influential marketing
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Experiential marketing

A large part of local, grassroots marketing is Experiential marketing, which not only communicates features and benefits but also connects a product or service with unique and interesting experiences. “The idea is not to sell something, but to demonstrate how a brand can enrich a customer’s life.”

Question 39
“An outlet which starts as a general retailer grows into a specialized retailer and in course of time becomes even a bigger general retailer.”Above statement corresponds to which of the following theory of Retail? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)
  • A.Wheel of Retailing Theory
  • B.Retail Accordian Theory
  • C.Theory of Natural Selling
  • D.Retail Life Cycle Theory
Correct Answer: Retail Accordian Theory

Retail accordion theory was developed to explain the way retailers choose the number and type of product categories they would retail, with the hypothesis that firms would go through a cycle of from general goods, towards more specific products, and then back to general goods again.

 

In the initial stages of setting up, and the early stages of retail, the retail stores would carry a wide range of products to satisfy different consumer category needs. As the retail environment grows there is an increased number of specialists attracting consumer attention. However, this trend of specialization may be shifted again to generalization as consumers may be attracted to convenience of different goods on one store, meaning specialist stores need to become more generalized to compete.

 

So, the given statement corresponds to Retail Accordian Theory.

Question 40
In the retail industry, a 'Category Killer' is referred to as: [UGC NET Management June 2021]
  • A.a multi‐category large discount store that is famous for its wide selection of products
  • B.a specialty store wedded to discounting and domination of a product category
  • C.a store in a residential area and offers all household goods and fresh groceries
  • D.a unique 24/7 store located on major highways and also located in fuel stations
Correct Answer: a specialty store wedded to discounting and domination of a product category

Category killer is a giant specialty store that carries a very deep assortment of a particular line. They are found in a wide range of categories, including electronics, home-improvement products, books, baby gear, toys, home goods, party goods, sporting goods, and even pet supplies.

Question 41
Once a company has appointed dealers, the main elements of dealer motivation then are:1. Territory of operation2. Trade discount3. Special incentives4. Effective communicationChoose the correct answer from the options given below: [UGC NET Management Jun 2021]Codes
  • A.1, 2 and 3 only
  • B.2, 3 and 4 only
  • C.1, 3 and 4 only
  • D.1 and 2 only
Correct Answer: 2, 3 and 4 only

In the context of managing a distribution network and ensuring effective dealer performance, the main elements of dealer motivation are outlined in the provided options. The correct answer is (B) 2, 3 and 4 only.

 

Territory of operation: Although not explicitly mentioned in the options, the territory of operation is a significant consideration when dealing with dealer motivation. Assigning a specific territory to dealers provides them with a defined area of responsibility, helping to avoid conflicts and enabling them to focus on their target market more effectively.

 

Trade discount: Trade discounts are reductions in the list price of products offered to dealers. These discounts incentivize dealers to purchase products in larger quantities and promote their sales within their respective territories. Trade discounts contribute to dealer profitability and encourage them to actively participate in promoting the company's products.

 

Special incentives: Special incentives are additional rewards or benefits offered to dealers to encourage specific behaviors or achievements. These incentives could include bonuses for meeting or exceeding sales targets, rewards for outstanding performance, or recognition for exceptional efforts. Special incentives motivate dealers to go beyond their regular efforts and contribute to overall sales growth.

 

Effective communication: Communication is crucial in maintaining a strong relationship between the company and its dealers. Providing dealers with clear, timely, and relevant information about products, promotions, marketing strategies, and any changes in policies helps them align their efforts with the company's goals. Effective communication ensures that dealers are well-informed and engaged in promoting the company's products.

Quiz Attempt #119608

Total Questions: 14
Question 1
Given below are two statements:(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)Statement I:The only purpose of logistics management is to coordinate activities of moving products from the factory to customers.Statement II:Logistics management is only the responsibility of marketing function.In the light of the above statements choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectbut Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectbut Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Statement I: "The only purpose of logistics management is to coordinate activities of moving products from the factory to customers."

This statement is incorrect. While coordinating the movement of products from the factory to customers is indeed a significant aspect of logistics management, it is not the only purpose. Logistics management involves a broader set of activities, including procurement, transportation, inventory management, warehousing, distribution, and more.

 

Statement II: "Logistics management is only the responsibility of marketing function."

This statement is incorrect. Logistics management is not the sole responsibility of the marketing function. It is a cross-functional activity that involves various departments within an organization, such as supply chain, operations, procurement, distribution, and more. Effective logistics management requires collaboration among different departments to ensure smooth and efficient movement of goods throughout the supply chain.

Question 2
Which of the following movement of products clearly defines the term “Inbound Logistics”?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)
  • A.Suppliers to company
  • B.Company to Reseller
  • C.Reseller to Customer
  • D.Customers to Suppliers
Correct Answer: Suppliers to company

Inbound logistics refers to the activities involved in receiving, storing, and distributing the raw materials or products that are coming into a company from suppliers. This includes all the processes related to managing the supply chain from suppliers to the organization.

 

Company to Reseller (B) refers to outbound logistics.

 

Reseller to Customer (C) also refers to outbound logistics.

 

Customers to Suppliers (D) does not fit the definition of inbound logistics.

Therefore, inbound logistics is best defined by option (A), i.e., the movement of products from Suppliers to company.

Question 3
In the recent years-the major gain in logistical efficiency have come from which one of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)
  • A.Advances in information Technology
  • B.Reduction in petroleum prices
  • C.Fast order processing
  • D.Increase in production of commercial vehicles
Correct Answer: Advances in information Technology

The correct answer is (A) Advances in Information Technology.

 

In recent years, major gains in logistical efficiency within the field of logistics and supply chain management have primarily come from advances in information technology. Technology has revolutionized logistics by providing sophisticated tools, software, and systems that enhance the efficiency, accuracy, and speed of operations. It has enabled better tracking, real-time monitoring, automation, data analytics, and streamlined communication throughout the entire logistics process. These advancements have significantly improved supply chain visibility, inventory management, order processing, transportation optimization, and overall operational efficiency.

Question 4
Market logistic planning has the following four steps. Arrange the steps in correct sequence (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)(a) Develop operational excellence in sales forecasting, warehouse management, transportation and material management(b) Select the best channel design and network strategy for reaching the customers(c) Implement the solution with the best information systems, equipment, policies and procedures(d) Decide on company’s value proposition to its customersSelect the correct option form those below:
  • A.a – b– c– d
  • B.d – b– a– c
  • C.d – b– c– a
  • D.d – c– b– a
Correct Answer: d – b– a– c

The correct sequence for market logistics planning steps is (B) d - b - a – c.

 

1. Decide on the company’s value proposition to its customers (d): This step involves determining the value that the company intends to provide to its customers, defining what sets the company apart and what benefits it offers to its target audience.

 

2. Select the best channel design and network strategy for reaching the customers (b): After deciding on the value proposition, the company determines the most effective channel design and network strategy to ensure that the value reaches the customers efficiently.

 

3. Develop operational excellence in sales forecasting, warehouse management, transportation, and material management (a): With the channel design and network strategy in place, the company focuses on enhancing operational efficiency in various aspects such as sales forecasting, warehouse management, transportation, and material management to ensure smooth processes.

 

4. Implement the solution with the best information systems, equipment, policies, and procedures (c): The final step involves implementing the chosen solution, which includes utilizing the best information systems, equipment, policies, and procedures to achieve the defined value proposition and operational excellence.

Question 5
Given below are two statements – one is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)Assertion A:If the firm is prepared to incur increased cost on transportation, it may be in a position to reduce its inventory costReasons R: As in such a case, the firm can use the fastest mode of transport and rush the goods/stocks to the desired warehouse, unmindful of the cost of transportationIn the context of the above two statements related to logistics management, which of the following options is correct
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true, but R is false
  • D.A is false, but R is true
Correct Answer: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

The correct answer is (B) Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion (A): If the firm is prepared to incur increased cost on transportation, it may be in a position to reduce its inventory cost.

This assertion is true. By opting for faster modes of transportation, a company can potentially reduce its inventory carrying costs. This is because goods reach their destination quickly, minimizing the time they spend in inventory storage, which can lead to cost savings.

 

Reason (R): As in such a case, the firm can use the fastest mode of transport and rush the goods/stocks to the desired warehouse, unmindful of the cost of transportation.

While this reason describes a scenario related to the assertion, it oversimplifies the relationship between transportation cost and inventory cost. Rushing goods to a desired warehouse without considering the cost of transportation is not a sustainable or efficient logistics strategy. Transportation costs must be considered and balanced with the objective of reducing inventory costs.

Question 6
Which of the following represents traditional logistics management approach? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)1. Independent inventory management efforts2. Minimize firm costs3. Amount of information sharing and monitoring limited to current processes4. Small breadth of supplier base to increase coordinationChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.1, 2 only
  • B.2, 3 only
  • C.1, 3, 4 only
  • D.2, 3, 4 only
Correct Answer: 1, 2 only

The correct answer is (A) 1, 2 only.

 

Independent inventory management efforts: In the traditional logistics management approach, each entity or department within the organization often manages its inventory independently without considering the broader supply chain perspective. This can lead to suboptimal inventory levels and increased holding costs.

 

Minimize firm costs: The traditional approach focuses on minimizing costs within the firm's operations without necessarily considering broader supply chain costs or collaboration with external partners.

Question 7
Which one is not an element of market logistics?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.Inventory
  • B.Order-processing
  • C.Warehousing
  • D.Supply chain management
Correct Answer: Supply chain management

Supply chain management (Option D) is not an element of market logistics.

 

Market logistics primarily involves the planning, implementation, and control of the flow and storage of goods and services within a marketing channel. The key elements of market logistics include:

 

(A) Inventory: Managing and controlling the levels of inventory to ensure product availability and minimize excess or shortage.

 

(B) Order-processing: Handling customer orders efficiently, including order entry, order picking, packing, and order delivery.

 

(C) Warehousing: The physical storage and management of products in warehouses or distribution centers.

Question 8
Which one of the following is NOT included in the distribution logistics? (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.Order processing
  • B.Inventory
  • C.Warehousing
  • D.Wholesaler
Correct Answer: Wholesaler

Distribution logistics, also known as physical distribution, focuses on the management and flow of goods from the manufacturer or producer to the end consumer. It involves various activities and functions to ensure that products are efficiently and effectively delivered to the target market. The options you provided can be categorized as follows:

 

(A) Order Processing: This involves the activities related to receiving, verifying, and processing customer orders. It includes tasks such as order entry, order confirmation, and order tracking.

 

(B) Inventory: Inventory management is a critical component of distribution logistics. It includes activities related to the storage, tracking, and control of products to ensure that the right quantity of goods is available when needed.

 

(C) Warehousing: Warehousing involves the storage of goods in facilities or warehouses. It includes functions such as receiving, storing, picking, packing, and shipping products to customers.

 

(D) Wholesaler: A wholesaler is not a component of distribution logistics but rather a type of intermediary in the distribution process. Wholesalers purchase goods from manufacturers or producers and sell them to retailers or other businesses. While they play a role in the distribution chain, they are not typically considered part of distribution logistics.

 

So, the correct answer is (D) Wholesaler.

Question 9
Distribution logistics (also termed as ‘market logistics’) does not include: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Distribution channel
  • B.Inventory
  • C.Transportation
  • D.Warehouses
Correct Answer: Distribution channel

Distribution logistics, also known as market logistics, typically includes the following components:

  • Inventory management
  • Transportation
  • Warehousing
  • Order processing

 

Distribution channels, on the other hand, refer to the paths or routes through which goods or services move from the producer or manufacturer to the end consumer. Distribution channels are a part of the broader distribution process but are not typically included as a component of distribution logistics. So, the correct answer is (A) Distribution channel.

Question 10
Arrange the steps of Market logistics in right sequence.(i) Selecting the best channel design and network strategy for reaching the customers.(ii) Deciding on the company’s value proposition to its customers.(iii) Developing operational excellence.(iv) Implementing the solutionChoose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(ii), (i), (iii), (iv)
  • B.(i), (iv), (iii), (ii)
  • C.(i), (iii), (ii), (iv)
  • D.(iv), (ii), (i), (iii)
Correct Answer: (ii), (i), (iii), (iv)

The correct sequence of steps in market logistics is as follows:

 

Deciding on the company’s value proposition to its customers (ii)

This step involves determining what unique value the company will offer to its customers, which is a fundamental aspect of any marketing strategy.

 

Selecting the best channel design and network strategy for reaching the customers (i)

After deciding on the value proposition, the company should determine the most effective way to deliver that value to customers, which includes selecting the appropriate distribution channels and network strategy.

 

Developing operational excellence (iii)

Once the channel design and network strategy are in place, the company needs to focus on developing operational excellence to ensure the efficient and effective execution of its logistics and distribution activities.

 

Implementing the solution (iv)

Finally, the company should implement the chosen logistics and distribution solution based on the previous steps.

 

So, the correct sequence is (ii), (i), (iii), (iv), which corresponds to option (A).

Question 11
Given below are two statements - one islabeledas Assertion and the other islabeledas Reason.Assertion "A":No system can simultaneously maximize customer service and minimize distribution cost.Reason "R":Maximum customer service implies large inventories, premium transportation, and multiple warehouses, all of which raise market-logistics costs.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

The correct answer is (A) Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion "A" states that no system can simultaneously maximize customer service and minimize distribution cost, which is generally true. Maximizing customer service often involves providing faster delivery, maintaining higher inventory levels, and using premium transportation methods. All of these factors can increase distribution costs.

 

Reason "R" explains why this is the case. It correctly states that maximum customer service may lead to large inventories, premium transportation, and multiple warehouses, all of which can raise market-logistics costs.

Question 12
_____________ consists of putting the goods in boxes or trailers that are easy to transfer between two transportation modes.
  • A.Optimization
  • B.Optimum Transportation
  • C.Containerization
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Containerization

The correct answer is (C) Containerization.

 

Shippers are increasingly combining two or more transportation modes referred as containerization. Containerization consists of putting the goods in boxes or trailers that are easy to transfer between two transportation modes. 

 

Market-logistics strategies must be derived from business strategies, rather than solely from cost considerations. The logistics system must be information-intensive and establish electronic links among all the significant parties. The firm must make 4 major decisions about its market logistics: Order Processing, Warehousing, Inventory and Transportation.

 

Transportation: Transportation choices affect product pricing, on-time delivery performance, and the condition of the goods when they arrive, all of which affect customer satisfaction. In shipping goods to its warehouses, dealers, and customers, the company can choose rail, air, truck, waterway, or pipeline. Shippers consider such criteria as speed, frequency, dependability, capability, availability, traceability, and cost. For speed, air, rail, and truck are the prime contenders. If the goal is low cost, then the choice is water or pipeline. 

 

Shippers can choose between private, contract, or common carriers. If the shipper owns its own truck or air fleet, it becomes a private carrier. A contract carrier is an independent organization selling transportation services to others on a contract basis. A common carrier provides services between pre-determined points on a scheduled basis and is available to all shippers at standard rates. Also, to reduce costly handing at arrival, some firms are putting items into shelf-ready packaging so they don’t need to be unpacked from a box and placed on a shelf individually. Piggyback describes the use of rail and trucks; fishy-back, water and trucks; trainship, water and rail; and airtruck, air and trucks. Each coordinated mode offers specific advantages. For example, piggyback is cheaper than trucking alone yet provides flexibility and convenience.

Question 13
Planning, implementing and controlling the physical flow of material, final goods and related information from point of origin to point of consumption to meet customer requirements at a profit is known as: - (UGC NET Management Jun 2020)a. Inventory managementb. Marketing logisticsc. Physical Distributiond. Selling managementChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a and b only
  • B.b and c only
  • C.c and d only
  • D.a and d only
Correct Answer: b and c only

Planning, implementing and controlling the physical flow of material, final goods and related information from point of origin to point of consumption to meet customer requirements at a profit is known as Marketing logistics and Physical Distribution.

 

According to Phillip Kotler, “Marketing logistics involves planning, implementing and controlling physical flow of materials and final (finished) goods from the point of origin to the point of use of meet customer requirements at a profit.” The actual work of logistics is supportive in nature. It involves the integration of transportation, inventory, warehousing, materials handling, packaging and information technology. Marketing logistics involves getting the right product to the right customer in the right place at the right time.

 

(i) Physical distribution is the set of activities concerned with efficient movement of finished goods from the end of the production operation to the consumer. Physical distribution (P.D) is an important marketing function describing the marketing activities relating to the flow of raw materials from the suppliers to the factory and the movement of finished goods from the end of production line to the final consumer or user.

 

(ii) Inventory Management is a systematic approach to sourcing, storing, and selling inventory-both raw materials (components) and finished goods (products). In business terms, inventory management means the right stock, at the right levels, in the right place, at the right time, and at the right cost as well as price.

 

(iii) Sales Management is the process of developing a sales force, coordinating sales operations, and implementing sales techniques that allow a business to consistently hit, and even surpass, its sales targets.

Question 14
Which of the following are the components of international logistics? (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)(i) Fixed facilities location(ii) inventory management(iii) Order processingChoose the correct answer from the code given below:Codes:
  • A.(ii) and (iii)
  • B.(i) and (ii)
  • C.(i) and (iii)
  • D.(i), (ii) and (iii)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii) and (iii)

The provided question pertains to the components of international logistics, which involves the management and coordination of various activities related to the movement of goods and information across international borders.

 

The components mentioned are:

 

(i) Fixed Facilities Location: This component involves the strategic decision-making regarding the locations of production plants, warehouses, distribution centers, and other facilities. The selection of appropriate locations impacts the efficiency of the supply chain, transportation costs, and proximity to target markets.

 

(ii) Inventory Management: Inventory management is crucial in international logistics to ensure the availability of products at various points along the supply chain. This component involves managing inventory levels, optimizing order quantities, minimizing carrying costs, and addressing challenges related to demand fluctuations and lead times.

 

(iii) Order Processing: Order processing refers to the activities involved in receiving and fulfilling customer orders. In the context of international logistics, this includes activities such as order entry, order confirmation, order picking, packing, and shipping. Efficient order processing contributes to customer satisfaction and timely delivery.

 

The correct answer is (D) (i), (ii), and (iii) because all three components (fixed facilities location, inventory management, and order processing) are integral to international logistics. These components collectively ensure the smooth flow of products, information, and services across international boundaries, contributing to effective supply chain management on a global scale.

Quiz Attempt #119609

Total Questions: 9
Question 1
The retail supply chain does NOT include (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.Manufactures
  • B.Retailers
  • C.Wholesalers
  • D.Regulators
Correct Answer: Regulators

The correct answer is (D) Regulators.

 

The retail supply chain involves various entities and stages, including manufacturers, wholesalers, and retailers, that are involved in the process of getting products from the manufacturer to the end consumer. However, regulators, such as government bodies or agencies, are not part of the retail supply chain. They are external entities that oversee and regulate various aspects of the supply chain but are not directly involved in the physical movement and distribution of products.

Question 2
Which of the following is NOT true for Supply Chain Management approach? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Joint reduction in channel inventories.
  • B.Large breadth of supplier base to increase competition and spread risk.
  • C.Risk and rewards are shared over long term.
  • D.Companies use intermodal transportation to reach to their markets.
Correct Answer: Large breadth of supplier base to increase competition and spread risk.

The statement that is NOT true for the Supply Chain Management approach is (B) Large breadth of supplier base to increase competition and spread risk.

 

In Supply Chain Management, having a large breadth of supplier base does not necessarily aim to increase competition and spread risk. Instead, Supply Chain Management focuses on building strong relationships with a selected number of reliable and efficient suppliers to streamline operations, reduce costs, and improve overall efficiency.

Question 3
Match the following.List I(a) Platform(b) Supply Chain(c) Value Capture(d) SolutionsList II(i) Redefine how company gets paid or create innovative new revenue streams.(ii) Create integrated and customized offerings that solve end-to-end customer problems.(iii) Use common components or building blocks to create derivative offerings.(iv) Think differently about sourcing and fulfilment.Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(ii) d-(i)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)

The matching options represent various aspects of business strategies, particularly in the context of creating value and innovation.

 

(a) Platform - (iii) Use common components or building blocks to create derivative offerings.

When a business uses common components or building blocks as a foundation, it is essentially creating a platform. This platform can be used to develop a range of derivative offerings or products, making the most of shared resources and technologies.

 

(b) Supply Chain - (iv) Think differently about sourcing and fulfillment.

Supply chain management involves the process of sourcing raw materials, production, and delivering products to customers. Thinking differently about sourcing and fulfillment means optimizing these processes to increase efficiency, reduce costs, and improve overall supply chain performance.

 

(c) Value Capture - (i) Redefine how the company gets paid or create innovative new revenue streams.

Value capture is about finding innovative ways to capture the value created by a business. This can involve rethinking the business model and revenue streams. By redefining how a company gets paid, it can maximize its profitability and success.

 

(d) Solutions - (ii) Create integrated and customized offerings that solve end-to-end customer problems.

Providing solutions to customers means offering integrated and customized products or services that address their specific needs and problems comprehensively. It involves understanding the customer's challenges and tailoring offerings to provide a complete solution.

In summary, these pairings illustrate different aspects of strategic thinking in business, emphasizing innovation, efficiency, revenue generation, and customer-centric approaches to creating value.

Question 4
A _______ contract establishes a long-term relationship in which the supplier promises to resupply the buyer as needed, at agreed-upon prices, over a specified period of time.
  • A.pillow
  • B.sheet
  • C.blanket
  • D.cover
Correct Answer: blanket

In the case of maintenance, repair, and operating items, buyers are moving toward blanket contracts rather than periodic purchase orders. A blanket contract establishes a long-term relationship in which the supplier promises to resupply the buyer as needed, at agreed-upon prices, over a specified period of time. Because the seller holds the stock, blanket contracts are sometimes called stockless purchase plans. The buyer’s computer automatically sends an order to the seller when stock is needed. This system locks suppliers in tighter with the buyer and makes it difficult for out-suppliers to break in unless the buyer becomes dissatisfied with prices, quality, or service.

Some companies go further and shift the ordering responsibility to their suppliers in systems called Vendor-Managed Inventory (VMI). These suppliers are privy to the customer’s inventory levels and take responsibility for replenishing automatically through continuous replenishment programs.

Question 5
Which of the following is NOT a buyer-supplier relationship category?(i) Collaborative(ii) Basic buying and selling(iii) Bare bones(iv) Contractual transaction(v) Customer supply(vi) Cooperative system(vii) Customer care service(viii) Mutually adaptive(ix) Customer is kingSelect the correct option:Codes
  • A.(iii)
  • B.(vii)
  • C.(vi)
  • D.(ii)
Correct Answer: (vii)

A number of forces influence the development of a relationship between business partners. 4 relevant factors are availability of alternatives, importance of supply, complexity of supply, and supply market dynamism. Based on these we can classify buyer–supplier relationships into 8 categories: 

1. Basic buying and selling—These are simple, routine exchanges with moderate levels of cooperation and information exchange. 

2. Bare bones—These relationships require more adaptation by the seller and less cooperation and information exchange. 

3. Contractual transaction—These exchanges are defined by formal contract and generally have low levels of trust, cooperation, and interaction. 

4. Customer supply—In this traditional custom supply situation, competition rather than cooperation is the dominant form of governance. 

5. Cooperative systems—The partners in cooperative systems are united in operational ways, but neither demonstrates structural commitment through legal means or adaptation. 

6. Collaborative—In collaborative exchanges, much trust and commitment lead to true partnership.

7. Mutually adaptive—Buyers and sellers make many relationship-specific adaptations, but without necessarily achieving strong trust or cooperation. 

8. Customer is king—In this close, cooperative relationship, the seller adapts to meet the customer’s needs without expecting much adaptation or change in exchange.

Question 6
Process of managing upstream and downstream of final goods, flow of raw materials and information about resellers and final consumers is classified as:
  • A.Marketing Logistics Network
  • B.Supply Chain Management
  • C.Value Delivery Network
  • D.Physical Distribution Management
Correct Answer: Supply Chain Management

The correct answer is (B) Supply Chain Management.

 

Supply Chain Management (SCM) is the process of managing the flow of goods, services, information, and resources from the initial suppliers of raw materials to the final consumers of finished products. It encompasses the coordination and integration of various activities such as sourcing, procurement, production, distribution, and logistics to optimize the efficiency and effectiveness of the entire supply chain network. SCM aims to ensure that products are delivered to the right place, at the right time, in the right quantity, and at the lowest possible cost. It also involves managing relationships with suppliers, manufacturers, distributors, retailers, and customers to create value for all parties involved.

 

Physical Distribution Management (PDM) caters to the actual movement of products through the various channels of distribution. This field of study is concerned with various aspects related to transportation of the goods, the main of which is transportation cost.

 

Marketing logistics network involve the transportation of goods in a planned manner, which offers control over the distribution mechanism. It involves mainly planning, actual delivery and marketing information flow. This is mainly a combination of marketing and operations. Marketing creates a demand and logistics fills that demand through effective flow of goods/services. Together they are referred to as Marketing Logistics.

 

Value delivery network is a network that made up of the company, its suppliers, its distributors, and ultimately its customers who partner with each other to improve the performance of the entire system.

Question 7
Arrange merchandising buying activity steps in a sequential manner.i)Evaluate the Merchandise Itemsii)Determine Merchandise Sourcesiii)Record the Buying Figuresiv)Collect Informationv)Negotiate the Pricesvi)Handle and Store the Merchandisevii)Finalize the PurchaseCodes:
  • A.(iv), (ii), (i), (v), (vii), (vi), (iii)
  • B.(iv), (ii), (iii), (v), (vi), (i), (vii)
  • C.(iv), (iii), (ii), (v), (vi), (i), (vii)
  • D.(iv), (v), (iii), (ii), (vi), (i), (vii)
Correct Answer: (iv), (ii), (i), (v), (vii), (vi), (iii)

The correct sequence for the merchandising buying activity steps is as follows:

 

Collect Information (iv)

Determine Merchandise Sources (ii)

Evaluate the Merchandise Items (i)

Negotiate the Prices (v)

Finalize the Purchase (vii)

Handle and Store the Merchandise (vi)

Record the Buying Figures (iii)

 

Merchandising is the sequence of various activities performed by the retailer such as planning, buying, and selling of products to the customers for their use. It is an integral part of handling store operations and e-commerce of retailing. Merchandising presents the products in retail environment to influence the customer’s buying decision.

 

Merchandise Buying activity includes the following:

Step 1 - Collect Information: Gather information on consumer demand, current trends, and market requirements. It can be received internally from employees, feedback/complaint boxes, demand slips, or externally by vendors, suppliers, competitors, or via the Internet.

Step 2 - Determine Merchandise Sources: Know who all can satisfy the demand: vendors, suppliers, and producers. Compare them on the basis of prices, timeliness, guarantee/warranty offerings, payment terms, and performance and selecting the best feasible resource(s).

Step 3 - Evaluate the Merchandise Items: By going through sample products, or the complete lot of products, assess the products for quality.

Step 4 - Negotiate the Prices: Realize a good deal of purchase by negotiating prices for bulk purchase.

Step 5 - Finalize the Purchase: Finalizing the product prices and buying the merchandise by executing buying transaction.

Step 6 - Handle and Store the Merchandise: Deciding on how the vendor will deliver the products, examining product packing, acquiring the product, and stocking a part of products in the storehouse.

Step 7 - Record the Buying Figures: Recording details of transactions, number of unit pieces of products according to product categories and sub-classes, and respective unit prices in the inventory management system of the retail business.

 

So, the correct code is (A) (iv), (ii), (i), (v), (vii), (vi), (iii)

Question 8
Name the process in which a buyer posts its interest in buying a certain quantity of item and sellers compete for the business by submitting lower bid until there is only one seller left. (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.Internet
  • B.Reverse auction
  • C.B2B market place
  • D.B2C market place
Correct Answer: Reverse auction

The correct answer is (B) Reverse auction.

 

In a reverse auction, the buyer posts its interest in buying a certain quantity of items, and potential sellers compete for the business by submitting successively lower bids. The auction continues until there is only one seller left, usually the one who has submitted the lowest bid. Reverse auctions are commonly used in B2B (business-to-business) procurement processes to help buyers obtain goods and services at the best possible prices through competitive bidding among suppliers.

Question 9
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Many companies today have partnered with specific suppliers and distributors to create a superior value delivery network, also called a supply chain.Statement II:To be successful, a firm also needs to look for competitive advantages beyond its own operations, into the value chains of suppliers, distributors, and customers.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

The correct answer is (A) Both statements are correct.

 

Statement I is accurate. Many companies recognize the importance of collaborating with their suppliers and distributors to create a well-functioning supply chain or value delivery network. This network helps ensure the smooth flow of products or services from suppliers to customers, enhancing efficiency and customer satisfaction.

 

Statement II is also correct. To achieve sustainable competitive advantages, firms must consider the entire value chain, not just their internal operations. This means looking for ways to improve processes and create value in collaboration with suppliers, distributors, and even end customers. By doing so, a company can gain a competitive edge in the broader marketplace.

Quiz Attempt #119610

Total Questions: 43
Question 1
Which of the following statements explains the Integrated Marketing Communication (IMC) concept?(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)a. IMC is the specific blend of promotion tools to communicate customer value and build customer relationships.b. IMC calls for recognising only those touch points where the customer physically encounters the company and its brands.c. IMC's goal is to deliver a consistent and clear massage about the organisation and its products.d. IMC ties togetherall ofthe company's messages and images.e. IMC calls for integration and coordination of the company's many communication channels.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a and c only
  • B.a, b and d only
  • C.c, d and e only
  • D.a, b and e only
Correct Answer: c, d and e only

Correct answer is option C - c, d and e.

 

Integrated Marketing Communication (IMC) refers to the strategic coordination of various promotional elements and communication channels to ensure that a consistent and unified message is conveyed to the target audience.

 

a. IMC is the specific blend of promotion tools to communicate customer value and build customer relationships.

This statement is a partial explanation of IMC, focusing on the idea that IMC involves using various promotional tools to communicate value and build customer relationships. However, it doesn't encompass the complete concept of integration and coordination across communication channels.

 

b. IMC calls for recognising only those touch points where the customer physically encounters the company and its brands.

This statement is not accurate. IMC is not limited to physical touchpoints only; it encompasses all communication channels, including both physical and digital.

 

c. IMC's goal is to deliver a consistent and clear message about the organisation and its products.

This statement accurately captures one of the main goals of IMC, which is to ensure that a consistent and clear message is conveyed to the audience across various communication channels.

 

d. IMC ties together all of the company's messages and images.

This statement highlights another key aspect of IMC, which involves integrating and aligning all of the company's messages and images to avoid inconsistency and confusion.

 

e. IMC calls for integration and coordination of the company's many communication channels.

This statement accurately describes a fundamental principle of IMC, which is the integration and coordination of diverse communication channels to present a unified message to the audience.

Question 2
Arrange the following steps in the proper sequence to develop effective marketing communication.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)A. Designthe communicationB. Select the communication channelC. Identify the target audienceD. Choose the communication mixE. Choosethe communicationobjectivesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, A, C, B, D
  • B.C, A, B, D, E
  • C.E, B, C, A, D
  • D.C, E, A, B, D
Correct Answer: C, E, A, B, D

The correct match is given below.

 

Identify the target audience (C): The first step is to determine who the communication is intended for.

Choose the communication objectives (E): Define what the marketing communication aims to achieve.

Design the communication (A): Develop the message, tone, and style to engage the audience.

Select the communication channel (B): Choose the medium, such as social media, TV, or print. Choose the communication mix (D): Finalize the combination of tools like advertising, PR, and sales promotions.

Question 3
Which of the following is not constituent of promotion-mix:(UGC NET Management Jun 2009)
  • A.Advertising
  • B.Sales promotion
  • C.Direct marketing
  • D.Publicity
Correct Answer: Publicity

A company’s total promotion mix—also called its marketing communications mix—consists of the specific blend of advertising, public relations, personal selling, sales promotion, and direct marketing tools that the company uses to engage consumers, persuasively communicate customer value, and build customer relationships. The five major promotion tools are defined as follows:

1. Advertising: Any paid form of nonpersonal presentation and promotion of ideas, goods, or services by an identified sponsor.

2. Sales promotion: Short-term incentives to encourage the purchase or sale of a product or service.

3. Personal selling: Personal customer interactions by the firm’s sales force for the purpose of making sales and building customer relationships.

4. Public relations: Building good relations with the company’s various publics by obtaining favourable publicity, building up a good corporate image, and handling or heading off unfavourable rumours, stories, and events.

5. Direct and digital marketing: Engaging directly with carefully targeted individual consumers and customer communities to both obtain an immediate response and build lasting customer relationships.

Question 4
Which one of the following is not coordinated in the Vertical Integration of Integrated Marketing Communications? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Pricing
  • B.Sales
  • C.Product Development
  • D.Customer Service
Correct Answer: Pricing

In the Vertical Integration of Integrated Marketing Communications, pricing is typically not coordinated. Vertical integration in marketing communications focuses on coordinating various elements of the marketing mix, such as advertising, sales promotion, public relations, and direct marketing, to deliver a consistent and cohesive message to the target audience.

 

While pricing is an essential element of the marketing mix, it is typically managed separately from integrated marketing communications. Pricing decisions often involve factors like cost analysis, market competition, and pricing strategies that are distinct from the coordination of communication elements.

 

So, the correct answer is (A) Pricing.

Question 5
Match the modes of communication in marketing and their communication platforms (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)Mode of Communication(a) Advertising(b) Sales Promotion(c) Word of mouth marketing(d) Personal sellingCommunication Platform(i) Blogs(ii) brochures & Booklets(iii) Sales meetings(iv) ContestsChoose the correct option:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii)

The correct matching of modes of communication in marketing and their communication platforms is (B) (a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(iii).

 

Detailed explanation of correct pair is given below:

 

Advertising- Brochures & Booklets

Any paid form of nonpersonal presentation and promotion of ideas, goods, or services by an identified sponsor via print media (newspapers, magazines, brochures), broadcast media (radio and television), network media (telephone, cable, satellite, wireless), electronic media (audiotape, videotape, videodisk, CD-ROM, Web page), and display media (billboards, signs, posters).

 

Sales Promotion- Contests

A variety of short-term incentives to encourage trial or purchase of a product or service including consumer promotions (such as samples, coupons, and premiums), trade promotions (such as advertising and display allowances), and business and sales force promotions (contests for sales reps).
