e. Rational appeal generally gets noticed: This statement does not align with the premise that emotional appeals are used because rational appeals are less effective at capturing attention.

Question 3
Experienced advertisers use the guide AIDA to construct their advertisement. Here AIDA refers to:(UGC NET HRM Dec 2024)
  • A.Attract, Interest, Develop, Action
  • B.Attract, Involve, Desire, Action
  • C.Attention, Interest, Desire, Action
  • D.Attention, Involve, Develop, Action
Correct Answer: Attention, Interest, Desire, Action

The correct answer is (C) Attention, Interest, Desire, Action.

 

AIDA is a well-known acronym used in advertising and marketing to guide the creation of effective advertisements. It represents the four key stages that a customer typically goes through when interacting with an advertisement:

Attention: Capture the audience's attention with eye-catching visuals or messages.

Interest: Engage the audience by providing information that resonates with their needs or wants.

Desire: Create a desire for the product or service by highlighting its benefits and how it can solve a problem or fulfill a need.

Action: Encourage the audience to take the desired action, such as making a purchase, signing up, or visiting a website.

Therefore, AIDA stands for Attention, Interest, Desire, Action.

Question 4
On which one of the following, the corporate advertising concentrates? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.Brand Personality
  • B.Product Personality
  • C.Organizational Personality
  • D.Recruitment
Correct Answer: Organizational Personality

Corporate advertising typically concentrates on (C) Organizational Personality.

 

Corporate advertising aims to build and promote the image and personality of the organization as a whole. It focuses on enhancing the reputation, values, and identity of the company among the public, stakeholders, and potential employees. This type of advertising often emphasizes the organization's culture, values, social responsibility, and overall identity.

Question 5
Match the items of List - I with the items of List - II and select the correct code of matching: (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)List - I (Advertising Agencies)(a) Ogilvy and Mather Ltd(b) JWT Hindustan Thompson Associates(c) Mudra Communications(d) McCann- Erikson India LtdList – II (Clients)(i) HDFC(ii) Coca-Cola(iii) Vodafone(iv) NestleCode:
  • A.a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
  • C.a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

The correct code for matching is (D) a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii.

(a) Ogilvy and Mather Ltd – (iii) Vodafone

(b) JWT Hindustan Thompson Associates - (ii) Coca-Cola

(c) Mudra Communications - (i) HDFC

(d) McCann- Erikson India Ltd – (iv) Nestle

Question 6
Statement – I: In developing advertising programme marketing managers must always start by identifying the target market and buyer motives. (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)Statement – II: A company may run multiple ad campaigns at the same time, each emphasizing different aspects of its brand and service.
  • A.Only Statement – I is correct.
  • B.Only Statement – II is correct.
  • C.Both Statements – I and II are correct.
  • D.Both Statements – I and II are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both Statements – I and II are correct.

Both statements are correct:

 

Statement I emphasizes the importance of identifying the target market and understanding buyer motives as the initial step in developing an advertising program. This step is fundamental because it sets the foundation for crafting effective advertising messages and strategies. When companies know who their target audience is and what motivates them, they can tailor their advertising efforts to resonate with these potential customers, increasing the chances of success.

 

Statement II acknowledges that companies may run multiple advertising campaigns concurrently. Each campaign can focus on different aspects of the brand or its offerings. This approach allows businesses to reach various customer segments or address different consumer needs. For example, a company might have one campaign that highlights the affordability of its products and another campaign emphasizing the quality or innovation of its services. By running multiple campaigns, a company can effectively communicate a diverse range of messages and appeals to a broader audience.

 

Together, these statements highlight the importance of strategic planning and customization in advertising. Identifying the target market and tailoring advertising messages accordingly are key factors in achieving marketing objectives. Moreover, running multiple campaigns can be a versatile strategy for reaching different customer segments and achieving various marketing goals.

Question 7
Match the items of the List – I with that of the List – II and suggest the correct code from the following: (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)List – Ii. Competitive Parityii. Promotional Elasticity of Marketiii. Optimal promotional mixiv. Contra-cycle advertisingList – IIa. Variations in Advertisingb. Level advertisingc. Advertising expenditure decisiond. Marginal equivalency of media outlayCodes:
  • A.i- b, ii-c, iii- a, iv- d
  • B.i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv- d
  • C.i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c
  • D.i-d, ii- a, iii- b, iv- c
Correct Answer: i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c

Given these correspondences, the correct matching is (C) i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c. This pairing accurately links the concepts from List - I with their corresponding concepts from List - II.

 

i. Competitive Parity - This concept refers to setting advertising budgets in a way that is in line with what competitors are spending. In other words, a company spends a similar amount on advertising as its competitors to remain competitive. This relates to "Level advertising," which means maintaining a consistent level of advertising expenditure.

 

ii. Promotional Elasticity of Market - Promotional elasticity of market refers to how sensitive the market is to changes in promotional activities. This concept is related to "Variations in Advertising," as it deals with understanding how changes in advertising efforts impact market responsiveness.

 

iii. Optimal promotional mix - The optimal promotional mix is about finding the right combination of promotional tools like advertising, sales promotions, public relations, etc., to achieve marketing objectives efficiently. This concept aligns with "Marginal equivalency of media outlay," as it involves determining how to allocate resources effectively across various promotional channels.

 

iv. Contra-cycle advertising - Contra-cycle advertising refers to the strategy of advertising more during economic downturns when competitors may be cutting back on advertising. This corresponds to "Advertising expenditure decision," as it involves making decisions about how much to spend on advertising based on the economic cycle.

 

So, the correct matching of items is:

 

i. Competitive Parity - b. Level advertising

ii. Promotional Elasticity of Market - a. Variations in Advertising

iii. Optimal promotional mix - d. Marginal equivalency of media outlay

iv. Contra-cycle advertising - c. Advertising expenditure decision

Question 8
Match the items of List – I with the items of List – II and select the code of correct matching: (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)List – I (Medium of Mass Communication)a. Outdoorb. Yellow pagesc. Brochuresd. TelephoneList – II (Limitations)i. Relative high cost; increasing consumer resistanceii. Over production could lead to runaway costsiii. High competition; long ad purchase lead time; creative limitationsiv. Limited audience selectivity; creative limitationsCodes:
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • D.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i

The correct matching is (A) a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i. This pairing accurately links the mediums of mass communication from List - I with their corresponding limitations from List - II.

 

i. Outdoor - This medium includes billboards and outdoor advertising. The limitation associated with outdoor advertising is "Limited audience selectivity; creative limitations" because it often reaches a broad audience without much ability to target specific demographics.

 

ii. Yellow pages - Yellow pages are a directory of businesses. The limitation here is "High competition; long ad purchase lead time; creative limitations" because businesses in yellow pages face competition from numerous other listings, and the process of creating and purchasing ads in directories can be time-consuming.

 

iii. Brochures - Brochures are printed materials used for advertising and promotion. The limitation of brochures is "Overproduction could lead to runaway costs" because producing too many brochures that do not get used can result in excessive expenses.

 

iv. Telephone - Telephone advertising can involve telemarketing or cold calling. The limitation associated with telephone advertising is "Relative high cost; increasing consumer resistance" because it can be expensive, and consumers are often resistant to unsolicited phone calls for marketing purposes.

Question 9
A company following a strategy of advertising the product for a period followed by a period with no advertising is called (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.Concentration
  • B.Flighting
  • C.Pulsing
  • D.Continuity
Correct Answer: Flighting

Media scheduling patterns are crucial components of an advertising strategy, dictating how and when advertisements are delivered to the target audience. Each pattern serves specific purposes and aligns with different marketing objectives. Let's explore these media scheduling patterns along with their explanations:

 

Continuity: Continuity is achieved by scheduling advertising exposures evenly throughout a given period. This pattern ensures a consistent presence of advertisements in the market over an extended duration. It is particularly useful when the marketing objective is to maintain awareness, reinforce brand messages, or promote products or services with consistent demand year-round. For example, a toothpaste brand may choose continuity scheduling to keep its brand visible and maintain consumer awareness continuously.

 

Concentration: Concentration involves allocating all advertising dollars within a single, concentrated period. This strategy is often chosen when there is a specific promotional event, product launch, or seasonal campaign where it makes sense to intensively focus marketing efforts for a brief period. For instance, a toy manufacturer may concentrate its advertising budget in the months leading up to the holiday season to maximize sales during this critical period.

 

Flighting: Flighting involves alternating periods of advertising activity with periods of no advertising. This pattern is suitable for products or services that experience seasonal fluctuations in demand or for campaigns with budget constraints. For example, a sunscreen brand may use flighting by advertising heavily during the summer months when sun protection is a top priority and then reducing or pausing advertising during the winter when demand decreases.

 

Pulsing: Pulsing combines continuous advertising at low-weight levels with periodic waves of heavier advertising activity. This pattern aims to maintain a baseline level of visibility while periodically intensifying marketing efforts to capitalize on specific opportunities or seasonal variations. It's often employed when a product or service has some level of year-round demand but experiences significant peaks at certain times. For instance, a sportswear brand may use pulsing to maintain a consistent presence in the market but boost advertising during major sporting events or athletic seasons to take advantage of increased interest.

 

Thus, the correct answer is Flighting.

Question 10
An ideal advertisement (ad) campaign would ensure that: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)A. The ad motivates consumers to consider purchases of the brand.B. The ad gives maximum possible product knowledge to the customer.C. The ad causes the consumer to pay attention but does not distract from the intended message.D. The ad properly reflects the consumers level of understanding and behaviours with the product and the brand.E. The right consumer is exposed to the right message at the right place and at the right time.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A, B and E only
  • B.C, D and E only
  • C.A B, C and D only
  • D.A, C, D and E only
Correct Answer: A, C, D and E only

An ideal advertisement (ad) campaign should aim to achieve multiple objectives to be effective. Let's break down the given options to understand why (D) A, C, D, and E only is the correct answer:

 

A. The ad motivates consumers to consider purchases of the brand: This statement is correct. Effective advertising should motivate consumers to consider purchasing the product or brand being advertised.

 

B. The ad gives maximum possible product knowledge to the customer: While providing product knowledge is important, it's not always necessary to give "maximum possible" knowledge in a single ad. The key is to provide relevant and compelling information that helps consumers make informed decisions.

 

C. The ad causes the consumer to pay attention but does not distract from the intended message: This statement is correct. A good ad should grab the viewer's attention without overwhelming or distracting from the core message being conveyed.

 

D. The ad properly reflects the consumer's level of understanding and behaviors with the product and the brand: This statement is also correct. Effective ads should resonate with the target audience and align with their existing knowledge and behaviors related to the product or brand.

 

E. The right consumer is exposed to the right message at the right place and at the right time: This statement is crucial for successful advertising. Targeted and timely exposure ensures that the advertisement reaches the intended audience when they are most receptive to the message.

Question 11
Advertising method in which a commercial is broadcast simultaneously on several radio stations and/or television channels is known as (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Road block
  • B.Road side
  • C.Intensified campaign
  • D.Exclusive drive
Correct Answer: Road block

The correct answer is (A) Road block.

 

A "roadblock" in advertising is a method where a commercial is broadcast simultaneously on several radio stations and/or television channels. This approach aims to reach a broader audience by ensuring that the advertisement is seen or heard by a large number of viewers or listeners across various media channels simultaneously.

Question 12
Match the following. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)List I (Advertising Agency in 2020)a. O&M (Ogilvy and Mather)b. McCannEricksonc. Trikaya Greyd. JWT Hindustan Thompson AssociatesList II (Brand)i. Mastercardii. Nestleiii. Cadburyiv. Proctor and GambleChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • C.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
  • D.a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

O&M (Ogilvy and Mather) – Cadbury

Mc Cann Erickson – Mastercard

Trikaya Grey – Proctor and Gamble

JWT Hindustan Thompson Associates – Nestle

Question 13
Which method of setting the advertising budget of a company is considered to be the most scientific? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.All-you-can-afford method
  • B.Percentage of sales method
  • C.Competitive-parity method
  • D.Objectives and tasks method
Correct Answer: Objectives and tasks method

The method of setting the advertising budget of a company that is considered to be the most scientific is the "Objectives and tasks method" (Option D).

 

The Objectives and tasks method involves setting the advertising budget based on the specific objectives a company wants to achieve through its advertising efforts. This method is considered the most scientific because it requires a thorough analysis of the company's advertising goals, the tasks needed to achieve those goals, and the associated costs. By linking the budget directly to objectives and tasks, it allows for a more strategic and precise allocation of resources to achieve desired outcomes.

Question 14
Assertion ‘A’: “Advertising plays a vital role in selling products/services.”Reason ‘R’: “Sales promotion is incomplete without a good advertising plan.”Codes:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)
  • A.A is correct, but R is false.
  • B.A is false, but R is correct.
  • C.Both A and R are correct.
  • D.Both A and R are false.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct.

The assertion (A) is correct because advertising indeed plays a vital role in promoting and selling products/services by creating awareness, generating interest, and influencing consumer behavior.

 

The reason (R) is also correct because a good advertising plan is often an integral part of an overall sales promotion strategy. Advertising can help in promoting sales promotions, special offers, and discounts to a wider audience, making the sales promotion more effective.

 

Therefore, both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are correct, and the correct option is (C).

Question 15
Road blocking advertisement is: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2011)
  • A.Advertising a product by blocking a road.
  • B.Putting an advertisement on a blocked road.
  • C.A technique of gathering potential customers on the road.
  • D.Advertising a product on all similar TV/Radio channels at the same time.
Correct Answer: Advertising a product on all similar TV/Radio channels at the same time.

Road blocking advertisement is (D) Advertising a product on all similar TV/Radio channels at the same time.

 

In road blocking, advertisers buy up all the available advertising slots on multiple TV or radio channels simultaneously to create a dominating presence and capture the audience's attention. This technique is often used for the launch of a major product or promotion to ensure maximum visibility and impact.

Question 16
A marketer developing a brand name that is easy to pronounce would conduct:(UGC NET ManagementDec2013)
  • A.An Association Test
  • B.A Memory Test
  • C.A Preference Test
  • D.A Recall Test
Correct Answer: A Recall Test

Recall Test- Brand recall is also known as unaided recall or spontaneous recall and refers to the ability of the consumers to correctly elicit a brand name from memory when prompted by a product category. Brand recall indicates a relatively strong link between a category and a brand while brand recognition indicates a weaker link. When prompted by a product category, most consumers can only recall a relatively small set of brands, typically around 3–5 brand names. In consumer tests, few consumers can recall more than seven brand names within a given category and for low-interest product categories, most consumers can only recall one or two brand names.

Question 17
Which of the following is NOT the factor to be considered while setting Advertising Budget?
  • A.Stage in the Product Life Cycle
  • B.Advertising frequency
  • C.Cost of Product
  • D.Competition
Correct Answer: Cost of Product

Setting the Advertising Budget:

After determining its advertising objectives, the company next sets its advertising budget for each product. Here we describe some specific factors that should be considered when setting the advertising budget:

 

Stage in the product life cycle: New products typically need large advertising budgets to build awareness and to gain consumer trial. Mature brands usually require lower budgets as a ratio to sales.

 

Market share: High-market-share brands usually need more advertising spending as a percentage of sales than do low-share brands. Building the market or taking share from competitors requires larger advertising spending than does simply maintaining current share.

 

Competition: In a market with many competitors and high advertising spending, a brand must advertise more heavily to be heard above the noise in the market.

 

Advertising frequency: When many repetitions are needed to present the brand's message to consumers, the advertising budget must be larger.

 

Product differentiation: A brand that closely resembles other brands in its product class (coffee, laundry detergents, chewing gum, beer, soft drinks) requires heavy advertising to set it apart. When the product differs greatly from competitors, advertising can be used to point out the differences to consumers.

Question 18
What do you mean by ‘Media Vehicles’ in the context of selection of advertising media?
  • A.Specific media within each general media type
  • B.Alternate media sources
  • C.Deciding on the timing of media
  • D.Deciding on reach of media
Correct Answer: Specific media within each general media type

This step is about Selecting Advertising Media where media vehicle is described as specific media within each general media type, such as specific magazines, television shows or radio programs. In the process of designing advertising campaign, after creating the Advertising Message the advertiser must next decide upon the media to carry the message. The main steps in media selection are:

1. Deciding on reach, frequency and impact

2. Choosing among chief media types

3. Selecting media vehicles

4. Deciding on media timing

Question 19
Based on 5M’s, arrange the steps involved in developing an Advertising Program in correct sequence:(a)Deciding on the advertising budget (Money)(b) Deciding on Media Strategies (Media)(c) Choosing the advertising message (Message)(d) Setting advertising objectives (Mission)Codes:
  • A.(d), (b), (c), (a)
  • B.(d), (a), (c), (b)
  • C.(a), (d), (a), (b)
  • D.(b), (a), (c), (d)
Correct Answer: (d), (a), (c), (b)

Steps in developing an advertising program, are (based on 5 M’s):

1. Setting advertising objectives (Mission):

Objectives can be classified by aim:

- Informative Advertising

- Persuasive Advertising

- Reminder Advertising

- Reinforcement Advertising

 

2. Deciding on the advertising budget (Money):

Factors considered when budget-setting, are:

- Stage of product life cycle

- Market share and consumer base

- Competition and clutter

- Advertising frequency

- Product substitutability

 

3. Choosing the advertising message (Message):

Factors considered when choosing the advertising message, are:

- Message generation – How to create an effective message.

- Message evaluation and selection – How to rate messages, e.g. according to desirability, exclusiveness, and believability.

- Message execution – Deciding on how to say the message, e.g. present explicit features or appeal to emotions? What headings, tones, and words should be used?

 

4. Deciding on Media Strategies (Media):

Media Selection – finding the most cost-effective media to deliver the desired number and type of exposures to the target audience. It involves deciding on Reach (number of people exposed), Frequency of exposure, and Impact (qualitative value). The relationship between reach (R), frequency (F), and impact (I) is shown in total number of exposures (R × F), and weighted number of exposures (R × F × I)

 

Selecting media types (newspapers, television, direct mail, Radio, Magazines, outdoor, yellow pages, newsletters, brochures, telephone) and vehicles is also done. It also involves determining media timing like seasons and business cycles. Models developed on timing can be macro scheduling focused (like the time lag model), involving scheduling the advertising in relation to season and the business cycle, or micro scheduling based, calling for allocating advertising expenditures within a short period to obtain maximum impact. However, the most effective pattern depends on the communication objectives in relation to the nature of the product, target customers, distribution channels, and other marketing factors.

 

5. Measuring Effectiveness (Measurement):

There are 2 methods:

Communication-effect Research: It seeks to determine whether an ad is communicating effectively. Also called "Copy testing", it can be done before an ad is placed (Pre-testing) or after ad is placed (Post-testing). Methods of advertising pretesting are:

- Direct Rating Method - here, customers are directly asked to rate the advertisement and then these rating are calculated.

- Portfolio Tests - here, the customers see the ads and listen carefully to the ads and all the contents of the ads and then they are asked to recall the ad and the contents. Then the calculations are done with help of this data.

- Laboratory tests - here, the apparatus to measure the heart rates, blood pressure, perspiration, etc. are used on the customer after he watches the ad, to know the physiological reactions of the body.

 

Sales Effect Research: Sales Effect Research totally depends on the sales of the company. The sales keep varying from time to time. There are some factors affecting sales like product availability, the price of the product, contents of the product, and sometimes the competitors. So this method is a little difficult than the communication one.

Question 20
Which of the following is not a Media Scheduling Pattern?
  • A.Continuity
  • B.Scalling
  • C.Flighting
  • D.Pulsing
Correct Answer: Scalling

Media Scheduling Patterns: Continuity, concentration, flighting, and pulsing and different timing strategies:

- Continuity – Is achieved by scheduling exposures evenly throughout a given period.

- Concentration – Calls for spending all the advertising dollars in a single period.

- Flighting – calls for advertising for some period, followed by an interruption of no advertising, followed by a second period of advertising activity.

- Pulsing – Continuous advertising at low-weight levels reinforced periodically by waves of heavier activity.

Question 21
Which of the following is/are message execution style in advertising?
  • A.Fantasy
  • B.Testimonial Evidence
  • C.Slice of life
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Steps in developing an Advertising Program, are (based on 5 M’s):

1. Setting advertising objectives (Mission)

 

2. Deciding on the advertising budget (Money)

 

3. Choosing the advertising message (Message)

Factors considered when choosing the advertising message, are:

- Message generation – How to create an effective message.

- Message evaluation and selection – How to rate messages, e.g. according to desirability, exclusiveness, and believability.

- Message execution – Deciding on how to say the message, e.g. present explicit features or appeal to emotions? What headings, tones, and words should be used? Any message can be presented in different execution styles, such as the following:

Slice of life: This style shows one or more people using the product in a normal setting.

Lifestyle: This style shows how a product fits in with a particular lifestyle.

Fantasy: This style creates a fantasy around the product or its use.

Mood or image: This style builds a mood or image around the product, such as beauty, love or serenity.

Musical: The ad is built around a song or some well-known music, so that emotional responses to the music are associated with the product.

Personality symbol: This style creates a character that represents the product. The character might he animated or real.

Technical expertise: This style shows the company's expertise in making the product.

Scientific evidence: This style presents survey or scientific evidence that the brand is better or better liked than one or more other brands.

Testimonial evidence: This style features a highly believable or likable source endorsing the product.

 

4. Deciding on Media Strategies (Media)

 

5. Measuring Effectiveness (Measurement)

There are 2 methods:

Communication-effect Research

Sales Effect Research

Question 22
Which one of the following attributes of advertising regarding scheduling for seasonal product categories, and involves intermittent and irregular periods of advertising?
  • A.Pulsing
  • B.Continuity
  • C.Concentration
  • D.Flighting
Correct Answer: Flighting

Media scheduling refers to the pattern of timing of an advertising, which is represented as plots on a flowchart on a yearly basis. The plots in the flowchart indicate the pattern of periods that matches with favorable selling periods. The following are the classical scheduling models:

 

1) Continuous Advertising:

This scheduling involves advertising the message evenly throughout a given period. For example, if company wants 48 television/radio spots, it will advertise 4 times in a month or once in a week, or on every Monday.

 

2) Concentrated Advertising:

This scheduling involves giving all the advertisement in a single period. Thus, the concentrated advertising means to spend the entire advertising budget within one flight. It is applicable when product is sold in one season, event, festival or holiday. For example, the company advertises 48 spots within four days during Diwali festivals, 12 times a day.

 

3) Flighting Advertising:

This scheduling involves giving advertisement at specific intervals. Company advertises for some period, followed by break of no advertisement, followed by the second flight of advertisement and likewise. Company with seasonal, cyclical, or infrequently purchase products follows such scheduling. Company with a limited fund prefers to advertise during a specific season or festival only.

 

4) Pulsing Advertising:

This scheduling is the combination of both continuous and fighting advertisements. It includes continuous advertising at low-weight level, reinforced periodically by waves of heavier activity. In other words, the company spends certain portion of advertising fund for continuous advertising, and the remaining fund for fighting advertisement.

Question 23
Match the media factors given in List-I with examples given in List-II and indicate the code of current matching. (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)List – Ia. Media classb. Media vehiclesc. Media optiond. Scheduling & timingList – IIi. Prime time at 9:00 PM, full page ad of Honda Cityii. Magazine, T.V., Radioiii. Flighting, Pulsingiv. Times of India, T.V. serial Bhabhi Ji Ghar Pe HainCodes
  • A.a-ii b-iv c-id-iii
  • B.a-iii b-ic-iv d-ii
  • C.a-ib-ii c-iv d-iii
  • D.a-iv b-ii c-iii d-i
Correct Answer: a-ii b-iv c-id-iii

Media Class- A media class is a general category of media, such as television, radio, newspapers, magazines and the Internet.

 

Media Vehicle- The vehicle is the specific TV or radio station, newspaper or print publication, or online website. Examples Times of India, T.V. serial Bhabhi Ji Ghar Pe Hain

 

Media Option-Media option is defined as the predefined option for advertisement like in print media size and page fixation of advertisement, on air a specific time scheduling of advertisement. Example- Prime time at 9:00 PM, full page ad of Honda City.

 

Scheduling & timing- In terms of overall advertising expenditures, media advertising is still dominated by press and television. 

 

Scheduling refers to the pattern of advertising timing, represented as plots on a yearly flowchart. The classic scheduling models are continuity, flighting, and pulsing.

 

Media Scheduling Patterns: Continuity, concentration, flighting, and pulsing and different timing strategies:

 

Continuity – Is achieved by scheduling exposures evenly throughout a given period.

 

Concentration – Calls for spending all the advertising dollars in a single period.

 

Flighting – calls for advertising for some period, followed by an interruption of no advertising, followed by a second period of advertising activity.

 

Pulsing – Continuous advertising at low-weight levels reinforced periodically by waves of heavier activity.

Question 24
Assertion “A”:Too many stimuli make a person accommodated to those sensations. Sensory adaptation is a problem that concerns many advertisers, which is why they try to change their advertising campaigns regularly.Reason “R”:To cut through advertising clutter and to ensure that consumers perceive advertisement, marketers try to increase sensory input.Codes
  • A.A is correct and R is incorrect
  • B.A is incorrect and R is correct
  • C.Both A and R are correct but R does not explain A
  • D.Both A and R are correct and R explains A
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R explains A

Sensation is the immediate and direct response of the sensory organs to stimuli. A stimulus is any unit of input to any of the senses. Examples of stimuli (i.e., sensory input) include products, packages, brand names, advertisements, and commercials. Sensory receptors are the human organs (the eyes, ears, nose, mouth, and skin) that receive sensory inputs.

 

Sensory adaptation is a problem that concerns many national advertisers, which is why they try to change their advertising campaigns regularly. They are concerned that consumers will get so used to their current print advertisement and TV commercials that they will no longer "see" them: that is, the advertisement will no longer provide sufficient sensory input to be noted.

Question 25
The model of decision support where there is recommendation of the type of advertisement with humorous and ‘slice of life’ kinds of appeals to use for given marketing goals and characteristics of products, target markets and competitive situations is known as: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.MEDIAC
  • B.PROMOTOR
  • C.ADCAD
  • D.COVERSTORY
Correct Answer: ADCAD

Marketing Information System can be defined as a computer based system that works in conjunction with other functional information systems to support the firm’s management in solving problems that relate to marketing the firm’s products. A DSS (Decision Support System) is formed for recommendation of the type of advertisement to be used. There are several modules and software used for deciding the same. Few of them are:

 

BRANDAID: Flexible marketing-mix model focuses on packaged goods, contains sub models for advertising, pricing and competition.

CALLPLAN: Determine no. of calls to make per person to each prospect and current client, takes into account travel time and selling time.

DETAILER: Determine which customers to call on and which products to represent on each call

GEOLINE: Helpful in designing sales and service territories.

MEDIAC: Helps advertisers in media planning.

PROMOTER: Helps in evaluating sales promotion.

ADCAD: Determine type of advertisement that can be used.

COVERSTORY: Helps in analyzing sales data and writing reports.

Question 26
Most of the money spent in measuring the effectiveness of advertising is spent on: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Communication-response research
  • B.Pre-testing the advertisements
  • C.Post-testing the advertisements
  • D.Sales-response research
Correct Answer: Pre-testing the advertisements

Pre-testing, also known as copy testing is a form of customized research that predicts in-market performance of an ad, before it airs, by analyzing audience levels of attention, brand linkage, motivation, entertainment, and communication, as well as breaking down the ad’s Flow of Attention and Flow of Emotion. Pretesting is also used to identify weak spots within an ad to improve performance, to more effectively edit, to select images from the spot to use in an integrated campaign’s print ad, to pull out the key moments for use in ad tracking, and to identify branding moments. Most of the money spent in measuring the effectiveness of advertising is spent on pre testing as the marketer has to conduct surveys with actual customers or test the advertisement in close to real settings.

Question 27
For promoting sales advertisingendeavorsmay be made as per: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)I. Competitive parityII. Objective and taskIII. Tied salesIV. All-one-can-AffordCodes:
  • A.I and II only
  • B.II, III and IV only
  • C.I, II and IV only
  • D.III and IV only
Correct Answer: I, II and IV only

Advertising decisions can be made based on following factors:

1. Competitive parity refers to the optimal expenditure needed on branding and advertising activities to stay on par with the competitors of a particular brand, product or company as a whole. Promotional budget is allocated based on the scrutiny of optimal level of market competition. Competitive parity is a defensive strategy that is used by businesses to defend their reputation, their brand and its positioning without resorting to the overspending of financial resources.

 

2. Businesses that use the objective and task method for determining advertising expenses allocate the marketing budget based on set objectives. To use this method, a company must define the desired results of advertising and the strategies and tactics required to achieve these results. Additionally, the business must assess the costs associated with these strategies and tactics. If no financial restrictions exist, a company can build its marketing budget by examining each goal or objective and the tasks necessary to reach these objectives.

3. All-one-can-Afford Under this approach, a company spends as much on advertising as it can afford. It can spend for advertising as much as the funds permit. From the name itself, it is clear that the affordable amount set aside for advertising is known as affordable method. This approach appears to be more realistic, for all companies generally spend that much amount on advertisements which they can afford, even though they may not say so.

 

4. Tied sales is the illegal practice of a company providing a product or service on the condition that a customer purchases some other product or service. It is frequently used in reference to banks and referred to as coercive tied selling, but is also associated with the sales practices of product tying or bundling, which may be legal in some contexts. Tied selling may also be referred to as a "tying arrangement" or a "tying agreement."

Question 28
Who defines advertising as “any paid form of non-personal presentation and promotion of ideas, goods and services by an identified sponsor”? (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Philip Kotler
  • B.C.K. Prahlad
  • C.Chartered Institute of Marketing
  • D.American Marketing Association
Correct Answer: American Marketing Association

Chartered Institute of Marketing defines advertising as “any paid form of non-personal presentation and promotion of ideas, goods and services by an identified sponsor”.

Question 29
Selection of specific media in which advertisements will be run and when they will be run to reach the target market is called:(UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Advertising
  • B.Public Relations
  • C.Media Planning
  • D.Publicity
Correct Answer: Media Planning

Media Planning is generally outsourced to a media agency and entails sourcing and selecting optimal media platforms for a client’s brand or product to use. The job of media planning is to determine the best combination of media to achieve the marketing campaign objectives. It also decides the time schedule and time duration for which the advertisements are to be run to reach the target market. It is part of advertising which is one of the promotion mix.

 

Promotion Mix consists of: Advertising, Personal Selling, Sales Promotion, Public Relations and Direct Marketing.

Question 30
The most significant advantage in the use of newspaper as an advertising medium is(UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.Audience selectivity
  • B.Flexibility
  • C.High attention
  • D.National market coverage
Correct Answer: Flexibility

Merits of Advertising in Newspapers:

The following are some of the advantages of newspaper advertising:

1. Wide coverage: Newspapers serve local, regional and national markets. They reach people of all age groups and all income levels, both in cities and rural areas.

In the question D is not the answer because not all newspapers serve national market.

 

2. Quick response: Newspapers are the carriers of current news. People read them to find out the various developments that take place daily. Newspaper advertisements have a sense of urgency. The public response to the advertisements is immediate as it reaches them while they are fresh and are in a receptive mood.

 

3. It is regular and frequent: For those manufacturers who are more particular about the frequency and regularity of their message, there is nothing like newspaper advertising. Newspaper advertising keeps the product or the service constantly before the readers. It reminds them of the product or the service.

 

4. Flexibility: Advertisements can be inserted or changed practically overnight. Retail advertisers often make last minute changes in their newspaper advertisements to take full advantage of newly arrived products, last minute concessions to boost the sales — Hence, flexibility is an unique aspect in newspaper adverting.

 

5. Economical: Newspaper advertising, in view of the extent of coverage in terms of circulation has one of the lowest cost per reader.

 

Demerits of Advertising in Newspapers

The following are some of the disadvantages of newspaper advertising:

 

1. Newspapers have shortest life span: Newspapers have the shortest life. It has been estimated that the effective life of newspaper for an individual is about 15 to 20 minutes. None bothers to refer back the newspaper which becomes stale. Hence, to make the impression of advertisement lasting, the advertiser has to repeat his advertisements, involving additional costs.

 

2. It lacks quality reproduction: The paper in which newspapers are printed are of low quality, compared to magazines. Hence, the advertisements may not be very appealing, which is an essential factor for any advertisement.

 

3. Limited readership: As illiterate people cannot read the newspaper; the reach of the advertisement is confined only to the educated persons. Hence, this factor could pose a problem in rural India.

 

4. Element of uncertainty: As many readers ‘rush’ through their newspapers hurriedly, they may fail to see the advertisements totally. So, the number of people who may miss out the advertisement is more in newspapers.

Question 31
The most important factor in selecting advertising media is:(UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.Media cost
  • B.Media preference of target audience
  • C.Nature of the product
  • D.Type of message
Correct Answer: Media preference of target audience

Factors Governing the Choice:

1. The nature of product:

A product that is needed by all will encourage mass media like print, broadcast, telecast, outdoor and the like. A product needing demonstration warrants television and screen advertising. Industrial products find favour of print media than broadcast media. Products like cigarettes, wines and alcohols are never advertised on radio, television and screen.

 

2. Potential market:

This crucial task rests in identification of potential market for the product in terms of the number of customers, geographic spread, income pattern, age group, tastes, likes and dislikes and the like. If the message is to reach the people with high income group, magazine is the best. If local area is to be covered, newspaper and outdoor advertising are of much help. If illiterate folk is to be approached, radio, television and cinema advertising are preferred.

Hence, media preference of target audience is very important as advertisements are directed towards them only.

 

3. The type of distribution strategy:

The advertising coverage and the distribution system that the company has developed have direct correlation. Thus, there is no point in advertising a product if it is not available in these outlets where he normally buys. Similarly, the advertiser need not use national media if not supported by nationwide distribution network.

 

4. The advertising objectives:

Though the major objective of every company is to influence the consumer behavior favorably, the specific objectives may be to have local or regional or national coverage to popularize a product or a service or the company to create primary or secondary demand to achieve immediate or delayed action to maintain the secrets of the house.

 

5. The type of selling message:

It is more of the advertising requirements that decide the appropriate choice. The advertisers may be interested in appealing the prospects by colour advertisements. In that case, magazine, film, television, bill- boards, bulletin boards serve the purpose.

 

6. The budget available:

A manufacturer may have a very colourful and bold plan of advertising. He may be dreaming of advertising on a national television net-work and films. If budget does not allow, then he is to be happy with a low budget media like his news-paper and outdoor advertising.

 

7. Competitive advertising:

A shrewd advertiser is one who studies carefully the moves of his competitor or competitors as to the media selected and the pattern of expenditure portrayed. Meticulous evaluation of media strategy and advertising budget paves way for better choice.

 

8. Media availability:

The problem of media availability is of much relevance because; all the required media may not be available at the opportune time. This is particularly true in case of media like radio and television; so is the case with screen medium. Thus, non-availability of a medium or a media poses a new challenge to the media planners and the people advertising industry. It is basically an external limit than the internal constraint.

 

9. Characteristics of media:

Media characteristics differ widely and these differences have deep bearing on the choice of media vehicle. These characteristics are: Coverage, Reach, Cost, Consumer confidence and Frequency.

Question 32
Which one of the following attributes of advertising regarding launching of a new product calls for spending all the advertising budget in a single period? (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.Pulsing
  • B.Continuity
  • C.Concentration
  • D.Flighting
Correct Answer: Concentration

Media Scheduling Patterns: Continuity, concentration, flighting, and pulsing and different timing strategies:

Continuity – Is achieved by scheduling exposures evenly throughout a given period.

Concentration – Calls for spending all the advertising dollars in a single period.

Flighting – calls for advertising for some period, followed by an interruption of no advertising, followed by a second period of advertising activity.

Pulsing – Continuous advertising at low-weight levels reinforced periodically by waves of heavier activity.

It also involves deciding on geographical media allocation.

Question 33
Which method of setting advertising budget is most scientific and logical? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.All-you-can afford method
  • B.Competitive parity method
  • C.Objective-and-task method
  • D.Percentage-of-sales method
Correct Answer: Objective-and-task method

Objective-and-task method- Businesses that use the objective and task method for determining advertising expenses allocate the marketing budget based on set objectives. To use this method, a company must define the desired results of advertising and the strategies and tactics required to achieve these results. Additionally, the business must assess the costs associated with these strategies and tactics. If no financial restrictions exist, a company can build its marketing budget by examining each goal or objective and the tasks necessary to reach these objectives. A primary challenge associated with this method is the difficulty of accurately assessing the advertising costs necessary to accomplish the goals. This method is considered as most scientific and logical because it starts with object setting and then move ahead according to firms’ requirement.

 

Competitive parity method –Advertising expense budgeting method based on what a brand's or firm's competitors are estimated to be spending. This method assumes the other firms have the same marketing objectives and know what they are doing.

 

Percentage-of-Sales Method: Due to its simplicity, the percentage of sales method is the most commonly used by small businesses. When using this method an advertiser takes a percentage of either past or anticipated sales and allocates that percentage of the overall budget to advertising. Critics of this method, though, charge that using past sales for figuring the advertising budget is too conservative and that it can stunt growth.

 

All-you-can afford Method: Under this method the advertising budget is decided on the basis of whatever money is left after all other fixed and unavoidable expenses have been allocated. Conservative management uses this method & also new entrepreneur follow this when they are short of funds & have no other options.

Question 34
Statement I:‘Reach’ is the percentage of people in the target market exposed to an ad campaign during a given period.Statement II:‘Frequency’ is the number of times the average person in the target market is exposed to an advertising message during a given period.Codes:
  • A.Statement I and Statement II both are correct.
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct.
  • C.Statement I and Statement II both are incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
Correct Answer: Statement I and Statement II both are correct.

Steps in developing an advertising program, are (based on 5 M’s):

1. Setting advertising objectives (Mission)

 

2. Deciding on the advertising budget (Money)

 

3. Choosing the advertising message (Message)

 

4. Deciding on Media Strategies (Media)

- Media Selection – finding the most cost-effective media to deliver the desired number and type of exposures to the target audience. It involves deciding on Reach (number of people exposed), Frequency of exposure, and Impact (qualitative value). The relationship between reach “R”, frequency “F”, and impact “I” is shown in total number of exposures (R × F), and weighted number of exposures (R × F × I)

 

Reach is the percentage of people in the target market exposed to an ad campaign during a given period.

Frequency is the number of times the average person in the target market is exposed to an advertising message during a given period.

Media impact is the qualitative value of an exposure through a given medium.

 

5. Measuring Effectiveness (Measurement)

There are 2 Methods:

Communication-effect research

Sales Effect Research

Question 35
The _________ is an advertising strategy that focuses on low-cost unconventional marketing tactics that yield maximum results. The original term was coined by Jay Conrad Levinson in his 1984 book.
  • A.Right-Time Marketing
  • B.Demand Chain
  • C.Services Marketing
  • D.Guerrilla Marketing
Correct Answer: Guerrilla Marketing

a) Guerrilla Marketing - Guerrilla marketing is a marketing tactic in which a company uses surprise and/or unconventional interactions in order to promote a product or service. Guerrilla marketing is different from traditional marketing in that it often relies on personal interaction, has a smaller budget, and focuses on smaller groups of promoters that are responsible for getting the word out in a particular location rather than through widespread media campaigns.

 

b) Right-Time Marketing - Right Time Marketing is a way to boost customer acquisition and retention, provide seamless customer experiences, and grow revenue by understanding a customer’s characteristics, channel preferences and in-market purchase signals. It uses 4 R’s – right person, right channel, right moment and right answer.

 

c) Demand Chain – Demand is simply supply chain as seen from the viewpoint of the customer, who chooses among competing products and services and, thus, controls the demand.

 

d) Services Marketing - Services marketing is a broad category of marketing strategies focused on selling anything that is not a physical product. This includes everything from personal services like medical care and spa treatments, to the rental of vehicles and spaces, to experiences like concerts and dance lessons. Any method that can communicate a service's appeal and benefits to customers is a valid approach, including informational content, promotional deals, advertisements, and many other kinds of marketing materials.

Question 36
In choosing media, the advertiser has:
  • A.Micro scheduling decisions
  • B.Macro scheduling decisions
  • C.Both Micro and Macro scheduling decisions
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Both Micro and Macro scheduling decisions

2 major decisions are looked upon by an advertiser while deciding on which media to choose- Macro-Scheduling and Micro-Scheduling decisions.

 

1. Macro-Scheduling Decisions: relates to seasons and the business cycle. Suppose 70 percent of a product’s sales occur between June and September. The firm can vary its advertising expenditures to follow the seasonal pattern, to oppose the seasonal pattern, or to be constant throughout the year.

 

2. Micro-Scheduling Decisions: are the decisions for allocating advertising expenditures within a short period to obtain maximum impact. With respect to timing of the advertisement, they can be concentrated (“burst” advertising), dispersed continuously throughout the month, or dispersed intermittently. Also, advertising messages can be beamed with a level, rising, falling, or alternating frequency.

 

The timing pattern should consider 3 factors:

(i) Buyer turnover expresses the rate at which new buyers enter the market; the higher this rate, the more continuous the advertising should be.

(ii) Purchase frequency is the number of times the average buyer buys the product during the period; the higher the purchase frequency, the more continuous the advertising should be.

(iii) Forgetting rate is the rate at which the buyer forgets the brand; the higher the forgetting rate, the more continuous the advertising should be.

 

In launching a new product, the advertiser must choose among continuity, concentration,

flighting, and pulsing.

Question 37
Match the following.List-I (Medium)(a) Direct Mail(b) Television(c) MagazinesList-II (Advantages/Limitations)(i) High geographic and demographic selectivity(ii) Personalization(iii) High absolute costChoose the correct option from the following codes.Codes
  • A.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(ii), (c)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)

There are many advertising media available for marketer through which they can reach out to their target audience. Some of the traditional forms of media with their costs, advantages and limitations are enlisted below:

 

Question 38
Select the statement which is NOT true for a marketer while selecting print media as a media vehicle.
  • A.The media planner ranks each magazine by cost per thousand.
  • B.Marketers choose magazines with the highest cost per thousand for reaching target consumers.
  • C.Marketers need to apply several adjustments to the cost-per-thousand measure.
  • D.Magazines often put together a “reader profile” for their advertisers.
Correct Answer: Marketers choose magazines with the highest cost per thousand for reaching target consumers.

The media planner ranks each magazine by cost per thousand and favours magazines with the lowest cost per thousand for reaching target consumers. The magazines themselves often put together a “reader profile” for their advertisers, describing average readers with respect to age, income, residence, marital status, and leisure activities.

 

Marketers need to apply several adjustments to the cost-per-thousand measure. First, they should adjust for audience quality. For a baby lotion ad, a magazine read by 1 million young mothers has an exposure value of 1 million; if read by 1 million teenagers, it has an exposure value of almost zero. Second, adjust the exposure value for the audience-attention probability. Readers of Vogue may pay more attention to ads than do readers of Newsweek. Third, adjust for the medium’s editorial quality (prestige and believability). People are more likely to believe a TV or radio ad and to become more positively disposed toward the brand when the ad is placed within a program they like. Fourth, consider ad placement policies and extra services (such as regional or occupational editions and lead-time requirements for magazines).

Question 39
Match the following.List I (Place Advertising Options)a) Billboardsb) Public Spacesc) Product Placementsd) Point of purchaseList II (Location)1) movies2) colourful, digitally produced graphics3) live sampling4) hotel elevatorsChoose the correct option from the following:Codes
  • A.a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4
  • B.a- 2, b- 3, c-1, d-4
  • C.a- 4, b-3, c-2, d-1
  • D.a-2, b-4, c-1, d-3
Correct Answer: a-2, b-4, c-1, d-3

Place advertising, or out-of-home advertising, is a broad category including many creative and unexpected forms to grab consumers’ attention. The rationale is that marketers are better off reaching people where they work, play, and, shop. Popular options include billboards, public spaces, product placement, and point of purchase.

 

There are many ways marketers do out-of-home advertising or place advertising. Some popular ways are: billboards, public spaces, product placement, and point of purchase.

 

1. Billboards: use of colourful, digitally produced graphics, backlighting, sounds, movement, and unusual 3D-images in the form of huge hoardings.

 

2. Public Spaces: It involves placing ads in unconventional places such as on airplanes, in fitness clubs, as well as in classrooms, sports arenas, office and hotel elevators, and other public places. Advertisers can buy space in stadiums and arenas and on garbage cans, bicycle racks, parking meters, airport luggage carousels, elevators, gasoline pumps, the bottom of golf cups and swimming pools, airline snack packages, and supermarket produce in the form of tiny labels on apples and bananas.

 

3. Product Placements: Marketers pay product placement fees of lakhs of rupees so their products will make cameo appearances in movies and on television. Some firms get product placement at no cost by supplying their product to the movie company (Nike does not pay to be in movies but often supplies shoes, jackets, bags, and so on). Increasingly, products and brands are being woven

directly into the story.

 

4. Point of Purchase (P-O-P): also called In-store advertising, includes ads on shopping carts, cart straps, aisles, and shelves, as well as promotion options such as in-store demonstrations, live sampling, and instant coupon machines.

Question 40
A type of advertising where marketers reaches the people where they work, play or shop is known as:
  • A.Online Advertising
  • B.Place Advertising
  • C.In-house Advertising
  • D.Broadcast Advertising
Correct Answer: Place Advertising

Place advertising, or out-of-home advertising, is a broad category including many creative and unexpected forms to grab consumers’ attention. The rationale is that marketers are better off reaching people where they work, play, and, shop. Popular options include billboards, public spaces, product placement, and point of purchase.

Question 41
What is weighted average number of exposure of an advertisement on audience?
  • A.R×F×I
  • B.R×F+I
  • C.R×F/I
  • D.R+F+I
Correct Answer: R×F×I

The effect of exposures of an advertisement on audience awareness depends on the exposures’ reach, frequency, and impact:

 

Reach (R)- The number of different persons or households exposed to a particular media schedule at least once during a specified time period.

 

Frequency (F)- The number of times within the specified time period that an average person or household is exposed to the message.

 

Impact (I)- The qualitative value of an exposure through a given medium (thus a car ad will have a higher impact in Autocar magazine than in Filmfare magazine).

 

The relationship between reach, frequency, and impact is given below:

 

Total number of exposures (E), E = R × F also called the Gross Rating Points (GRP).

 

For example, if a given media schedule reaches 80 percent of homes with an average exposure frequency of 3, the media schedule has a GRP of 240 (80 × 3).

 

Weighted number of exposures (WE), WE = R × F × I

Question 42
Assertion “A”:In an ad campaign, what is being said is more important than how it is being said.Reason “R”:Marketers employ both art and science to develop the message strategy or positioning of an ad—what the ad attempts to convey about the brand—and its creative strategy—how the ad expresses the brand claims.Choose the correct option from the following:Codes
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R explains A
  • B.A is correct and R is incorrect
  • C.A is incorrect and R is correct
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect
Correct Answer: A is incorrect and R is correct

In designing and evaluating an ad campaign, marketers employ both art and science to develop the message strategy or positioning of an ad—what the ad attempts to convey about the brand—and its creative strategy—how the ad expresses the brand claims. Advertisers go through 3 steps while designing an ad campaign: message generation and evaluation, creative development and execution, and social-responsibility review.

 

Message Generation: Advertisers are always seeking “the big idea” that connects with consumers rationally and emotionally, sharply distinguishes the brand from competitors, and is broad and flexible enough to translate to different media, markets, and time periods.

 

Creative Development and Execution: The ad’s impact depends not only on what it says, but often more important, on how it says it. Execution can be decisive. Every advertising medium has advantages and disadvantages. Some of the advertising media used by marketers are television, print, and radio.

 

Social-Responsibility Review- To break through clutter, some advertisers believe they have to be edgy and push the boundaries of what consumers are used to seeing in advertising. In doing so, marketers must be sure advertising does not overstep social and legal norms or offend the general

public, ethnic groups, racial minorities, or special-interest groups.

 

Therefore, it can be concluded that how the message is executed is equally important as the content of the message. Hence, Assertion is incorrect, and Reason is correct.

Question 43
There are several factors that play a major role in deciding budget for advertising. Identify one of them from the following.
  • A.Product type
  • B.Marketer’s will
  • C.Stages in Product Life Cycle
  • D.Mission vision of the company
Correct Answer: Stages in Product Life Cycle

Here are 5 specific factors to consider when setting the advertising budget-

 

1. Stage in the Product Life Cycle- New products typically merit large advertising budgets to build awareness and to gain consumer trial. Established brands usually are supported with lower advertising budgets, measured as a ratio to sales.

2. Market share and consumer base- High-market-share brands usually require less advertising expenditure as a percentage of sales to maintain share. To build share by increasing market size requires larger expenditures.

3. Competition and clutter- In a market with a large number of competitors and high advertising spending, a brand must advertise more heavily to be heard. Even simple clutter from advertisements not directly competitive to the brand creates a need for heavier advertising.

4. Advertising frequency- The number of repetitions needed to put the brand’s message across to consumers has an obvious impact on the advertising budget.

5. Product substitutability- Brands in less-differentiated or commodity-like product classes (beer, soft drinks, banks, and airlines) require heavy advertising to establish a unique image.

Question 44
Automobile ads depicting satisfied customers enjoying special features of their new car would be an example of:
  • A.Reminder Advertising
  • B.Persuasive Advertising
  • C.Informative Advertising
  • D.Reinforcement Advertising
Correct Answer: Reinforcement Advertising

An advertising objective (or goal) is a specific communications task and achievement level to be accomplished with a specific audience in a specific period of time. We can classify advertising objectives according to whether their aim is to inform, persuade, remind, or reinforce. These objectives correspond to different stages in the Hierarchy-of-Effects Model.

 

(i) Informative advertising aims to create brand awareness and knowledge of new products or new features of existing products.

 

(ii) Persuasive advertising aims to create liking, preference, conviction, and purchase of a product or service. Some persuasive advertising uses comparative advertising, which makes an explicit comparison of the attributes of two or more brands.

 

(iii) Reminder advertising aims to stimulate repeat purchase of products and services. Expensive, four-color Coca-Cola ads in magazines are intended to remind people to purchase Coca-Cola.

 

(iv) Reinforcement advertising aims to convince current purchasers that they made the right choice. Automobile ads often depict satisfied customers enjoying special features of their new car.

Question 45
Which of the following is NOT one of the 5 Ms of advertising?
  • A.Money
  • B.Market
  • C.Mission
  • D.Measurement
Correct Answer: Market

In developing an advertising program, marketing managers must always start by identifying the target market and buyer motives. Then they can make the five major decisions, known as the Five Ms of Advertising:

 

Mission: What are our advertising objectives?

Money: How much can we spend and how do we allocate our spending across media types?

Message: What message should we send?

Media: What media should we use?

Measurement: How should we evaluate the results?

Marketing management must make four important decisions when developing an advertising program.

(i) Objective Setting: The first important advertising decision in developing an advertising program is setting the advertising objectives. The decisions of the past about the target market, Marketing Mix and positioning serve as a basis for the determination of the main job of advertisement in the total of advertising program. An advertising objective is defined as a particular task of communication that should be completed with a particular target audience and in a particular duration of time frame.

(ii) Budget decisions: When the advertising objectives are determined, then the next step of the advertising decisions is to determine the advertising budget for each market and product category. There are four methods for setting an advertising budget which are as follow: Affordable Method, Percent of Sales method, Competitive parity Method, Objective & Task Method. Whichever method is adopted for the budgeting of the advertisement; the main focus is to consider the appropriate amount of the advertising.

(iii) Developing an Advertising Strategy: The advertising strategy includes the following two areas of the advertising decisions:

Message Decisions: The success of advertising is not based on the portion of budget utilized, but it relies on the content of the messages that can attract attention of the customers and show clear picture. The effective advertising messages are required, which otherwise can cause serious problems to the advertiser. In the old days all the viewers of the television have limited option of few channels that can show them a great proportion of ads. But now with the advancement in the world, there are many options to the viewers of televisions and they can easily avoid many of the unwanted or boring messages. So the advertiser must develop a compelling creative concept – the compelling “big idea” that will bring an advertising message strategy to life in a distinctive and memorable way.

Media Decisions: The media decision of advertising strategy consists of the selection of proper media that can be effectively delivered the developed message. For this purpose, media planning is done by the media department in the organization to eliminate the friction between effective advertising message and appropriate media. The selection of media is carried out through the following steps.

(a) The decision of the frequency, reach & impact.

(b) Selection of one of media among prominent media categories.

(c) Selection of Particular vehicles of media.

(d) Decision about the timing of the media selected.

Advertising Media is the vehicle through which advertising messages are delivered to their intended audiences.

(iv) Evaluating Advertising Campaigns: The fourth & the last step in the related to the advertising decisions is the evaluation of the advertising campaigns. The advertising program not only evaluates the effects of Communication of Advertising, but also the effects of sales. All this evaluation is carried out on a regular basis. For the purpose of evaluation of communication effects, a technique called copy testing is used which can tell about any particular ad that either it is communicated well or not.

Copy testing technique can be adopted before or after the printing or broadcasting of any ad before placement of an ad, the advertiser can present it to the customers and ask various questions about the ad like how they feel about it? In this the advertiser can evaluate the attitudes of different customers and try to find the exact results of the ad when the ad runs through a medium, the advertiser can evaluate the effects of that ad on customers by analyzing the knowledge, awareness and preferences of the customers about the product.

Return on advertising investment: The net return on advertising investment divided by the costs of the advertising investment.

Question 46
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Most direct marketers apply the RFM formula to select customers.Statement II:Marketers also identify prospects on the basis of age, sex, income, education, previous mail order purchases, and occasion.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Most direct marketers apply the RFM (recency, frequency, monetary amount) formula to select customers according to how much time has passed since their last purchase, how many times they have purchased, and how much they have spent since becoming a customer. Points are established for varying RFM levels; the more points, the more attractive the customer.

 

The company’s best prospects are customers who have bought its products in the past. Marketers also identify prospects on the basis of age, sex, income, education, previous mail order purchases, and occasion. For instance, College freshmen will buy laptop computers, backpacks, and compact refrigerators; newlyweds look for housing, furniture, appliances, and bank loans. Another useful variable is consumer lifestyle or “passions” such as electronics, cooking, and the outdoors.

Question 47
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Communication-effect research, called copy testing, seeks to determine whether an ad is communicating effectively.Statement II:Marketers should perform this test both before an ad is put into media and after it is printed or broadcast.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Most advertisers try to measure the communication effect of an ad—that is, its potential impact on awareness, knowledge, or preference. Communication-effect research, called copy testing, seeks to determine whether an ad is communicating effectively. Marketers should perform this test both before an ad is put into media and after it is printed or broadcast.

 

Pretest critics maintain that agencies can design ads that test well but may not necessarily perform well in the marketplace. Proponents maintain that useful diagnostic information can emerge and that pre-tests should not be used as the sole decision criterion anyway. Many advertisers also use post-tests to assess the overall impact of a completed campaign. If a company hoped to increase brand awareness from 20 percent to 50 percent and succeeded in increasing it to only 30 percent, then the company is not spending enough, its ads are poor, or it has overlooked some other factor.

Question 48
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Companies are generally interested in finding out whether they are overspending or underspending on advertising.Statement II:A growing number of researchers are striving to measure the sales effect of advertising expenditures instead of settling for communication-effect measures.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Companies are generally interested in finding out whether they are overspending or underspending on advertising. One way to answer this question is to work with the formulation for measuring Different Stages in the Sales Impact of Advertising.

 

A company’s share of advertising expenditures produces a share of voice (proportion of company advertising of that product to all advertising of that product) that earns a share of consumers’ minds and hearts and, ultimately, a share of market.

 

Researchers try to measure the sales impact by analyzing historical or experimental data. The historical approach correlates past sales to past advertising expenditures using advanced statistical techniques. Other researchers use an experimental design to measure advertising’s sales impact. A growing number of researchers are striving to measure the sales effect of advertising expenditures instead of settling for communication-effect measures.

Question 49
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Macro-scheduling decision relates to seasons and the business cycle.Statement II:Micro-scheduling decision calls for allocating advertising expenditures within a short period.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

In choosing media, the advertiser has both a macro-scheduling and a micro-scheduling decision. The macro-scheduling decision relates to seasons and the business cycle. Suppose 70 percent of a product’s sales occur between June and September. The firm can vary its advertising expenditures to follow the seasonal pattern, to oppose the seasonal pattern, or to be constant throughout the year.

 

The micro-scheduling decision calls for allocating advertising expenditures within a short period to obtain maximum impact.

 

Suppose the firm decides to buy 30 radio spots in the month of September several possible patterns are given in the figure. The left side shows that advertising messages for the month can be concentrated (“burst” advertising), dispersed continuously throughout the month, or dispersed intermittently. The top side shows that the advertising messages can be beamed with a level, rising, falling, or alternating frequency. The chosen pattern should meet the communications objectives set in relationship to the nature of the product, target customers, distribution channels, and other marketing factors.

 

The timing pattern should consider three factors. Buyer turnover expresses the rate at which new buyers enter the market; the higher this rate, the more continuous the advertising should be. Purchase frequency is the number of times the average buyer buys the product during the period; the higher the purchase frequency, the more continuous the advertising should be. The forgetting rate is the rate at which the buyer forgets the brand; the higher the forgetting rate, the more continuous the advertising should be.

Question 50
Match the following.List I(a) Continuity(b) Concentration(c) Flighting(d) PulsingList II(i) Online activities and programs designed to engage customers.(ii) Alternative advertising periods.(iii) Continuous advertising at low-weight levels.(iv) Exposures appear evenly throughout a given period.Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)

In launching a new product, the advertiser must choose among continuity, concentration, flighting, and pulsing.

(i) Continuity means exposures appear evenly throughout a given period. Generally, advertisers use continuous advertising in expanding market situations, with frequently purchased items, and in tightly defined buyer categories.

(ii) Concentration calls for spending all the advertising dollars in a single period. This makes sense for products with one selling season or related holiday.

(iii) Flighting calls for advertising during a period, followed by a period with no advertising, followed by a second period of advertising activity. It is useful when funding is limited, the purchase cycle is relatively infrequent, or items are seasonal.

(iv) Pulsing is continuous advertising at low-weight levels, reinforced periodically by waves of heavier activity. It draws on the strength of continuous advertising and flights to create a compromise scheduling strategy. Those who favour pulsing believe the audience will learn the message more thoroughly, and at a lower cost to the firm.

Question 51
When companies work with each other online and offline to promote each other, they are creating _____. (UGC NET Management Aug 2016)
  • A.Contextual advertisements
  • B.Alliance and affiliate programmes
  • C.Content sponsorships
  • D.Search related advertisements
Correct Answer: Alliance and affiliate programmes

The correct answer is (B) Alliance and affiliate programs.

 

When companies work with each other online and offline to promote each other, they are typically creating alliance and affiliate programs. These programs involve partnerships between businesses to mutually promote their products or services, often through various marketing and promotional channels. Content sponsorships and contextual advertisements can be part of these programs, but the broader term for such collaborations is "alliance and affiliate programs."

Question 52
The firm may go for defensive advertising as per which one of the followingapproaches.(UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.Percentage to sales approach
  • B.Return on investment approach
  • C.Competitive parity approach
  • D.Objective and task approach
Correct Answer: Competitive parity approach

The correct answer is (C) Competitive parity approach.

 

Defensive advertising is a strategy where a firm advertises to match or keep pace with the advertising and promotional efforts of competitors.
